div.p: The Famous Chinois: OR THE LOVES of Several of the FRENCH NOBILITY, under borrowed names. VVith a Key annexed.
LONDON, Printed by E. O. for Thomas Dring at the white Lion next Chancery Lane end in Fleettreet, 1669.

div.head: TO EUDORA.
div.p:
THe Famous Chinois comes, as obliged, towaite upon you in a habit of Englih phrae: putting him into which I have in the general taken patern, meaure and materials from that which was ome years ince made him in Frenth
by Monieur Du Ball; but, (if I may ay o without upicion, of arrogating or detracting as well as without guilt of it) not without more pains in particulars than Tranlatours commonly take, or ele ue to have acribed to them. I have thus employed ome months, becaue I have not had opportunity of atcheiving more elevated tudies, becaue I would not for my own atisfaction leave unfiniht what I was by the commendation of others induced to begin, and becaue
though there are abroad everal hitoricall dicoures very ravihingly and advantageouly compoed of Loves and Gallantries, they for the mot part have come out of the hop of inventive fany, but this under a Romanticke colour and fahion records not only very coniderable traveres and events of the ame kinde, but thoe alo as true as coniderable, and no where ele to be found. Whether my pains are worth either their own time, or that of peruing them, I ubmit to your examination and
judgement, whoe agenes and Candour together with the other trancending beauties, which hine in you, in a high degree concile to you the admirations and obervances of all that know you, but of none in a higher, than of Eleutherius.

div.head: The Firt BOOK.
div.p:
AT length the great Alcidor no longer able to endure that Certafilan hould o abolutely enjoy Atatia, Solicited her to conent, that he might again convey her out of his ingroing hands; and She indeed loved the Author of this Advice with too much Flame to be backward to comply with him in any thing that was honet and that admitted a plauible excue: but when She came eriouly to conider the Quality and Conequence of this Second Rape, She could finde no Praetext that was Tolerable with which to favour it. The Reaons which moved Her to diallow his Demands, and with which She endeavoured to ilence them, were, that She had no more any caue to complain of Certafilan, who treated Her with more weetnes than
She cared for, that She could not forake Him without makeing the King and Her Siter Her Enemies, without indeed working the ruine of her Honor and Comfort, and that She hoped they hould in time have Liberty of eeing and Entertaining one another at their Pleaure, without Her running away from Him, conidering that He kept Her not Company o cloely as He was wont, and beides was no longer jealous. Nothing could have come more trange to the Lovers Mind than did thee arguings of his Mitres; He took them not only for a flat Denial of what He had begged, but alo for an unquetionable Aurance that She no longer Loved Him: and hurried away with this Opinion, all in a rage he flung from her without vouchafeing her any Reply. This his Indignation was as wounding to Her, as Her reaoning had been offenive to Him; it truck deep into her Heart, and moved it from the bottom. But She conidered that it Imported Her not to be troubled at it, o as to be taken notice off, She therefore made ue of all Her forces to undergoe it o as became Her. But what with Her Inquietudes which grew Riotous, and what with the contraint which She Exercied upon Her elf
to uppres them, She o much indammaged Her Health that She within few houres went ick to Bed. Where having lain two dayes without Alcidor, who had knowledge of it, hewing himelf not at all concerned in it (as indeed looking upon it as Counterfeit) wallowing down the Affront which She could not chew upon without a mot exaperating digut, She gave Her Page the charge of the enuing Letter and bringing back an Anwer.

div.head: Ataia to Alcidor.
div.p:
WHat have I ever done againt you to Merit the Pain which You make Me endure? Have You oberved in Me one ole Motion tending to dipleae or dioblige You? If when You Propounded to Me a econd Flight, I freely, yet cooly repreented to You the Reaons by which I ought to be kept from it, is this a Crime which deerves to be puniht with o much Severity? I well know You have not to this hour been at all toucht with My Illnes, and yet I cannot forbear telling You that Your Dipleaure has well-nigh brought Me to the Grave. To hear Me as You have done, to have notice of my Indipoition, to be Concious to your elf tbat you are the caue of
it, and not in the leat to be moved at it, to think of this, Oh me! Afflicts Me to the utmot Point. I can go no farther, and if Your unkindnes continue, know that with the los of Your Affection You will quickly ee that of My Life.

Though at the intant of Reading thee Words, Alcidor's Heart felt it elf melt with Compaion, he nevertheles made it appear to him that brought them, as if they were altogether indifferent to him, and he at firt ent him away without an anwer, but having conidered that this was too roughly to handle Ataia, he caued him to be called back and gave him This.

div.head: Alcidor to Ataia.
div.p:
YOu doe me wrong to name the just reentment which I have of Your coldnes an over evere Punihment. For if You well conider how You have lighted My Loyal Paion, You will acknowledge that had I not taken notice of it, You might deervedly have named Me inenible. You have indeed Conferred Favors upon Me which I have Reaon to remember with an immortal and an untainted Gratitude, and if I left
You without bidding You Adieu, it is the repect that I bare You which Obliged Me to it. Would it have been jut for Me to have gone againt Your Will, and to have endeavoured by an Opinionative Obtinacy to have forced You to have granted Me that of which You found me unworthy? No, Madam Alcidor knows better how to live then o, and when it hall come to the los of his Life, He will never contradict it, if You have Ordained it. But that You may know what an Obequious Zeal I have for You, only recover your Health and You hall ee by the Continuation of My Services that I Honor You more than all the World beides.

Though the illnes of Ataia was very much augmented before her Page returned, She never the more forbore, when he preented thee Lines to Her, to take and Read them, and She took them, Read them, and thought of them with uch Hot and Violent Emotions that her Fever Redounded and put Her in much wore Condition than She before had been. Of this dangerous Surcharge of Her Ditemper Alcidor taied not long before he was Advertied, and after he was Advertied of it, laying aide all other Dipleaure but what that
Suggeted to him, He taied not at all before
• e went to ee Her •
Certafilan being at Her Bed-ide when he came into her Chamber, he received him with a handom Courteie, thankt him for his Care of viiting them in their Affliction, and expret a great contentment to ee him, which whither it was as real as it eemed great he could not Judge: Howoever that which Ataia derived from the ight of him was both real and great, it was far more Evident than that he could make any doubt of it; She was Extaied with it and fell in a Swoon in her Husband's Arms; at which Accident it was Legibly enough written in Alcidor's Looks that his heart was not in much better cae than was that of the Intranced. But the Remedies that were ued bringing her to her elf again (and together with her, her Sympathizer alo) no ooner almot had She opened her Eyes, but, Sir, aid Certafilan to him, our Company doth my Wifes Health an Injury, let us therefore, if you pleae, leave her for the Preent and return to her when She is in a better Capacity. If I knew my elf o unhappy, Replied Alcidor to him, as to increae the illnes of thoe whom I Viit, rather than doe them that Michief, I would all my
Life forbid my elf the ight of them, and ince you are of the Opinion that my Preence brings a Detriment to your Lady, I leave both her and your elf to your Repoes. By this his Reply Certafilan perceiveing that what he had aid had too harply Prickt him, he endeavoured by Excues and Blandihments to heal the hurt that he had made, but whatoever Skill he ued in the Endeavour he could not hinder him from going away in Dipleaure.

The Lover was indeed from this time, putting all things into the Ballance together, o Ill atisfied with the Husbands humour, that to give it no more Umbrage he reolved, not only to go no more to his Houe, but alo to deface out of his Soul all thoe Draughts which the Beauty of his Wife had Ingraved there. In Favour of this deigne he et himelf on work to urvey the more lovely Faces of Paquin, that o by their Variety or by the Prevalency of ome one of them he might be brought to forget that which he had a while adicted himelf to, but which now he wholly quitted to its Uncommunicative Proprietary: and of all, which in that his Copious Propect came under his Conideration, he was not long before he concluded Carmelia the mot worthy
of his Vows. That therefore he might have Liberty of Viiting her without upion he tyed himelf in o traight a friendhip with her Husband Clidantus that there was hardly in all the Court to be een its Parallel. By which means he and that Fair having a Frequent Convere, if his glowing heats for her oon grew to a burning Fever of Paion, She alo quickly began to languih with a Dieae which made her as much need him for her Phyician as he did her for his.

Thee new Loves knocking at Ataia's Eares, She was o far from Frowning upon them, that She with Smiles and from her heart bad them Welcom. Her Sentiments were indeed ince her Sicknes turned o contrary to what they had before been, that in the place of Amorous Paion She had nothing any longer for Alcidor but an Amicable care of his good. When the Forces of his Merit at any time Aaulted her, She by the Rules and helps of Prudent Vertue o Reolutely and Dextrouly defended herelf againt them that they could gain nothing upon her more than to make her admire in the Creature the Creators Magnificence. When She thought of what had pat between them, I hould be ready to
upect, aid he to her elf, that Alcidor would throw Dirt upon my Name, but that I am trongly aured that he hath more both of Widom and Generoity then to Defame a Woman who hath by more than Ordinary Repects Obliged him to her. Beides what Credit would he get in leading a Triumph over my Weaknes and etting up Trophies of an Advantage which my little reitance enabled him to acquire? Only Glorious Victories are to be publihed and not uch as digrace both the Vanquihed and Vanquiher together. Yet let us Write to him to let him ee that I, from my Soul renounce all former Pleaures, and that I doe o becaue I preferre my happynes before my Detruction. Accordingly She thus dret a Paper and ent it by Garinter.

div.head: Ataia to Alcidor.
div.p:
YOu ought not to take it ill if having Glory to gain by my good Works, I repent of haveing committed ill ones. We may by reaon of our Frailty ometimes fall, but being by the Benigne care of Heaven raied up again, it is our Duty inceantly to Act thanks to the Author of our Deliverance. This is that wherein I propoe Sedulouly to employ my elf for the Future, and upon that account
the Abode in which I at preent as Innocently as Loneomely lead my Life, is more agreeable to me, than the Palace of our Kings. See how I intend to pas the ret of my Dayes with Certafilan whoe Carriage is become o Unblameable that I have great Reaon both to admire his happy Change and to content my elf with it.

Alcidor having read thee Tearms was glad to undertand that he who wrote them would not diturb his new Affections nor be diturbed by them, and having weighed as well as read them he Drew this Anwer to them, and ent it away by him that brought them.

div.head: Alcidor to Ataia.
div.p:
I Mut be void of a Humane Soul not to approve your Holynes of Life, and though your Graces have made deeper Impreions upon my Mind than I can quickly blot out, I hall notwithtanding endeavour to have no other thoughts of them than uch as my Concience may in Jutice allow. See, Madam, if in whatoever Condition you are I have not a erious Ambition of atisfying you: Nor am I o much an Enemy to mine own Happynes as
not to go in earch of it by a Life which hall uddenly conform it elf to yours.

Garinter gone Alcidor went to Carmelia who waited for him to go along with her to ee her Husband at the Waters. Being alone when he entred her Chamber, It is indeed, Sir, aid he to him, a very Liberal expreion of your Goodnes that at my Husbands Intreaty you will Accompany me to the Place to whicb you have o lately given a Title by the Kind and Noble Rape which you Acted there: But not finding her there whom you carried thence every Minute of your tay, will be an houre of tediounes to you. There being no Object in the World o Amiable to me, nor Company o dear as you. Madam, replied Alcidor to her, Judge again and ay if I hall not account the Dayes which I hall pas in your Preence horter than hours, but alo weeter than Moneths pent any where ele. We know you are an excellent Artit of Rallery, interrupted him, Carmelia, without being thus informed of it, but remember that you in earnet wrong Ataia, when you though only in jet ue Courthip to any other Woman. Let us peak no more of Ataia, returned Alcidor, for he
is no more to be reckoned of the World, having withdrawn and • hut her elf up in a Solitude for the remainder of her Life. That o Conpicuous a Starre as Ataia, aid Carmelia again, hould of her own choie leave the clear and eminent Orb of the Court, where her Siter alo moves with mot prevailing Splendors and Influences, and for altogether betake herelf to the obcure Station of a Rural Privacy is a tory of much more Rarity and Wonder than that I hould eaily believe it, did any other but your elf tell me it. I never pake any thing more true, aid Alcidor: And I never heard any thing more trange, aid Carmelia, more trange, adjoyned he, than that the Fair can live content in a eparation from Alcidor who is looked upon as her Heart and Soul. I know not, aid Alcidor, what Immaginations thr World hath either of her or me; but this I can faithfully aure you, our Converation was never but very innocent and unblameable, and I conveighed her not away but with the King's Approbation. I am not about, returned Carm • lia, to make an ill Judgment of her, whom, notwithtanding that her Husbands jealouie hath made more than a few of the Oppinion that you have had an
abolute Power over her and governed her according to your Mind, I have always believed to be entirely age and to have teered her Converation with an unreproachable Dicretion. Certafilan himelf, aid Alcidor, hath by the change of his Mind, loudly confet the injutice of thoe upicions which he had of her Vertue, and their reconciliation makes it ufficiently appear that it was nothing but his undierved mitrutfulnes and headlong Frenzy which carried him to treat her o ill as he did, and nothing but his treating her o ill that caued her to take that coure that he did. And indeed, adjoyned Carmelia, whatoever ignorant or over Critical People may ay, I am altogether of the Mind that a Woman is very excueable in doing what may be thought direpectful to her Husband, when he without any apparent reaon but out of a Giddy Undicerning Rahnes, or an Exceptious Peevih Dipoition, paeth a Contumelious Sentence upon her honety. Not but that I know that the greatet part of the Men of this Age are poet with the immagination that the more Fair a Woman is, the les Chat he is, as if Nature never formed a Peron more than uually handom, but to be more than
commonly Vitious. This is, aid Alcidor, one of the groet abues that a Mind can poibly be educed with, and I cannot think that any Man will leave himelf to the urprize of it, Who is not o much a Fool that he knows not how to ditinguih between deert and default. For what appearance does it carry of Truth that Organs well dipoed in an Elegant Body hould be ubject to act les Vigorouly in what is good than what is placed in a body of a meaner Fahion, epecially conidering that they whoe form challengeth a Veneration for them have far more Advantages and Encouragements to do well than they who being expoed to contempt by their outides have little care taken of them and can procure little regard to be had, either to their Perons or their Actions. Of your Mind is my Husband, aid Carmelia, and I have often heard him ay that the more beautiful he aw a Woman, the more he eteemed her Retained and ober. I have, howoever, Madam, reumed Alcidor, for a long time oberved it to be true, that there is carce any evil that rageth with o wild a Violence, that o hardly admits of a remedy, and that produces uch ad and dimal effects as does the poyon of jealouie, epecially
when drunk in by a Man of Quallity and Stomach; all Theatres are died with the Bloud of its Tragoedies, To uch a height of Fury indeed, aid Carmelia, does this Malady ue to carry him whom it poees that rarely he can be cured but either by his own death or that of the Peron at whom he takes offence. But, thanks to my kind Detiny, I have a Husband of whom I have not the leat fear that he hould ever be infected with this o micheivouly fatal Plague. We ee much tranger things come to pas, aid Alcidor, than that there hould be ome Vaal of your Beauty who hould pay homage to it otherwie (though Vertuouly too) than Clidantus hould think convenient. But hould there be ome uch Man (as what Husband can hinder another Man from honoring his Wife above all other Women?) and Clidantus hould nor only take it ill, but alo interdict you his company, What in that cae would you reolve upon? Not to ee the Peron that might be upected by him, anwered Carmelia, that o I might remove from him all argument of afflicting himelf and me. Would you then, aid Alcidor, commit uch an injutice as to light them that honored you in favour of a ditrutful quarrelome
Husband? I could not be accued of any injutice, or of any lighting in doing o, replied Carmelia, becaue I did it not but by contraint and out of neceary coniderations of my Repoe, my Reputation and my Duty. I hould indeed reckon that it behoved me to put in practice all the expedients which I could have any hope would retore to a good temper him who was in o ill a one: But if I found them all unavailable, and that he would till perecute me notwithtanding all that I could do to oblige him to the contrary, I would no longer make any Difficulty of eperating my elf from him. So Ataia, aid Alcidor, cannot be in equity blamed for quitting Certafilan when he aw that by nothing that either he her elf or others could either ay or do he would be retrained from abuing her, and if you at any time hould do the like, forct to it as he was, your Vertue will appear not at all the les, ince reaonably one cannot dilike unfortunates for eeking to affranchize themelves from their preures. If I have poken any thing to the diadvantage of Ataia, aid Carmelia, you have caue to reprehend me for it; but tell me, I intreat you, what caue you have to immagine that a wie Man as is Clidantus and
that loves me with all his heart as he does hould ever turn Fool as did Certafilan, and by his unmerciful perecution of me, hould drive me to tread the ame path that did Ataia. As I have not Beauty nor other alectives, o no beliefe that any Man can have uch regards for me, as that thence his fancy hould have any thing of haddow to vex it elf about. How in aying o, Madam, interrupted her Alcidor, do you wrong heaven together with your elf diowning the abundant wealth of Graces which its goodnes hath betowed upon you. But, I mut beg leave farther to tell you that as you are at a great ditance lovely above others; o you are very far above others beloved, I am one that love you o, and the chains, which fetter my heart in this Affection are embodied into it and grown a much dearer part of it than that I hould be willing to part with them for all the Freedom with which the World can tempt me. You are come I ee, interrupted him Carmelia not o much to give me your Company as to make your elf port in jeering me. It is urely no making my elf port, nor jeering of you, returned Alcidor, to peak highly of that which every body that knows you prizes highly, and tell you that I adore you as with a mot
Profound reverence I do, I am come to wait upon you in your journey; and withall to gain an opportunity of declaring to you that my paion, which hath a great while been kept in by the awe in which I tand of you, but which now breaks its way out by its own greatnes and force. If the dicovery have any thing criminal in it, inflict upon me what punihment you hall think fit, I hall make no appeal from your entence, o long as I know that my Torment contents you. Know then, aid Carmelia, to what I condemn you; It is to live with me as you have been wont without peaking to me of Love or Paion, it being certain that you are either free from them, or if their troke hath reacht you, it is by the vertue of Ataia's Merrit, not of mine, which I am concious is too weak to take the meanet and mot facile heart Prioner, much les is it able to ubdue yours. To thee words Alcidor making anwer, firt with mot Eloquent ighs and ilence, then with mot earnet and winning protetations, that his heart was all an entire piece of Devotion to her and to none but her; he changed her tile and told him that becaue he would put him to no more trouble he would endeavour to believe what he had aid. Encouraged with this conceion, he imprinted
a flaming Kis upon her hand; which he not dicountenancing, he indutrouly purued his point with other Galantryes, and for his ucces evidently read it in her looks and ilence that he was very well pleaed with them, but withall as much ahamed as pleaed.

After he had at a while without peaking a word to him, or o much as looking him in the face, eeing Paper with Pen and Ink upon the Table he took the Pen and wrote, I Love, and then, he looking to to ee what he wrote, let drop the Pen, and fell a ighing. All which he took notice of; and better undertanding the advantage of the occaion than to let it lip, he intreated her to et down the ret of her thought: to which he anwering that it was without deign, that that word came to hand. He again o earnetly pret her to proceed, telling her that he was too judicious to begin to write, what he had no mind to finih, and that the beginning was too good to remain imperfect, that he reumed the Pen and compleated the Sentence in thee termes, I Love Alcidor, if • he be Dicreet. Having this hort, but acceptable line, he broke out into traines of Joy, Thanks and Love, in which he who was at other times wont to
excell others, now Farre excelled himelf. To repart to them, the Lady thought herelf concerned to ue uch Language as this, I confes it is not without Reaon that every one eteems you, Alcidor; you have powerful means to render your elf Mater of hearts, it is not now the firt time that I knew it, and ince the Princes Floria, and the weet Ataia hath been overcome by, and been glad to yeild to thoe your Powers, it cannot urely be ill thought of if I alo am urprized by them. If what therefore you have told me is true, all my Life hall witnes that what I have now written is certain. I confes, I love you, but I withall expect that a vertuous retainednes hould have the guidance of your carriage towards me, and if otherwie you at any time prove o unober as to deire of me, things which my honor permits me not to give you, aure your elf you hall carry away nothing of ill intenions, but a denial tamp with indignation; for I love my Husband, my Honety, and my Reputation better than to do anything that may prejudice any of them. Your decree is juter, Madam, replied Alcidor, than that I hould in the leat go againt it; and I am more effectually yours, than to ceae to be o by enterpries diagreeable
to you. Having topt a little at thoe words, I acknowledge, Madam, went he on, that you may with equity defend me from apiring to thoe Bli • es, which you have in your power to betow, but which are too great for the greatet, and of which they who have mot worth are unworthy: yet let your charity allow, as it unblameably may, that upon this beautiful Mouth of Roes, and this fair Boom of Lillies (together with thee words he kit them both) I protet before Love himelf, that I will hence forward have no other will but yours. This on-et of Love, gracefully conducted as it was, Carmelia not having the Power to take it ill, That I may not hew my elf o evere, aid he, in ome confuion of affection and modety, as to deny you what I may honetly grant you, I permit you this familiarity of Kies, provided they be innocent and free from impurity; but this is the greatet peronal kindnes that you are to expect from me, and that great enough to let you clearly ee, I love you to a high degree. The priviledge, Madam, returned Alcidor, is of a much Nobler value, than that in the frution of it I hould not own my elf a mot wealthy Man of happynes. More he was going to ay, but Felisbea coming
into the Chamber interrupted their convere, and they had at that time no more opportunity of dicoureing of any thing, but the journey which they were about to make together. They nevertheles expret their hearts to one another by igns as Emphatical as words, and having broken their Fats, and taken the Road, they there alo, though that Siter of Clidantus not a little obtructed their deernees, frequently tranmitted them by tealth to one another, without being at all perceived by her.

Confirmed by thee

that if he tayed with her any longer he mut either unworthily abue or ele Marry her, from both which he had many reaons that diwaded him, he enforced himelf to go on with what he had undertaken, and what he aw neceary, though harh. ved of him as well as of the ret. Rolimon did his endeavour to remove from her this impreion, peaking all that he could to the advantage of his friend; but he after all found that it was but labor in vain to go about to replace him in her favour. He ceaing therefore to alledge any thing more in his behalf, he changed her action and language, and uccinctly told them all that had pat between her and Alcidor, o handomely repreenting to them the Love which he had propounded to her, that they reented a high delight in hearing it, and earnetly connelled her to think of no other Husband. Alcidor, aid Rolimon, beides that he is of an illutrious Bloud, is Mater of Quallities, altogether uncommon to the World, his Courage maks him feared, his
Courteie loved, every thing of him admired, he hath gained a reputation of a large extent and a mot glorious nature, and hath deerved it as well as gained it, having done as eminent things as ever Man of his age and condition. Riches and Grandeurs do not at all blind him or allure his mind to a higher or more eager flight than becomes him: But had he occaions of enterprizing things atisfactory to the height and magnitude of his • oul, his Element would be to conquer Kingdoms. A great Princes and as fair as great would have made it her glory to have gained him for her Husband, but that he could not dipoe of her own will, nor could he conclude it convenient for him to Marry o famous a Paronage. If he loves you, as I have no reaon to doubt but he does by the tetimonies that you have given us of it, and your good Fortune brings you to be his Wife, as I have hopes it will, you may with a jut confidence rank your elf among the mot happy Women of China. I know his humour, I am acquainted with his Birth and Education; I undertand a great part of the motions of his Life, and can therefore peak of him, as I do with aurance. You peak too much on his ide, Sir, aid Dorame, not to make him uppear amiable and to oblige me
to court his neeret friendhip. Satisfied therefore as I am, that you know he outweighs Cartagenes, I am reolved to follow your advie and not by a di-ingenious, foolih, unworthy co • nes, debarre my elf of the preent, which heaven eems willing I hould receive. You have reaon indeed, Couzen, interpoed Melian, to think no more of your old ervants, for the one Alcidor's lutre darkens all theirs how coniderable oever. He who knows him, aid Vindorix, and will not acknowledge him compoed of worth, mut be concluded either to overflow with envy, or to be very defective in judgment, I with a great deal of Solicitounes wih you married to him, and I am in continual fear leat this good fortune hould be raviht from you by ome initer accident. Heaven, if it thinks good, returned Dorame to him, will preerve him from me. You had een him here at preent had not a quarrel between two of his friends called him away; but to morrow he is to return, and if he loves not me, yet he loves his word better than to fail. I wih, reumed Rolimon, that he veiled not his deign from you, and intead of going to agree ome friends is, not gone to fight ome Enemy. Give not your elf the trouble of uch
fears, replied Dorame to him, for I am very certain he hath nothing of difference of his own to decide with any body, having ight of a Letter which informed me he was only arbitrator in a diagreement of others. But ince you are pa • ticularly acquainted, as you was aying, with his life; the Hitory of it, during his abence, would be a diverion very agreeable to me if not a labor too troubleome to you, You could not ask me a thing, anwered her, Rolimon, which is more to my mind, than to entertain you with what I undertand of his affairs, and if you will not give me that attention which I may claim as their right, I doubt not but to make you confes that few things more coniderable have come to your ears. Preently Melian, Vindorix and Dorame eating themelves about him, he began his Narration in thee Tearms.

div.head: The Hitory of <>
div.p:
SInce I have undertaken to give you an account of as much as I know of Alcidor's Life, it is jut that I firt hew you what his Original was and what his younger Motions, rhat o by the one you may ee what a Noble Stock he grows upon, and by the other what an Elevation of Spirit he gave evidence of in his feeble years. He is Iued by his Father Miraldus of one of the mot antient Houes of the Province of Quincij, by his Mother Deifila of a Branch Royal of China, by both allied to the mot Eminent Families of the Kingdom. The Pomp of his Birth was equal to the height of it, there was no body coniderable in the Vicinage who came not to welcome him into the World, and Feats,
Bals, and all the more fahonable and elegant expreions of joy were for five days together the exercies of them that came. The firt hours of his birth, they who eriouly conidered him, not out of flattery but judgment, congratulated his Parents concerning him, as a work of their Mariage which Nature had taken a pleaure to render compleat. They themelves indeed could not look upon him without fancying his eyes, beamings of a Genius that promied nothing mean; and he gave a very early confirmation of their Fancy; for by that time he had gotten over four years he delighted himelf in nothing o much as in eeing Arms and Hores, and in handling the one and mounting the other, thereby giving Omens that holding dear in his Childhood the intruments of glory, he would in time prove by them as worthy an Heir of Miraldus his Reputation, as of his Etate.

When he had attained to an age capable of learning things worth the knowing, he found nothing difficult to him but comprehended them wholly almot as oon as he had the beginnings of them taught him. I my elf have, not without atonihment, oberved him to undertand at even years that which a better pirit than ordinary mut
have been at a great deal of p • ins to appr ••
hend at twelve, his judgment and gracefulnes were while he was a Child advanced to a maturity that pake him Man. Grown bigger he hewed himelf furniht with o many excellent quallities that his glad Parents thought it time that he hould ee the Superbe Court of Florimen, where they hoped he would one day make his Vertue hine, and there, if he was taken with the beauties of the place he took all that aw him with the early and mot hopeful bloomes of his youth; Arcantus in particular the King's Brother took him into his Boome, and affectionately made it his cai •
that there hould be nothing wanting to the rendring of him a mot compleat peron.

The various practies of the Indian Kingdome inciting the great Lords of China to revolt anew, and combutions being by that means kindled and blown up very dammagable to the State, in aggravation of the diorder, Arcantus complained that he was lighted, and that Podamus, • rates and Belliman had in the Counell of the twelve Auditors without calling him to it, acted as they thought good, very much in prejudice of his concerns. Nor did he complain only, but alo, not able to brook the
Bravades of thoe Princes who were trangers from the Royal Bloud, he departed from Court and levied Forces. In thee Alcidor commenc't the Soldior, following his Colours with an ardor anwerable to the obligation which he had to him, and which remarkably aupicated thoe great things which he afterwards performed.

From this pring many different motions ariing in China, the Prince Arcantes within a few days publihed a Declaration, in which he proteted that he had not departed and armed but to employ his Fortunes, Forces and Life, to remove the Authors of the publick confuion, to proecute jutice for <> the Rapires and Maacres comitted during the Reign of Trailas, and to retore the many Lords, Gentlemen and others that were in Prion and in Exile. In purute of this Declaration to encreae his Appennage and by common armes recover peace to the Nation, he joyned himelf with thoe of the new ect (as it was called) of Religion. But the Queen-Mother eeing that his Reentments and proceedings enfeebled rather than trengthened the authority which he aumed over all affairs made a journey to him, and by her powerfull influence and Prudential workings obtained
a ucces of Hotility for ix Moneths.

By the end of this time Rolianis Brother in Law to Florimen by the Marriage of his Siter having made an ecape from Court a potent Army of Male-contents was in the Field and Arcantes marching in the head of them. To oppoe them, Orates and thoe of his Houe framed a • eague and drew the King to ign it, and all was ready to be undone, when to take from the factious all pretext of fihing in troubled Waters, Arcantus returned to good tearms with the King, having obliged him to hold a general Counell of the Kingdom for recompening the good, punihing the bad, and etting right what was out of order.

All quarrels appeaed between the two Royall Brothers, the Revolters ent abroad their Manifeto's, and in calming this diturbance, was the King detained when came Deputies of the Province of Loxa to beg uccors of him, and to demand the Prince his Brother for Protector of their Liberties againt the Indians. What they askt they obtained; Arcantus was preently declared Lieutenant General, and with a coniderable um took his way to Brema, Alcidor both by the Prince's invitation, and
by the intigation of his own humor went one of the company thither, and he aw there o much Honor paid to Arcantus and o much affection hewed to the meanet of his retinue, that he was ready to repute their aboade there for that of Florimen's Palace, and that fair Town for the Florihing City of Paquin. All were indeed received by their new Hots with as much kindnees, as if they had been in their own Houes but they ill repaid their kindnees, • and and by grand diorders made them too quickly reckon, that the Chinoie tuition was les eaie to brook than the Indian Tyranny. In hort, whatoever good order Arcantus could take, who in an exemplary manner caued the inolents to be puniht, they who were called in for uccour loaded with uch ill uages by thoe that had called them, that to dienlave and revenge themelves together, they turned to weave conpiracies againt them, and reolved by an univeral Maacre to digorge them. From the reolution they oon pat to the execution, and it was o bloudy a one, that the Prince did not but with much difficulty ave himelf from it. A great part of his People were aainated in Brema, and Alcidor had in all likelyhood ran the ame fortune, had not the faithful Turgitus kept him concealed in his
Houe till the rage of the multitude was blown over. His Prince having left behind him that infamous aboade, when o much noblenes had in a mot horrid manner a Burying place given them, not eeing him among thoe that ecaped, believed without any farther hopes and therefore not without a Pathetick orrow that he had been Sacrificed to the ame barbarous fury with the ret. With the ame ad concluion were Miraldus and Deifila, after all the information that they could get, forced to it down, wholly overwhelmed with grief. But while they were lamenting him as dead, he on a udden preented himelf to them alive and well, and together with himelf Turgitus as the invaluable freind who had firt aved him from the tempet, and then taking the advantage of the fair weather that ucceded it had put him in diguie and conducted him to them. That the ight of him did in a moment change all their blacks into colors of extream joy and that his Deliverer had large heaps of remunerations thrown upon him, I upoe, I need not tel you.

Orastes and his confederates, no • able better to authorize their Monopolies than by etting the Subject againt the King, did by their ubtle acts o effectually work them
to their purpoe that to hear their inolent dicoures of their Sovereign and his Government would have inclined one to ay that he was bound to hold in fee of their capriciounes. In proecution of this they took up Arms and brought into the World the deigns which they had been a long time hatching, by the ame means ending Arcantus out of it, who with greif to ee his Brother and the Kingdom involved in the confuion of a ixth civil War, wherein alo he aw his own pretenions revered, fell ick and dyed. After his death the King who had no Child caued Potianis to be received as the firt Prince of the Bloud and Prime Victory of China. Where the Leagurers deriving freth pretexts of diatisfaction pake not of the King but with an unufferable contempt, told the Multitude that Polianis would bring the true Religion of China under the yoke of the new Sectaries, owed abroad defamatory Libels, vigorouly carried on their Counels in the Provinces of Iroquiam and Cantan, begot a numerous increae to their party in Paquin and every where induced the People to rie, who were otherwie dipoed to it by the corruptions of the Court. To prevent the ruine which by this means hung over the Publick
and to that purpoe to wah away the foundations of the Confederacy that threatned it, the King dipatcht Letters into all his Provinces, wherein he obliged the Governors of places and perons of quallity not to abandon his ervice and the common good. Among thee, Alcidor, though eminently recommendable for his Birth Courage, Vertues and Interets, and though Mater of a very large Etate which his lately deceat Father had left him, was forgotten to be put by the King. This forgetfulnes, boyling with a generous heat of Soul, he took for a Mark of contempt, and was toucht with it to the quick: from the emotion he proceeded to a conideration of concience, and repreenting to himelf that the Party of the League was of the true Religion and undertook its defence againt the other, he grew to an opinion that to follow them was to fight for God. Notice of his dicontent by ome factious intruments brought to Orates, he quickly ent to viit him with Officers of all the Advantages which in uch a War he could on his ide hope for, and when, not a little pleaed to ee himelf ought to by a Prince of o advanced a name and waying influence he as he thought himelf bound to do, went to
him, that perfect Courtier by the inevitable pels with which he laid hold upon him brought him with fervour to embrace his ide againt that of his Sovereign. Which done, to keep him his, as he made him, and withal to take the benefit of his being o, he gave him Moneys and Commiion to raie five hundred Hore, and he in execution of the trut was on a udden een at the head of many ilent Men, attempting and atchieving things which, called, not only the vulgar but the bravet of the Nation to take notice of him with admiration, and which particularly purchaed him the good will of Liantus one of the mot Gallant chiefs of the party.

The heads of the League, to give it good colour and to draw trength to it, had publiht very pecious principles as motives of it, and had conjured the Princes, Nobles and Commons to tand up for the Antient faith againt the Novel, which they aid the King favoured againt them, by that Lure decoying into them multitudes of credulous People. To impede this the King put abroad a Declaration in which he cleared himelf from the everal blots wherewith they apered him and particularly tetified that he bore a incere and contant love to the ettled Religion of China; that which diarmed a
great number of People and ome of them very coniderable; but not Alcidor, who perited o affectionate to the caue which he had epoued, believeing himelf bound to venture, and if need required, to pend his Life in its quarrel, that nothing but death eemed of power to dicover him from it. In proportion to his affection did his courage and Prudence labour for its advantage, but notwithtanding all the endeavors both of him and others to hold it up, they aw it in a hort time o enfeebled and bent to fall that they were contrained to incline to peace, and to return it, not for always, yet at leat for a time to the obedience of their King.

It was indeed no long time before they who had been o forced to lay down their Arms had taken them up again; which Polianis eeing put himelf in the Field with a very coniderable Strength, and as firt Prince of the Bloud declareing their practies Felonious proteted, he would as faithfully as necearily defend againt them the prerogative of the King, the State of the Queen Mother, and the fundamental Laws of the Realm. In equel of this the War becoming open, Alcidor got on Hore back and ranged himelf in the Army that was
led by Lucimon, where continually eeking occaions of Action he ignalized his vertue and aggrandized his name by deeds, which were altogether wonders. But he could not by all that he could do, protect that Brother of Orates from being as continually moleted o in everal Battels notably beaten by the Brother-in-law of Florimen.

Lucimon after a while advancing to Paquin, whoe Inhabitants had been diligently cha • ed to tir, and lookt with jealouie upon the intervier which Polianis and the Queen Mother had lately had, and there by the interet of Orates whom they worhipt as a God, making what impreion upon them he deired, Orates, himelf in another quarter with loud and harp invectives complaining of the King that he had labored againt his own work by revoking an authentick Edict of Peace by another which he had made ince, carried on the War with a very edulous and potent hand. In the end the Indians being called in by him and following his call, and the Kingdom being on all ides imbraced with Hotility, the Opponent Armies came to a bloody Fight, in which Lucoris was lain, Polianis remained Victorious, and the vanquiht were reduced
to uch an univeral diorder, extream confuion and mierable etate that they who ecaped from the deluge of blood that was hed, had wholly expoed themelves to the mercy of the Conquerors, had it not been for Alcidor, who as in the Battel, o in the rout and Flight, did all that it was poible for a Man of heart, to do. He with a management which can never be too much applauded carried of the aid relicks of the hipwrack, drew them into a Body and offered fair for the repairing of the los. But the Commanders proved too timerouly affected towards the undertaking, and the Soldiers more eager of ecuring, than of hazarding themelves and of running a way than of Fighting again.

The revolt was thus et at Bay; but the principal Authors of it determined, rather to Abys themelves in the ruines of the State, than change the coure which they had begun: and preently the King from all parts received Advertiement of the conpiring of his Subjects. For the neceary ecurity therefore both of his Peron and his head City, he put a Garrion in it; which Orates looking upon as intended a curb to his ambitious practies he o powerfully incited the people that they fall to barricading
and committed ravages altogether unworthy of Chinoies, and which made the King leave Paquin to go eek a helter againt the torm that threatned his life. The King, and with him the Court gone, the Mierable Citizens enible of the wound which they had thereby received, repented of their diobedience and deired the Parliament to beg their Pardon and humbly beeech his Majety to return to his Palace, and by his preence retore to that great Town the abundant Emoluments which his removal had taken from them. But this, reckoning himelf jutly incent, he reolvedly denied; his denial very much perplext both the People and their leaders, and to warrant themelves from the micheifs which they aw were likely to fall upon their heads they et new Engines on work and made new experiments. Florimen on the other ide armed, both againt them, and thoe of the other Religion, and againt both obtained very important victories; All things went to his advantage. Which Orates eeing, and that after whatoever manner he teered his deigns they ailed not with an untoward wind, he demanded an aemby of the general Counel of the Kingdome to the end, as he aid, of re-etablih •• d peace and replacing
the King's Subjects in a perfect Obedience. The King having granted what he demanded, and opened that great Court with a peech, of which the Eloquence and Conduct made him admired for one of the wiet and mot excellent heads that wore a Crown, he, who had braved his authority confidently, preented himelf before him, and he received him with a gratious apect, but not long after by the advie of his Counel dipatcht him out of the World. Upon notice of which Execution the People of Paquin broke out into extremeties which trampled all their allegiance under foot, and in revenge of it Lucimon raied them that were exaperated in plain rebellion, and after their example everal of their chief Towns of China, and having gained a formidable trength advanced towards Florimen with a confidence of making him his Prioner. But upon intiligence of his enterprize Polianis reconciled himelf with the King, employed his Arms in his uccor and forc't the Enemy to fly. In this occaion was Alcidor engaged on the ide of Lucimon and performed all the parts of a Man of courage but was contrained to give place to Equity and Force.

A little after having notice that his friend
Tyrenas was taken Prioner and kept at Chinanfu he contrived and effected the conveiyance of a Letter to him, wherein he aured him that he would, if poible, uddenly procure his liberty, either by Money, or Exchange, or ome other means; and what he promied he faithfully endeavored by Offers of tearmes, but altogether unprofitably.

He therefore wove a project of urprizing the place, which he communicated to Liantus, and which he highly approving they caued a ilent number of Souldiers to be habited like villagers, but armed under their habits, and ent them with intructions under hew of going to Market to eize one of the gates, but before thy could eize it they were dicovered and the body of the guard alarrumed. They, notwithtanding that, after a hot aault and vigorous reitance made themelves Maters of it. At the noie which they made Alcidor powred in with the Men which he had in readines for the purpoe, and after him Liantus with a greater force, and having taken the firt Body of the Guard and all without, eized a Canon that was pointed againt them, and pointed it againt the Town. Amazed with which, and looking upon themelves as unable to reit, thoe of the Garrion
received the Laws of the Conqueror. I need not repreent to you the pleaure of
• y renas to find himelf at liberty and the acknowledgments that he made to the Authors of it; they are eaie enough to be immagined.

In this part of the relation Dorame, could not forbear interrupting her Uncle and telling him that all the actions of Alcidor had o much Beauty in them that he let none of them pas without giving them acclamations; but this lat of all the ret, conidering epecially, added he, that uch men who will hazard their lives for them whom they pretend to love, are very rare in this age, in which falhood and diimulation raign far more powerfully than either Fidelity or freenes. It is uual with Alcidor, Coin returned Roliman to her, to perform that which is not uual with others, and there are everal paages of his tory, yet behind by which you will ee he hath an unquetionable title to more than common Encomiaticks and that upon the core not of one only but of many vertues.

A Few days after the urpial of Chinanfu, went he on, Alcidor had information brought him that the Governour whom he and Liantus had placed in it, deigning to better his fortune by betraying his trut, was about
to dipoe it to the ervice of the King; with which he having acquainted Liantus, they only with two Men put themelves into the place, ecretly called together ome of the principal Perons of it, and by the Oratory that they ued moulded them into the form that they deired. That done they aembled the chief of the Governour's Party and with the Poniard at their throat made them promie to erve the League; they turned out the old Governor and ettled one of approved Integrity in his room, they took an Oath of Fidelity of all the People, and made the Garrion mot firmly theirs.

No ooner had they with a great deal of honour accompliht this, which they had with enough of danger enterprized, but Lucimon informed of Florimens advance towards Paquin conjured Alcidor with all peed to put himelf into it, to defend it. But with this part of his life, I am not throughly acquainted particularly not with the love, which they ay, he and the Princes Floria had at that time for one another. Hearing him ay o, I am very orry, aid Dorame to him, that you can relate nothing to us of that buines with which I have been more than once entertained, but
o confuedly that I undertand lit •
<>
and which I aure my elf is none of the meanet imbellihments of that life that you are recounting. The occurencies of it are indeed very divertiing, aid Vindorix, and uch that one cannot well hear without having one's pirit made a kind of a Prioner to them. You have then a knowledg of them, aid Dorame to him. I have a great deal of reaon to blame my Memory, reumed Rolimon, for not re-calling that my Nephew was during all the Siege hut up in Paquin with Alcidor; o that there is no body who o well as he can preerve his tory from having one of his chiefet ornaments retrencht. I mut acknowledge, reparted Vindorix, I not only was a witnes of the Atchievements of War which Alcidor performed in that Siege, but I was alo no tranger to the intrickes of love which pat then between him and the Princes Floria. I was for that time his Companion in Arms, and he made few enterpries upon our Enemyes in which I was not his aitant. One deigne had engaged us to the League, and reckoning to act vigorouly for our concience and glory, we upon all occaions put our elvs upon dangers for a party which we have ince found
unjut and too late abandoned. But, not to wat time in that which is nothing to our preent purpoe, I hall give you all the account that I can of that which you deire to know.

As Vindorix was opening his mouth to begin what he had to ay, word was brought to Dorame that there were two Gentlemen alighted who deired to pay her their repects. Having ent back him who brought the word to conduct them in, and riing up to go and receive them, he aw enter her Chamber two near Kinmen of Cloriates who a little before would have Duelled Cartagenes as his rival in her love. Rolimon, Orlian and Vindorix, being well acquainted with them, quickly learnt what it was that had brought them thither. Which being to olicite Dorame to accept their kinman for her Husband, Rolimon made uch a rehearal to them of the refual which he had given him and his companions uing for Cartagenes, that they lookt upon it as unreaonable for them to imagine that they could obtain of her for their friend what her Uncle and Couins could not for theirs. They were made yet farther to depair of prevailing with her by Vindorix auring them that there had pat mutual profeions of kindnes
between her and Alcidor. In the lat place Dorame herelf deprived them of all hope, peaking to them of Alcidor as of one whom he had reaon to love, and whom therefore he really did love above all thoe who had made uite to her. Unable therefore to diapprove the choice that he had made and unwilling to travel their pirits to make Marble enible, they upereded from their negotiation and pat to congratulate to her the affections of him, of whoe value they avowed they had ufficient cogniance. In uch dicoures they held one another till Supper time; when Dorame contrary to the intentions which Floris and Lucidas had of going away that night engaged them to it down at Table with her. After upper going to pend what remained of the day in the Garden they fell preently upon their former ubjects, Cartagenes, Cloriates and Alcidor, and all agreed to give the lat a higher form in their Elogies than to either of the former, but that Cartagenes was to be et above Cloriates, or Cl • riates above Cartagenes would by no means be yielded by Floris and Lucidas on the one ide, or by Rolimon, Melian and Vindorix on the other. The contet growing warm, to bring them to an
accord and not favour the one in diadvantage of the other, Dorame pat judgement that they were both Men of Honor, and o equal in all quallities requiite to perons of their conditions that there were no praies due to the o • e which were not alo deerved by the other. This determination finihing the difference and the hadows beginning to cover the Earth they retired all into the Houe and quickly after every one to his Lodging.
div.trailer: The End of the Firt Book.

div.head: The Second Book.
div.p:
NOT a wink of leep could Dorame get all Night, Diquieted with the Viion which he had of a hadow every moment, preenting it elf to her; the more he conidered of which the more he imagined Alcidor dead, and the more this indignation prevailed upon her, the more increaed her inquietudes. Her ighes reaching the ears of Oriana and Milinda, her women, they roe, lighted Candles, inquired into her new trouble, and finding what ill impreion he had concieved, endeavored all that they were able to remove it. But it had taken too deep root to be on a udden pulled up; only their remontrances and the light of the Candles together in ome meaure leened the diturbance that it gave
her. Perceiving which, though he remanded them to their Beds, they would not be over-ruled to leave her till it was day and that he had in a good part laid aide her black fancy. The day advancing and he keeping her Bed to redeem the repoe of which the dipleaures of the night had robbed her, it was not long before a kind leep lockt up her enes and cares together. Which lating ome hours and then leaving her very well refreht, he was told as oon as he was throughly awake that Rollmon; Vindorix and the others having heard of her ill ret waited to know when they might with her convenience viit her. She thereupon ending them word that he was ready to bid their company welcome, they came all into her Chamber; where after they had heard from her own mouth what diturbance he had had, they jointly made it their buines to take her from all melancholick immaginations.

While they were thus employed there was brought into the Chamber Limonides who applying himelf to Dorame, I come, Madam, aid he to her, to bring you the
• idings of my Maters fate, whom Alcidor hath ent to his Grave. Alcidor hath killed Cartagenes, cryed Dorame: See the
truth of the Viion which hath o much tormented me. Here is a Letter, Madam, proceeded he, preenting one to her, which will aure you of what I have told you. Having taken and opened it he read in it thee words.

div.head: Cartagenes to Dorame.
div.p: I Have reckoned it more jut to try the honorable way of a combate with Alcidor than to withdraw cowardly from your ervice, and hamefully leave him the Glory of o fair a prize, I have been the aggreor in the quarrell and for my reward have received two wounds which deprive me of my blood and life together. My ervant will entertain you with the accident, the litle trength that I have left permitting me to tell you no more but that I dye your ervant and that Alcidor merits you far better than either Cloriates or Cartagenes.

Dorame was deeply truck with the mifortune and witneed by plenty of tears the lively ene which he had of it, together with the good eteem in which he had the unhappy lover. Oh the trange effects of Love, cryed Rolimon! Cartagenes ingaged
us to eek Dorame in Marriage for him, and in his oul thought of dying. Pardon me, Sir, aid Limonides to him, my Mater thought of nothing les than fighting when he gave you the pains of comming hither, he had at that time nothing in his mind but his Love; but there afterwards evened other things which begot in him an intention of fighting, that o he might confer and vindicate his honour. But whence, Limonides, aid Dorame, prung his quarrell with Alcidor? That you hould know it, Madam, replied Limonides, was part of his will before he dyed, of which he appointed me his Executor. Intantly after that my Lords who are here, Your Uncle and Couins were gone from his Houe, came in Almidon to him, and before me told him o many things to provoke him, that unles he had been altogether tupid or a coward he would by no means have remained without an angry reentment. Among other things he told him, that Alcidor having with little paines acquired your favour o as to be declared your ervant and owned by you for uch, had to your elf in the preence of many perons of quallity poken o diadvantageouly and contemptuoly of him that
he could not believe himelf his friend, did he not give him notice of it, and farther wirh all his power ait him to recover atisfaction of the injury. Cartagenes having with impatience enough heard what he aid, If you did not aert it, Alcidor aid he, I hould have a great deal of difficulty to believe that Alcidor who is eteemed one of the mot generous of men would dicoure of me to her whom I adore; or indeed to any Body otherwie than he in equity and Candor ought. Hath he beides ever known me tamely pocket up an affront that he hould take the confidence to give me o cruel a one? But I have a way to arret his inolency, and if there be nothing beides the Beauty of Dorame, that is enough to make me Valiant, if not invincible. At thee words Almidon aying that it belonged to him to erve him in revenge of the injury who had informed him of it, Cartagenes drew him aide and for ome time held a dicoure with him, of which I confes I had more than ordinary apprehenions. I knew Almidon to be a turbulent and unlucky intermedler, I knew alo that he had a deign of drawing my Mater to the earch of his Couin Lidia; I therefore eaily believed that he had upon that account brewed this quarrel for him.
Almidon gone, Cartagenes pat the ret of the day in Melancholy. At night when he was going to Bed remembring that I had heard the greatet part of what Almidon and he had aid to one another, could you have ever thought, aid he to me, that Alcidor would have thus abued me? I cannot be induced, Sir, returned I to him, to give any credit to what hath been told you, and I wih for your quiet you would not at all regard it. To this he replied nothing but bid me put him to bed, which I did and gave him the good-night. Next morning at point of day he called me to dres him, which done, he took hore (and I with him) to go to ee one of his friends. By the way (I know not what ill fortune would have it o) he about the middle of the day took a path which he was never, that I know of, wont to follow. Having followed it ome Miles he happened to meet Alcidor, whom accoting with a bold roughnes, he angrily enough demanded of him the reaon why he had poken o unhandomly of him to Dorame, To that, you hould learn to know me better, replied Alcidor, than to believe that I am of a humor to offend any Peron without reaon; and the injury that you
• o me in taking up that ill opinion of me is
greater than that which it eems you take for granted I have done you. But beides this, the Lovely Dorame deerves that we hould make one thrut with our Swords, as I ee you have a mind we hould; and I take mine in my hand, continued he, to let you know that I will have the glory of erving her alone, engaged both by what he had aid himelf, and by Alcidors words and action my Mater drew together with him, but wholly to his misfortune. For though he was well mounted and (as is enough known) very tout, he quickly recieved two wounds, one of which being in his belly gave him only leaure to get to a little houe hard by where they fought, to write the Letter that I have brought you, and jut as he expired to command me to give you, together with that, an account of his diater. But I mut not forget, added Limonides, the generounes of Alcidor, who, when he aw his adverary tumble to the ground at the econd thrut that he gave him, jumpt from his Hore to his uccor. Which he who was fallen eeing, and getting up of himelf, trouble not your elf, brave Alcidor, aid he, to help me; I am mortally wounded, and though with your Sword Almidon is the caue of it. That
bae man hall dye, returned Aclidor to him, or I will my elf perih by that kind of people who are skilful to make more quarrels than they are able to appeae. Believe me, I never pake a word of you that could give you a digut. I am too certain of your innocence, replied Cartagenes to him, to make any further quetion of it, and let you plainly ee the baenes of Almidon, Limonides hall give you an account of the dicoure which he yeterday held to me, in the mean time that we binde up my wounds and I recover trength to carry me to ome place where I may dye more conveniently than here. Accordingly while Alcidor erved my Mater for Chyrurgion, I erved Alcidor for intilligencer. Which done we had only time to conveigh my Mater to the nearet comodious place that we could find, and there as oon as he had written to you he dyed. An adventure Sir, aid Vindorix to Floris, which challenges the tribute of a weeping eye, and I fear, if ill Fortune be not by ome means of prevention made to change her coure, the ame may arrive to Cloriates. To prevent that, returned Floris to him, we will make hat to him and perwade him to it down form his
hopeles uite and leave the excellent Dorame, to her Gallant Alcidor, Cartagenes himelf, when he was dying, voting him the mot worthy to poes her.

Dorame was going to peak, when a Lacquey of Alcidors was brought into the Chamber and hindred her, preenting her a Letter which he firt read privately to herelf and then aloud to the company in thee words.

div.head: Alcidor to Dorame.
div.p:
I had no deign when I took leave of you but to accord a difference between two of my Friends; but I have experimented that my ill fortune detined me to omithing ele. Yeterday I by chance met with Cartagenes, who aboarded me with o ill a dicoure, that my honour obliged me to make him little ele of anwer but that of my Sword in my hand. We fought, and though he had more valour than I, he had wore luck, it was my luck to make him fall. I reckon my fault very great that I have drawn my Sword, and that mortally, againt one who offered ervice to you, and whom you jutly eteemed. But by that goodnes that is proper to you, I beeech you to pardon me, and I hope you will, conidering among other things that
without your anger I am ufficiently puniht for what I have done in that I must for a while deprive my elf of the happynes of eeing you, not thinking • t fit for the preent to make you ee him who hath killed Cartagenes.

Dorame was troubled as much at this Letter as for the death of Cartagenes believing that Alcidor would leave of his pretenions of Love to her, out of apprehenion of many dangers which he might poibly incurre in proecuting them. Vindorix knowing what pinched her, acquainted as you are with the entiments of Alcidor, aid he to her, by the ill judgement which I ee you make of him, you unufferably wrong both his courage and his affection. He is none of thoe whoe ouls tart back at the noie of leaves, or whoe loves are unhinged by their more predominant fears. He is indeed moved when he is prickt in honour and bound to eek atisfaction, but it is not that he dreads a new quarrel or a new combate that he tells you he hall be without eeing you; it is only that he may not appear before you with his hand dy'd, and reeking with the bloud of Cartagenes. Write to him to come to you, and you will oon ee that he knows how to obey you. If he
tayes not but till he is ent for returned Dorame, I hall quickly ee him here, for I hall quickly give him the ummons of a letter. It is indeed, Couzen, aid Roliman to her, no more than what is handom on your part, and deerved on his, and you will (as far as can be een) derive from it nothing but what is good. I am altogether of that mind, added Melian to her, and you will oone be convinced that nothing can defer him from preenting himelf to you when he knows you deire it. Dorame relihing well the reaons of her Kinmen and the inforcements of them which were made by Floris and Lucidas, preently took her Pen and drew thee lines.

div.head: Dorame to Aleidor.
div.p:
I Write not to you to blame you for what you have done, I am enible of the jut occaion which you had of erving your elf with your bet forces and addres to preerve your life against thoe who wo • ld have raviht it from you: It is only to oblige you to give me your company as oon as you can, your action not being uch that it hould be puniht with light or any thing of hame or horror. Cartagenes himelf hath left ufficient tetimonies to jutifie
you, and you will believe that I have recieved them, and approved them, when you ee that the bearer of this Letter is Limonides who hath order to eek you through all the World.

Limonides very gladly taking the charge of carrying this Letter, as that which he aid would be a great contentment to him amidt the dipleaures which he had for his Maters death, and being gone away with it, Dorame who had her mind no more dieaed with the frightful fanies of the night, roe from her bed, and at down with her company to dinner. Rien from Table they went into the Gallery and there ometimes walking, ometimes itting, pent two or three hours in dicouring about Alcidor and Cartagenes, about the various traveres and effects of Love, and at lat about Cloriates; reviving their apprehenions concerning him, that he might plit himelf againt the ame Rock that Cartagenes had. After which Floris and Lucidas conidering that it was time he was advied rather to be patient in miing than obtinate in attempting that which it was impoible for him ever to obtain, and which to eek to obtain, would in probability be fatall to his life, and alo that they had no more of day
left than they hould need to conveigh them whither they were to go, they took congey of Dorame and her relations and went away. Their backs being turned, Dorame took her Uncle and Couins into a private Chamber, and having made them it down and eated her elf, You know, Couin, aid he, directing her peech to Vindorix, that the arrival of Floris and Lucidas hindred you yeterday from carrying on the tory of Alcidor in that part of it where without your help it will remain defective, and that other impediments alo have fallen in to day: But now we are at leaure to enjoy this divertiement; I intreate you therefore to favour us with it. I am ready, Madame, replyed Vindorix, to obey you, and after a little paue began thus.

Alcidor having receaved the deires of Lucimon and Liantus to put himelf into Paquin, the friendhip which he and I had contracted, uffered us not to part, and, though I was alltogether unworthy of that repect, he would not enter the citty without my company. The day of our entrance the five hundred hore which he brought with him, and his preence together raying and fortifying the fallen courages of thoe whom the concience of their crimes had filld with the
apprehenions of punihment, we were wellcomed with o much honour, he for his part that Lucimon and Liantus could not have receaved more, and I, for my part, that I never the like. The Magitrates and Grandees giving him this reception in the palace of Floria, whom her Uncle Lucimon had left in Paquin after the death of her Father Orates, the remarkes which he hewed of kindenee toward him were uch, that together with me, many others that were there tooke notice that he was never accutomed to afford the like to any. He againe applyed himelfe to her in uch a fahion, that the Mues eemed to it upon his lippes and the Graces upon all his parts: and not content by that meanes to draw her repects to himelfe he pake to her of me o much to my advantage that he pent complements upon me which I very well knew I had nothing that encouraged me to owne as my due, and with which I found myelfe more put to a tand than ever in my life beides.

The Governour and other Officers having intruted us with the cheife commands of the Towne, wee without any upinenee ued them to the utmot of our power in giving neceary orders for defending it, and that late enough; for within foure dayes
after the paages were all eized by the King, the out workes attaqued and the eige formed. We lay not till in this occaion, Alcidor had more gallantry and his Troopes more ambition of fighting, we made a alley, and in that firt eay of our armes brought backe advantages over our beeigers which caued fires of joy to be lighted through all the City. Not atisfied with the triumph unles he aw him who had procured it, Floria ent for Alcidor to come to her, and it was then that going along with him to her I percieved by her eyes, words and whole carriage not onely that his valour kept her from haking under the feares which he had of falling into the hands of her fathers enemies but alo that his peron was a great deal more than indifferent to her. When wee were going from her, you have not onely Paquin to preerve, Alcidor, aid he to him, you have alo an unfortunate princee under your guard, take heed therefore how you hazard your life ince it is my upport. In reply to this, I therefore make Eteem of Paquin, Madam, aid Alcidor, becaue it holds o rich a treaure as the princee Floria. Knowing indeed whence and what you are I hould goe againt my Concience, hould I not et an higher value upon you
than upon what I hold dearet to me in the world. Whatoever coniderations therefore I can have, the ambition which I have of erving you will be ure to urmount them all, & it will I hope not onely upply me with boldnes of heart but with prudence alo to manage it. This reply mooving o violently her inmot veines, that there roe a udden crimon from them and pred it elfe over her face; he left us with out aying any more but that he would have us ee her often. And in this wee obeyed her command; for whatoever imployments we had to remedy the diturbances which the enemy procuredus, we forbore not to viit her twice every day, and after a while whither he deir'd him o to doe or that it came of his owne motion Alcidor tooke up a cutome of going frequently to her without me. But on the other ide whatoever intreaties he ued to him, and he ued, beides that mentioned before, very many and earnet ones not to throw himelfe into danger, he forbore not frequently to ingage himelfe in the midt of the enemy, doing things which made every body have him in their mouths for a kinde of miracle.

If we were active, our beeigers were not idle, making atempts which for ome time
kept us day and night at worke. From which having one afternoone a little releae I made ue of it to goe viit Alcidor: but coming to his lodging. I found that he was gone to doe the ame to Floria. I neverthelee went into his chamber, where finding a booke upon his table I opened it, and turning over the firt leafe of it I aw a letter drop, which, out of a curioity to know more of my friends particularities than I believed he had imparted to me, taking up and unfolding I read in it thee words.

div.head: Floria to Alcidor.
div.p: IF you have but a little conideration of the paine that I endure becaue I ee you not o often as I wih, I perwade my elve you will come to ee me aoone as you have read this letter wherein I deire it. You too well know your owne merit and the influence which it hath upon me to make any quetion of the advantage which I derive from your convere. Make hat therefore to me and involve not your elfe o much in the troubles of war as not by intermiion to come and weeten thoe of Floria.

The fortune which I aw by this letter was arrived to Alcidor urprized me with a gut that was very acceptable to me, but not
without an allay when I coniderd that he might not draw all that atisfaction from the affections of o high a peron which he might from thoe of a meaner. The letter for feare that if I left it, where I found it, it might bee found by ome other as it had been by me, or ele might bee wholly lot I carried with me to my lodgings; where aoone as I was entred Alcidor coming to eek me, all his dicoure to me was of Floria and particularly of the viit which he came from making to her, and in his dicoures he could not with all his arts o well diemble but that he often changed colour, and dicovered by many tetimonyes that another God beides Mars had made him his votary; but yet he tooke not any notice to me of the princee's writing to him, nor did I therefore to him that I knew any thing of it. I on the contrary indutriouly abtained from peaking anything of her to him at all, much more of her merite. But the more I hunned that theam, the more he pret it. To ee therefore whither his paion would carry him I made it my buiines to dient from what he aid, which he tooke o ill, that to heare him chide me would have dipoed one to judge that I had committed ome groe enormity.

Here Dorame interpoing, it is not a little
dipleaure, aid he, which a Lover receaves when one aproves not the prayes which he betowes upon her whom he loves. I told you what deigne I had in doing o, reumed Vindorix and therefore I was not at all tirred with what Alcidor, aid to me, and I afterwards changing my tile pake o much good of the Princes that he quickly changed his alo and gave me better words than he ever before had done. I then againe introduced another ubject, which was that of warre, but it was eay for me to perceave that thoe words of Canon, powder musket, pike, ounded not o well in his eares as thoe of Love, of Floria, and of her graces.

After we had thus entertained our elves a while at my chamber he carried me to his, When a little after we were entered taking up the booke in which I had found the letter, he turned over the leaves, ran into his cloet, left no place unearched, no ervant unquetioned for what he mit. I asking him what it was that he inquired for, he told me that it was a paper of great importance to him. Farther I pret him, not for feare of being upected of taking away that of which the abence put him into o great pain; But when I aw him by degrees calme himelfe and his pirit grow to ome tillnes, I ecretly o
that he not at all perceaved me, put the letter under the tapetry of his table where he had not yet earched, and then as if by chance threw downe one of the ides of the tapetry o that it let the letter dropp. Having with joy natched it up, ee that, ai • he to me, in which lies comprehended all my etate of happinee. What o important treanre can it conceale, returned • to him, that hould make you peake o highly of it? Nor Riches nor honours, Vindorix, aid he againe, doe at all content us if our friends are ignorant that we poes them. Was I monarch of the world, I hould not be atitied if Vindorix had not knowledge of my cepter. I asking him than if omething new had happened to him which lay hid from me. Reade this letter, my deare companion, aid he to me and you will know what a liberall benefactres Fortune hath beene to me with which words, he putting it into my hand, I tooke it and after ome ceremony that I ued to it read aloud what I had more than once read to my elfe.

At thee words, indutrious cheater that you are aid Dorame to Vindorix, had Alcidor knowne your fraudulent ubtleties your cloe correpondencies would have beene in danger to have been turned into an irreconcileable
dicord. Why returned Vindorix to her, did I doe any thing in this which can be accounted a breach of freindhip or which the bet freind in the world would not have done? For all my talking, aid Dorame to him againe, I really blame you not at all; but I pray goe on with • our relation. To goe on with it, reumed Vindorix, Alcidor after I had read the letter told me that he had things to recount to me which I could not heav without urprize, and preently ued this dicoure to me.

It is a trange power that of love, which we in vain inforce our elves to reit. Who would have ever thought that I who perpetually made a mocke of love, hould come to be hut up in this beeiged City to be made ubject to that which I made a mocke of? I thought of vanquihing, and I am vanquiht; I aimed at triumphing over brigades of Hotile men, and I am overcome by a maide a friend. You, divine Floria, have inlaved me to your lawes, but by a force the weetet in the world as well as the mot compulive. You cannot but remember, my Vindorix, the day, the houre, the moment that we had firt the blie of wayting upon her, ay truly, have you ever met with a face more beautifull, a proportion more
exact, a pirit more fine, a port more gracefull? I know not how he appeared to your eyes, but in mine he had altogether as much beauty and Majety (be it poken without injury to her virtue) as ever the poets attributed to the Mitree of the God of warre. Interpoing here, having then and ince, aid I, with a <…> coniderd the qualityes wherwith heaven hath furniht her, I cannot ay that he hath parallel. This is, rejoined Alcidor, to judge of things as they deerve, and ince to you I neither ought to diemble nor will, I acknowledge that from the firt moment wherein I aw this unparalleld woman, I conceaved a paion for her; all the time that we were then with her, I thought of nothing but of her, I carce coniderd that I was in Paquin to defend it and had my elfe alo to take care of. When we were parted I et my elfe eriouly to tudy both of her perfection, and my owne change which prang from them, and I trongly endeavoured to beate out the power which I found had urprized my heart, but I was forced to leave my elfe to be vanquiht by that which I plainely aw I was not able to fight with.

The Princes you know, added he, from the good ucces which we had of our words
when our beeigers firt approached the Citty, drawing an occaion of ending for u •
to give us the congratulations which he thought fit, it was from that time that I knew that he tooke a more than a common if not a very affectionate interet in me.
