One mut indeed have been blinde, interrupted I him, or ele wholly deprived of judgment not to draw that concluion from all her deport towards you, particularly what other interpretation than that could be made of thoe words which he ued to you at parting, you have not onely Paquin to preerve but alo an unhappy Princes to guard; take heed therefore how you hazard your life leat by looing that you doe injury to mine by depoiling it of its upport.

After this, went he on, I many times viited her without your knowledge, and as many times received tetimonies of her kinde inclinations towards me. One time among the ret he was pleaed in plaine tearmes to tell me that my peron and humor were very agreeable to her, and that he made more account of me than of all men in the world together; and I let not the opportunity lip by without improoving it, but tooke courage from what he aid to declare to her in the mot repectfull phrae
that I could invent, that I had dedicated me elfe entirely to her as to the mot abolute peice of divinity among mortalls. In anwer to which, you doe not at all dioblige me, Alcidor, aid he, in letting me know that you have an affection for me: Love me as much as you are deare to me, and I aske no more to be the mot contented woman that lives. Impregnated with joy to heare her ay o, The Goodnes, Madam, replyed I to her, which you are pleaed to tetifie towards me fills me with an inebriating glory, bankrupts my gratitude, and leaves me nothing to doe in the world but by your premiion to be all my life in the quality of your lave, paying as much as I can of what I owe to your birth merite and bounty. Her Gentlewoman coming in, as I aid o, I held my tongue and laid a retraint upon my carriage; eeing which, have no reerve, Alcidor, aid he to me, becaue of Leonora, for he knowes all my ecrecies; from the moment that I loved your vertue, I made her acquainted with it, and he intead of diuading me from it, repreented many things to me on your ide, which erved to make me more highly eteeme you. Hearing this, I mut be tupified, Madame, returned I to her, not to thinke that I have an obligation
to her which is not eaily dicharged, and I hould deerve nothing but ill offices from her intead of good ones, hould I not eek occaion of thanking her. With wich words pulling a diamond from my finger I intreated her to wear it as pledge that I was enible of the favours which he had done me, and he by the princee's command accepted it. After this, Love, intead of abaing my courage raied it, and beleiving it my duty to performe omething anwerable to the elevation of my affections and to the honour that the princes deigned me, I often with you, Vindorix, you know, aught occaions of remarkable actions, and one day epecially having no more eyes than love that conducted me, I blindely precipitated myelfe into dangers, out of which had not you drawne me, I cannot ee but that I had in all probability periht. Returning victorious to the City, the paines which we had taken in the fight requiring that we hould a little ret our elves, we as you may remember left one another to go to our everal lodgings. Come to mine, it was not many moments that I had hut my elfe into my cloet and laid me downe upon my couch, not o much to repoe my elfe as to thinke of Floria, when one of her pages brought me this letter from her.

div.head: Floria to Alcidor.
div.p: I Have heard uch great things of the enterprie that you come from making upon our enemyes, and of the ucces that you have gained over them, that the affecton which I bear you carries me to rejoyce at them. But there is nevertheles that which troubles me extremely, it is a continuall feare that you hould fall a victime on the feild of battell, or at leat receive ome horrid wound. What ill offices does your valour render me? Retraine, I conjure you, this heate of fighting, ret your elfe from your labours, and end me word how you doe, and if your health is in that condition that I wih it, come to ee me to morrow morning.
In anwer to thee lines I drew and ent thee that follow.

div.head: Alcidor to the Princes Floria.
div.p:
YOu make me bluh with the Eulogies that you give me and with the care that you take of me. I am altogether undeerving of them: but the imployment in which I am, uffers me not to bee les active than I am, and if I have made ally without your command, it is becaue the good of the publicke required it. Excue
the affection that I beare it, ince it does not in the leat diminih that which I have for the mot deerving Princes that the un beholds. For my health I never felt myelfe better, and hall not faile to waite upon you at the time that you appoint to render you an account of my actions.

Going the next morning and urprizing her in bed with Leonora entertaining her, after he had made me take a eate by her bedside and given me her hand, which without conidering that it was too much for me to attempt, I kit when I tooke it, I at her command gave her a relation of the alley which we the day before had made. While we were talking about which, her hands playing with my locks, her boome by tealth dicovered it elfe with beauties which I greedily fed upon with my eyes, but of which I durt not owne the relih which I had in my mind. The repect indeed which I had for her put a trict bridle upon all my carriage towards her: which he oberving, as if on purpoe to make me ue more familiarity with her, he ued more than formerly with me. I tooke the overture and imprinted an hundred hot kies on her hand; which he allowing I ventured the ame to her face and met with
no repule. Our carees thus riing by degrees but no higher than was fitting, they were ready to melt away my oule with delight, when a top was put to them by the coming in of the Governor of the Town. Hee held dicoures to her about her Uncle Lucimon, and they were of uch concernement as required her to write to him. Which being done, and the Governor gone, he told me he would rie. I withdrew therefore into the antichamber, where meeting with her Gentleman, I, while he was dreing, entertained myelfe with him, and learnt a great many things of him; particularly whatoever craft he ued to hide it, I oberved that he had a deigne of dicovering whether or no the Princes loved me. To make me dicloe he told me that never had he eteemed any man o much as me, and that he had allwayes my name and actions in her mouth. To this I anwerd, that it was proper to thoe that were great to peake well of thoe that were mean, to the end to make their own vertue hine more clearely, and to hew by commending thoe that have little merite that they know how to give true and jut prayes to them who deerve them, and that if he at all coniderd me I well knew it was
only becaue he was o good as to thinke that I might poibly bee helpfull to the defence of the City. Placidas not finding my dicoure uitable to his expectation, turned his tongue to other ubjects; but I inenibly grew upon him and at lat brought him to advertie me that Lucimon had by a letter which he had lately written to him, given him charge watchfully to oberve all the actions of his neice, and withall to hew me the letter; reading which I aw that the viits which I made to Floria were knowne to that prince and upected by him. Having thus learnt of him what it was, very conducible to my advantage to know, I with the bet arguments that I could ue peruaded him to be faithfull to his princes and to informe her of whatoever he hould know was practied to her detriment: particularly I advied him to give her notice preently of that which her Uncle had wrote to him, but without ignifying to her that I knew any thing of it, adding that I hould o well manage the tenure of my cariage for the future that Lucimon hould finde nothing in it to cenure.

According to my advie as oone as Placidas knew that he might enter the princee's Chamber he went to her and gave her the
ame intelligence that he had given me. Upon which ending him immediately for me, carce was I within her Chamber dore but he told me before him what he had told her, not without dicovering an extreame dicompoure, and aying all that could bee aid againt a man, againt Lucimon. After he had by words and teares diharged ome of her vexation, I, with the repect that was due to her and with the bet motives that I could thinke of, intreated her not to be troubled at the buines, adjoining that rather than he hould by occaion of me receive any thing of dipleaure, if my being deprived of her ight would remedye it, though it would be a greater punihment to me than I knew how to live under, I would without diputing it banih my elfe from her preence. Hearing me ay o, I am o far, Alcidor, reparted he to me, from having a minde that you hould abent yourelfe from me becaue of Lucimon, that I would have you doe me the kindnes of viiting me oftener then heretofore, that being o ill treated by an uncle I may amidt my unhappinee have the conolation of being uccoured by one who hath no tie upon him to doe it. Could it not uffice him to have hut me up in this mierable City
which two potent Princes have for the object of their indignation, and which could not keep it elfe from falling under their power, if your valour and conduct forbad it not, without going about to double my imprionment by retraining me from eeing thoe who can give my pirit ome relaxation? what trange Barbarounes is this and how little ued by an Uncle to a neice? Does he feare that I have a minde to take from him the pretenions which he makes to the kingdom and to place the crowne upon Alcidor's head, that he would not have him come neare me? He is indeed abundantly worthy of a cepter, but both his intentions and mine are juter and more moderate than to apire to any uch thing, was it, as it is not, in our power to attaine it. No, No Alcidor, added he to me, you mut not forake me, it would be too much cruelty in you to abandon a Princes that breathes not, but by your aitance, and expects not her deliverance but by your meanes. In repone to this I aid all to her that love and duty could ugget to me, to demontrate to her my zeale of living and dying for her. All which, both what he aid and I, Placidas hearing, and not being able to hear without being certaine that there was a more than
ordinary kindenes between us, he humbly offered her to erve her to the utmot of his capacity againt her Uncle; and being thereupon commanded by her to eteem me as one to whom he had great obligations, he intreated me to beleive that I was Mater of his heart and that he would never have any other inclinations than to doe me all the good offices that he could. After which he and Leonora leaving us together, we conferred a while about Lucimon, thence we proceeded to tetifie our affections to one another, I with the bet language that I could put together, and he with as many favours as her vertue and modety would allow her to betow upon me. She withall enjoined me not to peak a yllable of our correpondencies to any body; no, not to Vindorix, aid he, for he is too much affected with glory to like that you hould ingage your elfe in love at a time o proper for Armes. This is the ole reaon why I have till now concealed from you my love and the good fortune that I have had in it; You therefore ought not to take it ill from me, epecially conidering that Floria hath no ooner given me liberty of acquainting you with the ecret (for it was but this afternoone that he gave it me) but I have made
ue of it to let you ee that I have nothing of concerne which I am willing to reerve from your knowledge. To this I anwered that I lookt upon the injunction which the Princes had laid upon him, not as an effect of her ill will to me, but as a fruite of her prudence which obliged her to ditrut all the world in an affaire of o much conequence, that I hould have thought it very ill done of him if he had not obeyed it, and that I had a better ene of the favour that he had done me in giving him leave to impart o much to me as he now had done, than ever to imploy it otherwie than to both their advantages.

I having aid o, ince that time, went he on, I have very often been with her without any body having cogniance of it but Placidas and Leonora, and I was never with her but he gave me demontrations of her affection towards me, which as they bred in me a rich delight, were enough alo to have begot in me a mot fond vaine-glory, if by a ober reflection upon my elfe I had not been throughly acquainted with my unworthines of them. That you may ee, how far I am in her eteeme, added he, tepping to a little boxe of pearl taking a paper out of it and bringing it to
me, read thee few lines. Doing as he deired me, I found they held uch ene as this.

Though poibly there bee few pretenions of marriage o exalted, which my birth would not authorize me to make, the worth which continually repreents it elfe to me in you hath o much of magneticke influence upon me that my heart cannot keep it elfe from being drawne and tied fat to you and that I cannot forbeare telling you o. And this you hall never faile of knowing, o long as you render your elfe capable of doing o. But make no ill judgment of my freenee, for my virtue is no otherwie intereted by my affection than it ought to be, and as it is mot true that I love you, o is it alo that I love you in uch a manner as chatity and agenes allow, and that I looke you hould continue in the tearmes of repect that are due to me.

When I had done reading thee words, not to detaine you any longer with this concerne, adjoined Alcidor, I am at preent mounted to the highet tep of happines that a vertuous love without marriage is able to bring me to, and, if I may ay o
without imputation of arrogance, I have reaon to thinke that I may be to morrow the husband of Floria, if I will. She every day indeed prees me to be o, and though I upon a manifold conideration beleive that I hall never have her for my wife I have promied to make her o as oon as the eige is raied, and in the meane time to prepare my elfe for it by gaining as large a tock of honour as I can.

He thus concluding his dicoure to me, I told him that he had certainly done very well in atisfying the princes with thoe aurances that he deired, and that I made no great quetion but the terme which he had taken for marrying her would produce uch a revolution of affaires as would et him at liberty to doe in that affaire according as he hould ee caue. Then, not thinking it fitting to counell a man whom his dicretion made him act well in every thing, I onely let him know how deeply I accounted my elfe in his debt, for communicating to me the particularities of his affections, and preently we parted.

Having uch within our walls as practied for Polianis and carried on conpiracies of moment enough to have quickly detroyed
us if we had not happily melt them out and provided againt them, we were eight dayes in remedying this deeae which done we made our beeigers ee that wee had not lay till but to take breath that we might fall upon them with the more life, cutting our way up to their trenches, putting them into a great diorder and bringing backe a great number of prioners.

There was againe nothing worth mentioning attempted on our ide till one day Alcidor without me, whither I was otherwie buied or that he had ome other reaon not to take me along with him, iued out of the Town accompanied onely with ten volunteers that put themelves under his conduct. They were preently et upon by twice as many and were at length contrained to give way to their trength and retire. But before Alcidor made his owne retreat, he by amuzing the enemy gave his party leaure to make theirs. Upon which occaion taying a little too long behind, after he had maintained fight as long as he was able, to put himelfe out of the danger that he was in, he leaped his hore over a great ditch; Thereupon one of thoe whom he had to deale with vainely enough u • braided him that he had the advantage of making him
fly. To him, the advantage is, returned Alcidor, that you are o many, were you a little fewer you hould quickly ee me come backe to you. It hall be your fault if you come not, aid the other againe, for I promie you, you hall have to doe with none but me: try the adventure and you hall ee I will attend you as it in honour becomes Liimax. Hearing him ay o, Alcidor was about to jumpe backe to him, but he at the intant perceived about halfe a core horemen galloping to intercept his way; he therefore et purs to his hore and retired.

Got into the Town he came and recounted to me what had befallen him: he told me withall that Liimax being the favourite of Florimen and of an applauded name, and there, therefore being a great meaure of glory to be gotten by a ingle combate with him, he reolved to demand it of him. The reaons which he alleadged for his reolution inducing me to approve it, after I had intreated him to let me be his econd but could not obtaine it of him, we concluded that it was neceary for him to have the conent of the Princes and of the Counell of warr in the buines; and we went firt to the Princes, to whom he declaring that his
honour put him upon a duell with Liimax, he before me could not forbear having her elfe extremely troubled at it, and endeavoured all that he was able to turne him from it. But when he aw he could not pervail with him, Goe then, aid he to him, and fight this Giant, and heaven reerve for you the victory. From her we went to the Governour, at whoe houe the cheif officers being convened, Alcidor propounded to them what he deired and without difficulty procured their leave to doe as he thought good. From them I waited upon him home; by the way whither, The King, aid he to me, beleives Liimax invincible, and o doe others alo; if therefore I overcome him I hall acquire a glory which will not quickly dye: but if my ill fortune on the other ide will have him triumph over me, this atisfaction I may pretend to, that I am vanquiht by one of the bravet Cavaleirs of our age. It is almot impoible that you hould not conquer him, replyed I to him, o much advantaged as you are. Was there indeed nothing but the favour of Floria that is enough to make you irreitable, and I make no doubt but the prayers which he ends up for you will be heared and draw down upon you the bleing of heaven.

We were in thee tearms when we came to his lodgings; where he making me tay and up with him, during upper I againe et upon him with the bet rhetorike that I had to peruade him to make me of his party, but all to no effect. Rien from table we went into his cloet, where he giving me a book to reade, I had not perued many lines, before he had drawn thee and came and hewed them me.

div.head: Alcidor to Liimax.
div.p: YOu may well remember what yeterday pat betweene us, and you live in a higher reputation than to beleive any thing meane of yourelfe. If therefore you can get leave of the King as I have done of thoe upon whom I depend, it hall lye upon you if I come not to day to ight you at the head of your army. You are a better man at armes than to refue to fight with Lance and Sword; with thee I hall waite upon you if I hall finde your reolution uch as I deire it. I hall expect it with impatience, yet am better acertained of your valour than to beleive that you will hun the occaion of making it appeare.

Having conidered thee words I aured him who askt my judgment of them that
the moderation and civility of them was uch as could not be betterd, and as his enemy could not but commend. Satisfied with which approbation he reolved to think of no other language but to end it the next morning as it was. I could carce leep all the night, I was o retles to ee again the day and Alcidor; going to him aoon as I could get up after it was light, I found him rien and upon the point of ending his chalenge. It was carried by a Herauld with ceremony enough, and it was receaved by Liimax with as much Candor, who after he had been with the King ent back this anwer.

div.head: Liimax to Alcidor.
div.p: I Honour your valour more than not to conent to the deign which it hath of trying mine. We will fight therefore to morrow at un rie in the preence of both armyes, ince you deire it, and I have my Kings permiion to doe it, and our armes hall be the the ame that you have precribed. Thinke to defend your elfe well, for I have a trong deire to attaque you well; the glory will remain with the conquerour.

The Herauld bringing backe this anwer, together with on aignement of the place
where the two champions hould act their parts and the two armyes tand pectators, not without an aurance from the King, that there hould on his ide be no act of hotility committed till all were returned to their former quarters, he having pledged the ame in our name to the King, Alcidor had apparent in his face the characters of a gallant exultancy of pirit; the cheifs applyed themelves to take care about the marching forth of the army the next morning, and the Princes had a hundred times in an hour day and night by turnes in her breat, what with her hopes, what with her feares. But he who gave her the occaion of thoe viciitudes, pending all his time with her, brought her before he left her to a more ettled temper, and at parting received of her together with her good wihes a very rich carf, imbroiderd with her name.

The next morning in a uperb array marched the army out of Paquin to the place appointed, where the other alo failed not of rendring it elfe, Floria eated her elfe in an eminent place where he might ee the combate and be able by her regards to animate Alcidor. All things in hort were ready, and preently appeared the two competitors of honour. Before they came
to their tations the King gave Liimax his word and repreented to him that he had an enemy who was both excellently skilfull ad valiant. The Princes wiht that he had had the liberty of doing ome uch thing for Alcidor, but he could doe no more than end him ecretly by Placidas a bracelet of her hair. After this, and that I had put myelf in the head of the cavalry of which Alcidor was commander, with reolution either to dye or vanquih in cae there hould be any treachery (though this as it afterwards appeared needed not, there being nothing attempted againt the publike faith) Liimax and Alcidor choe their judges, took their places and the trumpets ounding ran againt one another with a wiftnes like that of a furious wind. Their ucces was very different; for Alcidor receiving the lance of Liimax in the bow of his addle o that it flew in peices, he with his owne lance peirced his hores houlder and belly, with his word cut in pieces his bridle, and diarmed him. Having thus almot in a minute dipatched the fight, not without all the feilds and City ringing with the houts of our army and people that were upon the walls, he ent the word which he took from his adverary to the King
who had given it him, and preently both the armyes retired, theirs to their ordinary pots, and ours into the Towne. Never man of Alcidors condition received more honour in a day than he did in this, by the order of the magitrates bonfires for ome hours together lightened, and Canons thundred in all parts of the City; no peice of triumph was omitted that ues to accompany famous victories; the Grandees gave him complements, and all orts of people acclamations, which declared them mot pathetically tranported with what he had done, and the replyes which he made to them augmented their tranports with their elegancy and Generoity. But all the ret was cheap to the price of thoe congratulations which he received from the Princes; they were as expreive of joy in her elfe and of honour to him as her exuberant ingeny prompted with her vehement affection could dictate to her; and he in anwer to them attributed all his happines to the prayers which he had ent to heaven for him, and to the other favours that he had conferred upon him, and that with a rhetoricke, modety, gallantry and repectfullnes which gave her new occaions of extolling and careing him.

This action of Alcidor coming to the knowledge of Luimon and Liantus was very differently received by them. Lucimon fearing it would prevail with his neice to conider him yet more advantageouly than he did, vext him elfe at it with a mot diingenuous cancetous malice, and peaking of it upon all occaions mot detractingly himelfe, caued others alo to pread reports of it altogether contrary to truth: but it hon with a more triumphant plendor than to be o obcured. Liantus on the other ide was himelfe continually where ever he came dicouring of it as of that which he could not encomiaze enough, and et his friends on worke alo to proclaim to the world its grandeur. What is it more, aid he often, to have gained all than to have vanquiht Liimax the mot daringly active man of his party.

But while Alcidor had good ucces in the particular undertakings of his word, as alo in his loves (for he and Floria in depight of Lucimons malignant intentions continued to live in their accutomed intelligences. Placidas who had received his commands to detroy them (favouring them as much as he could), the general concernement of the eige went on very ill on our ide; the royall
forces continually increat by freh upplyes, ours conumed a pace by icknes and allyes, and we were at length brought to uch a pas, that what becaue we were for the mot part beaten, what to preerve our remaines wee durt not tir out of the incloure of our bullwarkes. Scarcity of victualls alo grew upon us o that the people who had before only groaned privately under their ufferings without daring to complain publickely, now mutinied for bread and rifled everall houes of the mot noted Burgees. To lay this dangerous diturbance the Governor and thoe others in power at whoe nodds the large but racall body of the multitude was wont to move, fed them with hopes of great things which Alcidor and I undertood not. Among other things they told them that if they would have but a little patience, they hould quickly ee themelves delivered from the eige and all their other mieries together, and that there was but a moment almot to wait for that fortunat event which would render them completely happy. Preently after when Alcidor and I thought of nothing but the meanes of reiting thoe that begirt us and dayly grew upon us, we at counell of war to our grand atonihment had
newes brought us that the King was killed with the tab of a knife. Struck with horrour at this blacke paricide, we had it redoubled at the excees of joy with which we aw firt the aembly of Officers reent it, then mot of the inhabitants of Paquin and trangers that defended it, reputing it a miracle which the powers above had wrought for their akes. But as well workt tempers are never friends to baenes, the Princes in our preence regretted this tragicke fall of the upreme father of her countrey with as erious tears as he had done that of her own father.

In equel of this mot proditorious aa
• inate Lucimon, who had alone as much pleaure in his oul at it as had all the whole rebellion together, not daring to tep the next way into the throne himelfe, though profoundly deigning to doe it in effect, gave the title of King to Prince Dolimbus who was prioner; and, Polianis drawing of his forces from the eige of Paquin to carry on expeditions neceary to his regall interets, thither he came, and conveighed away his neice thence, hutting up in prion Placidas, whom he upected of being a freind to her intimacies with Alcidor, and uffering only Leonora to continue
till in her ervice. Where he placed he •
Alcidor was not able to finde out; exaperated at which and at his ill uage of her upon his account, he had taken a evere revenge upon him for it, had he not been hindred by the high authority that guarded him: he was how oever about to forake his party when Liantus came to him and refixt him to it by conjurations too trong to be broken through. Alcidor being pervailed with to ticke cloe to the ide of that illutrious man, I reolved to run the ame coure with him, they both trictly enough obliging me to it. But as if good fortune had a mind that I hould withdraw from that pernicious revolt which I had too long aited, I was by a dangerous icknes which I fell into contrained to quit both Liantus and Alcidor, and retire home, where I continued a long time ill. This, cozin, ended Vindorix, bowing to Dorame, is all that I am able to tell you of the adventures of your lover more particularly than can my Lord our Uncle; I hall therefore here leave off to give him way to accomplih the relation of them.

At thee concluding words of Vindorix Rolimon preparing himelfe to carry on what he had begun, Dorame motion'd, conidering
they had been a great while hut up in a chamber, to defer a little the proecution of the narrative and goe take the aire: that which the company approving, after a collation brought in and ended they walkt abroad. But before they had pent halfe an houre in their walk there fell a great rain which forced them to take covert, and there they continued in various convere till they were called to upper. Supper done they at Dorame's requet returned to the place where Vindorix had performed his part of the tory, and there Rolimon having eated himelf with the others by him, went on with his part to this effect.

Polianis jutly irritated by the murder committed on the acred peron of his overeigne and brother-in-law Florimen decreed to take revenge of it or to perih in eeking it. Being alo the next man of his line, he reolved to ucceed him in the throne or to be laid with him in the dut in attempting it. Carried by the interet of which determinations from the eige of Paquin into the Province of Xanton and being, to top his progres, followed thither by Lucimon, he marched up to him, defeated his army and drove him to eek his afety in a dihonorable flight. Puruing his victory
he drew up again to Paquin, took the uburbs, gained other conquets and advantages, and compelled Lucimon to run before him as if he carried lighthing in his hand to chatie him. In none of thee unfortunat proceedings was Alcidor, for though Lucimon earnetly endeavoured to have him with him, whither the more eaily to detroy him or the better to have an eye upon his actions, he would never march under his conduct, but gave himelfe wholly to Liantus who being ingaged in as weighty imployments as any other of his party had himelfe a particular army under him. But the notable uccees of Polianis cauing Lucimon, Liantus and all the other captaines of the league to make one body of their forces, and the conideration of their numbers in which they far exceeded Polianis, raying their courages, which the abundance of blood pilt in the lat celebrated battel had drawn low, and carrying them to venture another feild with him; it was in that memorable day that Alcidor practied all the offenive and defenive gallantries of war, that he flew among the rankes, overturning them, laughtering them, breaking them in peices like a wiftwinged thunder, that he carried victory whither oever he carried
his word. He indeed performed o much both of the commander and ouldior that thoe againt whom he performed it with a generall conent cried out, At the blue carfe, (It was Floria's kindenes which dret him with that remark), on his being overcom depends our conquet; and accordingly all that had courage exercied it againt him; Polianis in particular dicharged pitolls with him and laboured all that he could to make him his prioner, but he was bravely uccoured by Liantus. In hort, I have heard a Cavaleir of his troop ay, who was in this occaion mained for the ret of his life, that with ome volunteers who accompanied him into the hottet of the • ight he kept the fortune of the day a great while in ballance. But having had two brothers who fought by his ide and did, like him, things worthy of mot lating monument for the uncommones of them, killed by it (the one of them carried his bowells a long time in his hand, the other when he was dropping from his hore turned upon the enemy that he might die facing them) and being et upon on all ides, he was at length filled with wounds which caued him to be carried out of the battell. His ill fortune was the whole armies of which
he was, their efforts, as if they could not fight without him, languiht as oon as he was gone, and there being no body that fought with the aire of Alcidor but the redoubtable Liantus, Polianis every where travert the phalanxes and battalions with a force which quickly compelled thoe againt whom he imployed it to put their noe in the earth with a rout and los the mot notorious that they ever before receaved.

While Alcidor kept his bed of his wounds ome of his neighbours who were his enemies having knowledge that he was unable to tir, and that his brothers were lain, brought to one of his houes, lying a dayes journey from Paquin, Indians that et fire to it and burnt it. This malicious act not having the power to trouble his great minde o much but that within a few weekes he was got perfectly well, as oon as he was o, he watch fully oberved the marches of thoe that had done it and within a few dayes met with them as he deired. Having a troop of elect men with him he fell upon them with a violence by which they who were acquainted with the blowes of Liantus and Alcidor might eaily have guet him to be one of them, againt which notwithtanding, thinking of nothing les than thoe
two renowned warriors, and only imagining that they had to doe with a troop who had met them by chance they at firt made a reitance tout enough; but he lifting up his viour and naming himelfe to them, they immediately betook themelves to flight as their bet defence. They fled ome one wayes ome another with all the peed that a guilty concience and a feare of punihment could give them: but he, from whom they fled, and his company purued them every way with uch a wift and well managed fury that they had in a moment or two got them into their power. Which done, could you think, you barbarous people, cried he to them, that heaven would leave unpunihed the outrage that you have done me? or could you beileve that I was o void of a oul as not to be enible of it, or uch a coward as not to eek you out? aying o, he ordered a dozen of them to be bound to trees, and cauing fire and traw to be brought repreented to them the jut reaon that he had to burn them in requitall of their burning of his houe. There being not one of them that did not entence himelfe as ufficiently deerving this punihment, they perpared themelves to die: but when they were urrendring themelves
to the • lames, I content myelfe, aid he to them, cauing them to be releaed and cutting ome of their bands himelfe, to have made you affraid and given you to ee that it is in my hands to deprive you of life; live and learne henceforward to doe well; I give you your liberty to goe whither you have a mind. Treated thus by him whom they had ued mot unworthily they expret to him a repentance of their offence which baniht all ill remembrance of it out of his mind, they adored him as one of more than humane goodnes and upertitiouly enough to have raied temples and altars to him if they had judged he would have liked it, they went home with reolutions never to give blow againt the party of which he was, and after they had been a little time there came and preented to him in reparation of the dammage that he had utained by their meanes a coniderable um of money: but he would by no meanes be brought to receive it, telling them that that which he valued was their freindhip and not their coine. It is true though he refued their ilver, he could not but accept of other preents which they urged upon him of hores and armes.

After this rendring himelfe with Liantus
who from the catterings of the lat feild had gathered together a coniderable body both of hore and foot, and eeking occaions of keeping his word in exercie, he one day going abroad with only fifty Gentlemen met two companies of Carabins of fourcore men apeice. At ight of whom examining the courage of thoe that were with and finding it uch as he deired, he ranged them in two quadrons and having orderd them to follow him lowly and when he gave the ignall to come up and charge, one the one company and the other the other, rode a little on before them. The enemy eeing him, very advantageouly hort as he was, come traight up to them upon a mall gallop, all at once made their alute to him; and in return to it he and his followers were in an intant upon them, gave them a volley of hot with which many of them tumbled, and falling in amidt the confuion with an impetuoity which is not to be expret, quickly laid a great number of them more upon the ground, and forced the ret, to yeild themelves prioners part of them, part of them to fly.

Polianis in the interim, not blinding himelfe with his properities, but preciely oberving the motions of his enemies and managing
his affaires according to the bet maximes and rules of prudence, when having endeavoured to concile his people to his governement by weetnes, he aw himelfe forced by their obtinacy to ue teele and blood, he laid eige anew to Paquin, not without the inhabitants riing in his caue, nor without their being tilled and drawne back from him by the Governor and Magitrates. For the better defence of it Lucimon would have had Alcidor put himelf again into it; but Floria was not there to oblige him to doe o, and he had been too ill ued by that prince to oberve his deire. He kept in the feild, where making continuall coures to and fro, he moleted the Kings forces more than any of his party. In particular having gotten certain intelligence that at uch a time there would be a broad an important convoy of the enemy coniting of three hundred hore and as many Fanta • ns, and which way they would pas, he put himelfe with two hundred hore in ambucade in a wood, and there attending till they came, when he aw his time charged the Cavalry with a fury which they were not able to reit but were routed, cut in peices and taken: the Fantains in the mean time aving themelves by help of
the wood, but leaving what they were conveighing to the dipoall of the conqueror. Among thoe that were taken were Melampus and
• o • ilus, Lords whom Alcidor knew and who were retiring from the Kings army upon the account of ill health. To them he retored their liberty and caued all their equipage alo to be returned, for which they have ever ince been of the number of the bet friends that he hath had in the world. A great man who oberved him after the fight leaning againt a tree with his armes hining with ilver, with his word in his hand bloody up to the hilt and with the viour of his cask put up and dicovering his face hath everall times ince aid, that he could not imagine a more gracefull ight than he then appeared to him, or a more perfect reemblance of Mars taking breath after a conquet. At this defeat of his men the King was very much troubled, but being of a dipoition that carried him to commend brave actions he highly extolled this of Alcidor and named him one of the mot gallant men of his ide.

The mieries of Paquin being at length by the preures of the eige grown to incredible extremities, all things eemed inclined to put it into the hands of Polianis, and its
grand, officers urged by the mutinous and mournfull cryes of all orts of people and by their own neceities, were treating with him about a peedy urrender when they were incouraged o tand out a while longer by intelligence which they had brought them that Otravius was coming apace with a potent army to releive them; And they were not diappointed, for within a few dayes the King drew of all his forces to go offer that famed Captaine battel; but he would not be drawn to venture uch a dangerous cat, thinking it enough to uccour the cheif Town, and take ome others and retire; Nor was Polianis able either to force him to doe the on, or to hinder him from doing the other. Seeing which he fell to work with everall mall Towns and took them, and ome of great conequence: he made preparations alo for invironing Xanton; which when Otravius and Lucimon could no longer doubt of, they commended that Rivall of Paquin to the tuition of Liantus and Alcidor; Liantus in quality of Governor and Alcidor as his aitant, and they dicharged their trut with tupendious performances: whatoever honour put them upon they failed not of undertaking
and whatoever they undertook they failed not of having • crowned with honour: they by a alley which they made forced the army that begirt them to withdraw to a good ditance from the walls, and though they were afterwards brought into great traights for want of victualls they notwithtanding held it undauntedly out till the aforeaid princes came and compelled the King to rie from before them and leave them at liberty.

A while after the King, being infinitely troubled that he could ee no good end in the propect which lay before him of his people's obtinacies and mieries, to undeceive it poible thoe who had left themelves to be abued by the pecious pretexts that were et up againt him, and by that meanes tifle that hidra of the rebellion whoe heads recruited as fat as he lopt them of, publiht a declaration which erved very happily for a foundation of that obedience which many of his ubjects that were in arms againt him were preparing for him in their minds. It particularly put Liantus and Alcidor upon conidering and weighing of things which they had before very little or not at all thought of. But being the principall prings by which the
Union moved, they thought it not noble to leave in the lurch thoe that depended upon them, and who could not long ubit but would be utterly undone without them. They therefore kept on their way with their wonted vigor, but Alcidor not with his wonted ucces. Whither Fortune had a mind to cat a blot amidt his glories that o he might not boat he had impeded her from her changeablenes of motion, or whither heaven thought fit to animadvert upon him for uing his word againt his rightfull overaignes Florimen and Pol • anis by a cros adventure which hould take it out of his hand, he happened to be encountred by a force which gave him the hottet work that he had ever had experience of They were many of them that were met Commanders of known courage and addres, there was no body who did not chooe rather to die than flie; it is impoible as I have heard him ay ever to ee weightier blowes and more manfull attaques and reitances than were than to be een, and if one party was ready to be Victor one moment the other releived it elfe and was ready to give the law the next. But in the end Alcidor having done all that man could doe, he had his hore killed under him and was himelfe
overthrown upon the ground with him, in which poture being ummoned to yeeld he had nothing to anwer, but that the cae in which he was contrained him o to doe. Being demanded his name, conidering that he had too many enemies in the Kings army he judged it prudent to conceal it and called himelf Belompus.

At this Period Rolimon addreing himelf to his neice, Thee, cozen, aid he, are the mot remarkable adventures which I have any intimacy with of your new lover, and judge if I have not poken well of him in favour of whoe rivall I came to wait upon you. There are ome things in the world, Sir, replied Dorame to him, of which one cannot hold one's peace, and the paages of Alcidor's life being of this kind, it is truth and jutice which have compelled you to ay what you have aid. But I cannot yet be contented unles I hear what became of Floria and whither Alcidor aw her not during the time of his activity abroad. You cannot know this o well of any body as of Alcidor himelf, aid Vindorix to her, but was he here the quetion is whither you have the power
to obtaine the recitall of him. The quetion is rather, aid Melian, whether he hath the power of refuing her any thing, and certainly when he hall know that we have in his abence entertained our elves with what we know of his concernements he will not refue to entertain us himelf with what we know not of them. However ince we have no more to relate of him, reumed Vindorix, let us by my conent take our way to bed, and tay no longer with my cozen, to whom dayes, nights, ages would be no more than moments if one hould all the while hold her with dicoures concerning him. You peake, Cozen, returned Dorame to him, as if you was little skilled in obliging women, or ele as if you had more harpenes for me than if I had no relation to you. But poibly I hall not be o unhappy as not to • inde an opportunity of revenging myelf upon you. I make no quetion, aid he again to her, but I hall have patience enough to bear whatoever ill offices you hall have a mind to doe me, auring myelf that they will not be overgreat becaue I am Alcidor's freind. To this Dorame going about to repart, I ee, aid Rolimon, it is
neceary that I hould break off this contet which will otherwie not at all regard how late the hours grow or know when to make an end, and therewith roe from his eat; which the ret doing after his example, they bad good night and went to bed.
div.trailer: The End of the econd Book.

div.head: The Third BOOK.
div.p:
THe next morning Dorame riing early enough to make her guets ee that it was not lazines which had kept her o long in bed the day before, as oon as he was dret, he went to take her Uncle Rolimon in his chamber; but he found that he was together with Vindorix and Melian gon to walk in the garden. She going thither to them, I hope, my neice, began Rolimon to her, the ame phantames have not troubled you this night that did the former. I can never leep with more tranquillity, anwered he to him, than I have don to night, and if any thing came in my mind when I was awake more than ordinary it was only what you have recounted to me of Alcidor, and ome feares I mut confes
leat by the way hither he hould be met by ome freind of Cartagenes and called to an account for his death. Diturb not your mind with thoe upicions, replyed Rolimon to her, for he hath in this province a more redoubted name than that any body hould quickly be as rah as was Cartagenes to commit the like indicretion of aaulting him. Have you then o ill an opinion of the courage of Cloriates, aid Dorame to him miling, as to beleive that he will not fight upon my account. I hold him for a man of heart, returned Rolimon to her, but ince he knowes not that Alcidor is your Lover, would you have me imagin that there will be a combat between two perons who have nothing of quarrell. Let us not amuze ourelves in prognoticating a micheif of which there is no probability that it hould quickly, if at all, fall out, but let us think of eeing Alcidor here at dinner; for my part I have trong hopes that we hall, for I am ure there is nothing of expedition which he will not ue when he knowes that you deire to ee him. The night had not hades o thick as to hinder him from travailing, and beides when he undertakes any thing, he makes his way through all, nor
woods, nor rocks nor pitchy darkenees are unpaable to him. I have practied him enough to know him, and I peak no more than what I know to be true of him.

To this Dorame was going to ay omething, when they aw enter the coverd walk where they at Limonides with a look though not o overcat as when he brought the newes of the death of Cartagenes, yet very legibly incribed with omething of adnes. As oon as he came near them, have you ome new unhappines, prevented him Rolimon, to informe us of that you carry o melancholick a face? Have your pains been unprofitable in eeking Alcidor? or have you met with him, and ome ill hath befallen him? Almidon, Sir, replyed Limonides to him, hath followed Cartagenes; Alcidor hath made him pay at the point of the word for the outrage that he did him in reporting what was fale of him to Cartagenes. What • ighting is here, cryed D • rame ighing? This is not the way to let us quickly ee Alcidor as we expected. This will not all retard his coming, Madam, aid Limonides to her, you will ee him with you within an hour. You tell me what will be enough to my contentment Limonides, aid he in anwer to
him, provided it proves true. There is nothing in the world more true, Madam, returned Limonides to her, than that he intends it. I hal make no more quetion of it, replied Dorame to him, but tell us what you know of his fighting with Almidon. Being conducted, Madam, aid Limonides, by Alcidors lacquey to the houe of Meonimus (a freind of his) which is not far ditant from that, which was my Maters while he lived, nor from that alo of Almidon, I there found him and delivered to him your Letter; which when he had read he told me there was no cure that I could have brought him like that for the greif with which he reented my Maters death. Saying little ele but that little, enough to make me perceive that he had ome buines which he was in hat to dipatch with omebody, he jumpt on horeback and galloped away. To ee whither he went I followed him with as much peed as I could without being perceived by him; but I was not able for ome time to et eye upon him. At length I dicerned him above a hundred paces from me with his word in his hand againt a man whom at that ditance I know not. Riding as hard as I could to the place I had carce dicoverd
his adverary to be Almidon, but I aw him run into the body by him and fall. When Alcidor aw me by them, confes before Limonides, Almidon, aid he, the wrong that you have don me in reporting to his Mater thoe things that were the occaion of his death. I can by no meanes excue, returned Almidon to him, what you charge me with, and therefore if I may ay that I forgive what is jut, I forgive you the wound which you have given me, and which is apace letting out my oule. At thee words Alcidor dropping ome teares upon his misfortune as he had don upon my Maters, topt his wound with his handkercheif, et him upon his hore and conveighed him to the houe from which we came. There we aid, as Almidon deired us to ay, and aid himelfe that an enemy who had met him by chance had given him his hurt, and the Mater of the houe endeavouring to inform himelf of the name of that enemy he would never tell him, but deired him to content himelf with this that he was a gallant man who had jut occaion to et upon him, and that he died atisfied with him, not knowing how to complain of his action which he was free and valiant. He aid but little more and died
in the armes of Alcidor, who, his eyes being cloed, commanded me back to you with aurance that as oon as he had taken order to have him caried home, he would come away by the light of the moon to render himelf with you.

Limonides having aid thus and holding his tongue, It is indeed Alcidors happines, aid Dorame, that thoe whom he fights with and kills die his freinds, but I am, notwithtanding, that very much troubled at thee occurrences. That, aid Rolimon, is the part of honet perons that come to be o unfortunat, and thee incounters indeed, aid Vindorix, though they are to be accounted good in regard that Alcidor hath had the better in them, yet they are not o in regard that two men, and one of them a man of true gallantry, have in a privat quarrell lot their lifes by his hand. But we hall have the les reaon to be troubled provided Cloriates increaes not the number of thoe unfortunats: and we have reaon to hope that he will not, becaue at preent he does not think that he hath any occaion of falling out with Alcidor, and if he hould think o hereafter, he mut alo think that to fight with him is not but to augment his trophes. For one to have
two uch combats one upon the heels of another aid Melian, and in both to kill his adveraries without being at the cot of a drop of blood, does not uually happen; but it is to Alcidor that it hath happened and that hinders it from being a wonder. A great reaon of his good ucces, aid Dorame, urely is becaue he drew not his word but upon a jut caue; for who can deny but he had right on his ide in both thee duells, in the one as being aaulted, in the other as being outraged. No man, Cozen, aid Rolimon to her, can with jutice condemn him for what he hath don and if any man hould have either o much malice or o little judgment as to peak ill of him for it, he would finde enough ready to revenge it upon him. But let us withdraw hence to wait for him in the houe, as hady as this place is the rayes of the un peircing it, and beginning to et it on fire.

Removed into the houe, they for ome time held converation upon everall worthy things which Cartagenes had done, and then Dorame turned it to Floria and Alcidor, peaking very much in commendation of the former for regarding the merit rather than the birth of the latter, though reerving
the quality of Prince, he knew he was iued of one of the bet families of the kingdom and of him they were peaking when he came into the room where they were. At the ight of one another he and Dorame were truck into a little tupor, which being quickly diipated and alutations performed, you have ince you left us, Sir, aid he to him, been to us the caue and the object of more than ordinary apprehenions; my Uncle and Cozens who came hither two dayes ince have been both witnees and partners of them; but was there a neceity that you hould abue us by making hadow to us of going to agree ome freinds and engaging yourelf in mortall quarrells? I hope, Madam, interrupted her Alcidor, Limonides hath not done me the ill office to conceal what pat between his Mater and me? He hath given us a full account of it, Sir, aid Rolimon to him, but my neice taking a particular interet in your preervation, therefore ets thus upon you, that he may peruade you not to be another time o ready to atisfie the reentments of men void of reaon. What could I do les, replied Alcidor, than ue my word againt a man who forced me o to defend me honor and my life. I am
certainely no quarreller, much les am I of a humor to fall foul upon thoe whom I do not beleeve to have a deign of offending me, but that it hould be aid that out of cowardie I diengaged myelf from a provocation, or that any body hould et upon me without my giving them to ee, as far as I am able, that I am not inenible, I can by no meanes bring myelf to endure. You gave ufficient demontration of this to Liimax, aid Dorame to him, and thereby acquired a far more triumphing reputation than that any body hould be eaily dipoed to pas entence upon you as puillanimous. I ee you know, Madam, returned Alcidor to her, what in repect of its in coniderablenes I had reaon to think lay private from you; but that is too mall a thing to procure me credit with any body, much les can it bring me into eteem with you to whom thoe things are common which to others are rare. Not to diemble what we have done, Sir, aid Rolimon to him, Vindorix and I to divert my neice have imparted to her the knowledge which we have of your life, which reaches, you know, to the time that you was taken prioner, excepting what became of Floria and what intercoure you maintained with her, after her
Uncle removed her from Paquin. I am orry, replied Alcidor, that he hath had no better a diverion, the occurrences of War uually making horror rather than harmony to thoe of her exe and temper. Notwithtanding my weaker exe, reparted Darame, I am not of o weake a temper, as to be frighted with the bruite of things; on the contrary they have been very melodious aires to me, both thoe of your martiall deeds and thoe of your amorous intelligences whith the princes Floria. In the remainder of which latter I beeech you to intruct me, after you have recounted to us, that which I alo begge of you, how things went between you and Almidon. But yet before you doe this I will hew you what Cartagenes wrot to me dying. With thoe words he took out of her pocket and preented to him the letter of that defunct, which he having read. How few uch men, aid he, are there to be found in the world, and how much regret have I that uch a man hould fall by my word, though withall by his own fault. But let us leave him in peace Madam, continued he, and uffer me to tell you that you ue me with too much ceremony to intreat of me what it is your part to command. Had you as much favor
for me as I have honor and obedience for you, you would only ay, Alcidor, it is my will you hould do thus and thus; this freenes would make me do what you deire with greater cheerfullnes. But you beleive you hould render me too happy hould you treat me o. You have no reaon urely to complain, anwered he to him, if I pay you the repect which I know to be due to you: looe no more time therefore in producing to us thee punctilio's of your pirit, we being better aured of its excellency than to need uch tetimonies of it, but relate to us the adventure, which you have had with Almidon. Not to tell you again what you have been told allready, Madam, aid Alcidor to her, be pleaed to take this breviate of the ret.

After I was informed by Cartagenes and Limonides, how Almidon had calumniated me to the former, and by o doing been the author of his misfortune (over which I could not chooe but weep) I had no longer any thing beides my love of your elf o buy in my minde as revenge; but I was a while unreolved of what means I hould erve myelf in proecution of it; ometimes I thought of acting one way, ometimes another: I was indeed mot inclined
to go find him myelf in his houe, and draw him into the feild, there to demand an account of him for what he had done; but I was withall mierably agitated with fears of incurring your dipleaure by o doing, and of acquiring the tittle of a gladiator more than of your ervant. I had agreed thoe upon whoe occaion I went hence with the ucces that I deired, and there was nothing but my love that tood in the way of my anger. But when I conidered that you was of a more generous humor than to take it ill that I hould eek atisfaction for the wrong that was done to me and for the micheife that was done to Cartagenes, I wavered no longer but leaving that dying man in the armes and to the care of Limonides, I betook myelf to the houe of Meonimus from which that of Almidon was not far ditant. Where having taid ome hours to repoe my elfe and write that letter to you which you was pleaed mot obligingly to anwer, I got again on horebacke, and leaving behinde me my freind's houe was quickly at that of my enemie. I found him at home, was receaved by him better than I deired, and oon undertood from him that he knew nothing of the death of Cartagenes (for I reckoned
him to be by that time no more among the living) and that he beleived I knew nothing of the reports which he had made to him concerning me. Hiding therefore my reentments from him, after I had taid with him neer an houre, and refued the invitations of eating which he very civilly pret me with, I acted o that I engaged him to ride out with me. When we were come far enough from his houe, in the midt of a wood, whither I erved myelf of the occaion of a great roade to bring us, taking him by the hand and obliging him to make a halt as I did, Almidon, aid I to him, I know not where to find a place more proper to require an account of the injury that you have done me than this. Amaz'd at which words without giving me leaure to proceed, what is it, Alcidor, aid he, which moves you thus to urprize me? I never had a minde aid I to him again, to urprize any man unhandomely; but knowing that you have not freenes enough to atisfie willingly thoe whom you have wronged, I have choe to draw you clan • ularly hither that o you might not be able to find any way of ecaping or giving yourelf a dipenation from fighting. But tell me then, returned he to me, what the injury is which
you accue me of having done you, and for which you thus et upon me. Do you not remember, replied I to him, or can you deny that you not long ince poke of me to Cartagenes otherwie than was true and honet? who, anwered he, hath told you that I did? Cartagenes himelf, reparted I. He hath indeed allwayes told me, returned he, that he would ingage me in a quarrell with omebody, and I have now too much experience of it to quetion that he was in earnet. But I will maintain to him that he lyes and that I never poke of you but as I ought. At thoe words provokt with his baenes in denying what I was ure he was guilty of, and laying the blame upon one of whoe innocence I had ufficient proofe, I took my word in my hand againt him; but he made no offer of putting himelf in a poture of defence. Seeing which, are you o great a coward, cried I to him, as not only to unay what you have broached, but alo to refue fighting with one who defies you to it and will kill you if you do not reit him? But thee reproaches tirred him not and I was unwilling to trike a man who would not defend himelf. To try therefore if I could bege • a courage in him, and withall the better to convict him, I repeated to him
the words which he had aid to Cartagenes. Struck with which and his owne concience together he at on his hore like a tatue as if he had had nothing of ene or motion left him. At length recovering pirit, Cartagenes, aid he, hath been mot diingenuouly unjut to fixe upon me what I never thought of, and I hall act powerfully enough againt him to let you quickly ee his artifice and baenes, and that I am no uch bae or cowardly peron as you accue me to bee. Cartagenes no longer lives, cried I to him, this word which I hold in my hand to punih you hath forced him to make a voyage into another world for having too lightly given credit to your dicoures. That unhappy Cavaleir was as valiant to attacque me as you are heartles to defend yourelf; but the equity of my caue urmounted the injutice of his, and you, Impotor hall, if I can make you, run the ame adventure, expiating your crime with your blood. Take your word therefore in your hand or I will run you through. But thee words warned him no more than the former, and could he have fled I dare confidently ay he would not have taied long in the place. In ine, when after I had with a great deal of patience waited upon him he aw I would wait
no longer but was reolved to ue him enough to his ignominy unles he would tand upon his guard, he told me that his word was not equall to mine, as indeed it was not, being as bad a one as I have commonly een, and that if I would tay till the next morning he would render himelf where I hould appoint to give me the atisfaction that I deired. As commonly they who have an ill paymater their debtor are content to be paid with uch money as they can receive, I conented to his procratination and we concluded upon a place and hour where and when to meet the following day. Which being come, about halfe an houre before Limonides came to me, I aw enter the houe of Meonimus one whom though diguied I knew to be Almidons lacquey. The fahion in which I aw him, and the manner in which he inquired for Meonimus, whom I had ent from home in the morning upon other buines, that o I might have leaure to perform that which I had in hand with Almidon, made me upect that his Mater was brewing omething of treachery. To acertain myelf of the truth of it, and know what this diguie meant, I took the lacquey by the collar, and hewing my elf mot violently angry threatned him to make him
hang if he would not quickly tell me why he was metamorphot, and for what reaon he came into the houe covertly and like a theife. Preently the poor boy who had his enes frozen with feare confet to me that his Mater had given him a umme of money to advertie Meonimus ecretly of the Duel which he was to perform with me, and to feigne that it was his owne proper motion to give him the advertiement. Inquiring then of the lacquey where his Mater was, and hearing that he was gone to the place aigned for our meeting I thought of nothing any more but to make hate to him. But Limonides arrived at the intant with your mot wellcome letter, and I taid to read it twice over and to peak a few words to him that brought it. Which done to come upon Almido ••
unawares, I galloped to him by a private way. Perceiving him wholly atoniht to ee me intead of Meonimus whom he expected, I gave him leaure to recollect himelf, and then I with much difficulty made him draw his word; But he ued it o ill that I with little difficulty gave him a wound which let out the bet part of his blood upon the place. The ret Limonides I uppoe hath acquainted you with, I hall therefore only add that I have not
without a very great dipleaure to me been compelled in this fahion to make good my honor againt a gallant man and a cowardly. He having aid o, the action of the former of them, aid Dorame, does indeed afford a ubject of praie, that of the latter carries infamy in its remembrance. Nothing is more certain, adjoined Vindorix, than that a mans good or bad reputation depends for the mot part upon his actions. Some more words they had upon this occaion and Alcidor fell into particularities with Dorame; in which the other company being about to leave them, the table preently hewed it elf coverd and called them all to take their eates.

As oon as they had dined Dorame carrying them into a private room requeted Alcidor to make the reci •• ll that he had promied of the remainder of his loves, and he obeyed her in a dicoure to this effect.

Vindorix knows the trouble which the abence of Floria gave me, to which was added that which I had to ee him fall ick and contrained to leave me. The imprionment alo of
• l • cidas, which I knew he ufferd for favouring of me, I had uch a ene of that had I known where Lucimon had hut him up I hould either have drawn him
thence or lot myelf in undertaking it. I had I am ure too much caue to complain of that prince to erve him in his army. I therefore put my elf in that of Liantus, and there I pat ome time without learning any news of the princes though I had continually pies about Lucimon to dicover in what place of the earth he kept her. By this my cares of Love appearing without hopes of properity, and the War every moment furnihing me with new means of laying both them and the melancholy which they caued to me aleep, I began after ome months to think no otherwie of the Princes than as of one who was wholly lot to me. Among thee thoughts an expedition carrying us towards the province of Sancy, the econd day after our arrivall in thoe quarters I aw come into my chamber one, whom though diguied, I preently knew to be Alexis page to Floria, and who gave me a letter the contents whereof I till remember were thee.

div.head: Floria to Alcidor.
div.p:
AT lat in depight of Lucimon and his tyranny I have the means to informe you of the torments that I undergo. I am more retrained than laves and more rigorouly ued than
Crimi • alls. Excepting this Page and Leonora I have no body about me whoe fidelity is not corrupted. Judge then if I am not to complain and if my afflictions ought not to touch you. But I hall be in a great meaure happy amidt my unhappinees if I can but be aured that you till love me. I no ooner knew of the approach of Liantus towards this Towne of Sanchio but I imagined that you was with him and have therefore ent Alexis to you to let you know that my greatet fear is that of not eeing you. Send me word how you do and whither the courage of Alcidor can uffer that Floria hould live allways mierable.

Seriouly affected with thee lines when I coniderd that a page had had the faithfullnes, wit and courage to deceive the Princes's guards, I could not but reckon myelf obliged to practie all poible means of eeing her. Sending therefore Alexis before to advertie her that I would be uddenly at her feet, but that he and Leonora mut diemble their knowledge of me, with a elect Troop whom I durt trut and whom, in that confidence whichI had in them, I intructed to call me by another name, I took the way withall he peed that I could after him. Coming to the place about, twilight I askt to
peak with Doliban the Captaine that guarded the princes; who preently appearing I told him that Liantus having received advie of a deign that was on foot of taking away the Princes, had ent me to impede the execution of it. Taking what I told him for certain, he received me with a great deal of freenes, hewed me what ouldiers he had and what order he oberved for preerving his fair charge and deired me to do what I judged in the preent occaion fitting. Accordingly to confirm him in his beleife of what I had affirmed, I appointed entinells to be et at all the avenues of the place, and concerned my elf to ee that and everall other things done with as much zeal as if I had really been affraid of the rape that I pretended, and with as much diligence as if I expected it would have been preently attempted. All this while I dicoverd nothing to him of the deire that I had to ee the Princes, but as oon as we had ettled things for her afety, he of his own accord offerd me to conduct me to her, I took the offer and went along with him like one ufficiently diintereted, and he received me as coldly. When Doliban indeed with longer eulogies of me than either he or I at that time cared for, told her what rank I
held with Liantus and upon what errand I was come from him, he payd me thoe repects which in common manners were due, but yet he in every thing acted her part o agely that one would have firmely beleived he had not had the leat acquaintance with me. Leonora alo gave authority to the diimulation by the curioity which he hewed in inquiring after my name and everall other things about me. But Doliban being after a while called away, we quickly changed the fahion of your convere. We recounted, he to me the everities which her Uncle Lucimon had exercied upon her ince he had removed her from Paquin, I to her the pains that I had taken to learn her abode, both I to her and he to me how bitter our forcible eparation had been to us, and how weet our preent toln interview was; we deliberated of the means of keeping Doliban blind and of eeing one another for the future; we dicourt of all that we could think of pat, preent and to come that concerned either our good or our ill, we determined that for prevention of dicovery and to keep of upicion it was neceary that as I had come after the un was gone down o I hould be gone before it was gotten up: In breife the mot of the
leaure that we had we pent in reciprocating tetimonies of affection to one another the mot emphaticall that her vertue and my repectfullnes could allow us. But this kept us not from being o wary that when Doliban returned to me, he found me examining whither all things were in good order at the inlets. In which work he bearing me company, I took occaion to remontrate to him that it was neceary the plot hould be kept ecret from every body and particularly from Lucimon for fear it hould alarum him o as to diturb him in the great affairs which he had upon his hands. It is ufficient, added I, that the enemie's deign is known to Liantus, your elf and me, our forces and cares being of validity enough to ruine it; only let it be your buines to watch olicitouly for the ecurity and advantage of your charge, and it hall be mine to give as I am obliged a very fair character of you to him that ent me. To this Doliban haped a reply full of honety and civility, and carried me backe to the Princes; who ignifying ome apprehenions of the danger that he was in we aured her that provided they in the Town had, as there was no reaon to quetion but they had, reolution and fidelity anwerable to their duty, he was
as afe where he was as he could be any where ele of the Kingdome. I had by this time not above halfe an houre to tay, and Doliban as opportunely as if on purpoe receding, we improoved it as we were taught by our Mater Love. He reentring when we were drawing to a concluion my tongue inenibly lided to commend her to his tuition and to take my leave of them both. Returned to the Campe I found that Liantus had ent all about in earch of me; preenting my elf therefore to him though he with a trict curioity examined where I had been, I deceived him as well as I had done Doliban, diguiing things o to him that he had not the leat upicion of the truth.

By uch means during a month that we taied in the province of Sancy I eaven or eight times tole the ight and company of Floria; after which the motions of the War carrying us ele whither we bad one another adieu with tears on her part which he told me prang from trong apprehenions that he hould never ee me again, and with protetations on my part that how remote oever the Countrey was whither I went I would not with the bleing of Heaven be long before I viited her. But Polianis never uffering us to ret, but continually
hewing himelf either at our heels or Lucimon's, o that all the diligence that we could ue was too little to protect ourelves againt him, I was much longer than I expected before I could make good my word. He indeed by the victories which he obtained over us weakened us o much that I had more reaon to conider how to prevent the ruine of myelf and my party than how to carry on my loves with Floria. Not to reheare any of the traveres of the War (for with them I uppoe you are allready acquainted) every moment that I would have gone to find the Princes, new imployments were laid in my way by Liantus whom I accounted my elf bound in honour to oberve. But I was nothwithtanding all obtructions contriving at length how to make an ecape for a few dayes from the Campe, when Alexis preented himelf again to me together with this letter.

div.head: Floria to Alcidor.
div.p:
HOw repectfully oever Doliban treates me I am continually rackt with an impatient longing either to ee you or heare from you. I hould indeed be in hazard of dying with malancholy, was it not for Leonora who makes
it her worke to comfort me, and particularly endeavours to perwade me that the important affaires in which you are ingaged allow you not the time that you deire to atisfie my wil • . Howoever it is that you are imploied, for love of me preerve your life, • remembring that you ought to act the Captain and not the common Souldier, and either come to me or write the caue which hinders you from coming.

Incited by this language and my own inclinations I was never at ret till I had procured liberty of <> to be a few dayes abent, nor till I was gotten with Alexis to her who had ent him to me. She declared herelfe as glad to ee me as at other times, yet withall a little diatisfied with me becaue I had taid o long away from her. But with the remontrances which I made to her I o perfectly compoed her pirit and et all o well in tune that our convere all the while I taid after conited of no other notes but what were purely harmonious, and that when I told her the houres called me away he tooke it not at all ill, but freely dimit me. We thus from time to time aw one another by the politickes which we ued keeping Doliban from perceiving and Lucimon from learning any thing of our intelligence,
and conequently having the former allwayes dipoed to pleae us.

But I could not content my elf with this, unles I aw Placidas at liberty, whom I hould have been very ungratefull hould I not have remembred of my elf, and whom the Princes and Leonora putting me alo in mind of informed me of the place where he was kept prioner. In recompene therefore of the good ervices which he had done his Princes and the good offices which he done me, I procured his prion to be forced and his imprionment to be put an end to, an exploit of which I hould have been quickly upected the authour by Lucimon, had I not imploied in it uch in whom I knew I might trut, given them order to name themelves of the roiall party, and managed the whole buines with a uitable diguie. The newes of it flying as fat to Lucimon as Placidas did to me, he was vext at it to a tempetous rage, and conceived uch feares of eeing as much befall his neice that he immediately removed her from the place where he was. Whither he removed her I was not able by all the means that I could ue to decover; but at length Alexis came to me with word from her that he was at Suchieu and that Doliban
was no more with her but another Captain who allowed her not o much liberty as he had done. Not being allwayes able to find a tratageme favourable to my deire of viiting her, I ent this letter by him to her.

div.head: Alcidor to Floria.
div.p: YOur ufferings have not a harper influence upon yourelf than upon me. But a great and incomparable Princes as you are knowes how to overcome her afflictions with her contancy. Nor may you beleive that Alcidor will be deprived of the glory of eeing you any longer than is neceary for procuring an expedient of effecting it; and my love is more powerfull than not ere long to procure one in depight of the new tyrant that watches you.

Two dayes after I had ent away Alexis, Liantus having advertiement that the inhabitants of Suchieu were fallen into mutinies, to remedy the dicorder thought fit that I hould make a voiage thither. Having by which means in a hort time obtained an opportunity which I might have a long time been eeking by art, I was quickly on horebacke, and quickly at my journie's end. All
tumults ceaing at my arrivall. After I had reettled things in their former contitutions, I enquired of the officers of the Town what condition the Princes was in and what order was oberved in guarding her, and they not only informed me in what I askt, but they alo conducted me to her and left me with her; that which Anaximenes the Captain that had the Cutody of her, though it was wholly againt the command which Lucimon had given him, was o far from oppoing, that buying himelf about omething of his charge which required his preent care, he gave us ufficient leaure of entertaining one another. We had indeed not only that firt day, but alo during foure dayes that I taid at Suchieu as much liberty with one another as before that Lucimon was jealous of it, and I made as frequent and as free viits to her as I deired, Anaximenes being very happily to our advantage o paionate of Leonora that he made him act what part he would.

After this rate of correpondencies perited we to live till Dorilas, ecaping out of prion into his Uncle Lucimon's army and there hearing from that grand enemy of our loves all that he knew of them, came himelf to Suchieu and there charged it upon his
Siter with very harpe reproaches. Advertiement hereof he ent me by Alexis; whereupon, though he aured me withall that not brother, not Uncle, not all whooever hould either by fair or foul means be ever able to divorce her heart from me, I nevertheles with cloe and erious thoughts repreented to my elf that her quality, beauty, wiedom, vertue rendring her an equall match to the poeor of a throne, for me to apire to the poeion of her was to go about to debae her from her jut height, to be guilty of an arrogance of which the fruite would be common envy if it ucceeded, if it ucceded not publique deriion; and to pull upon me from her relations a loade of malice under which I mut necearily fall. From thee and uch like premies I drew a concluion to beware for the future how I nouriht an affection of which nothing could in all likelihood come but unhappines. But write this concluion to her in relation to whom I made it I durt not; I only ent her word by Alexis that ince her brother diliked that pious fire with which I offered my heart in acrifice to her, I would for ome time hide it under the ahes that o I might not kindle in him a deign of detroying me, but yet, during that
reerve, would not fail of eeing her if it was poible, or at leat of writing to her. Which meage in what ene he contrued, I know not, but this I know that from that time I nor aw her nor heard from her till after I was taken prioner.
