This turne of my fortune, having if I may peak it without vanity by an uninterrupted
• roperity of my armes climbed to a u •• icient eminency of reputation, I had at firt no other ene of, than as of a fall, the digrace and dammage of which was very hardly if at all to be repaired; but it afterwards proved of very profitable conequence to me. Polianis tooke notice and care of me as of ome body coniderable, he appointed me no other jayle but his court, no other jaylor but my parole, he gave me a thouand rich experiences of his goodnes, he earnetly pret me to ingage in his ervice, and I hould without doubt have done myelf the good office of atisfying him, had he been of the ame religion with me. That he was not was the argument that I ued to him for my dipenation, and he took it not ill; only when by far better fortune than merit I was demanded to be releaed in exchange for three, the meanet of whom was of much more value than Alcidor, he obliged me to
promie him that I would change my ide when he changed his faith.

While I lay prioner at the Court I was told by everall of credit that Floria was erelong to be married to Eridan, prince of the royall Blood. Whereupon, what I had before carried by rote, I confirmed by decree that I would conider her no more as my mot adorable mitres but only as my illutrious freind. But though I was fully bent to retire from her bonds, I notwithtanding went to waite upon her as oon as I was at liberty, and in our convere I ued all the skill that I was Mater of to veile my intentions from her. But we had not been long together before he told me that he after my long abence oberved a contraint and alteration in me which was very trange to her. I endeavouring to make her looe that opinion, and particularly excuing my abence by my imprionment and upon that occaion peaking honourably, and as I was in gratitude bound, of Polianis, he rejoined that he was affraid the favours and vertues of that victorious prince had overcome me o as to make me at once abandon the interets of her family and grow cold in the affection which I had vowed to her. To this I was haping an anwer with which I hoped
to atisfie her, but was prevented by the coming of Dorilas, which gave me no more leaure than to lip away without o much as bidding her Adieu, and I had no more opportunity of eeing her before that her upicious brother carried her away to a place where he was more traightly guarded than ever.

At length the King after he had eriouly deliberated of the concernements of religion making a turne which pleaed ome, dipleaed others, brought over to him the mot remarkeable Lords of • he Union, and rended Lucimon allmot deperate, with a mot propitious condecenion challanged me of the promie which I made him when I left his prion, and I readyly followed whither the loadtone of his authority and goodnes drew me, not without the honour of having the incomparable Liantus to beare me company. Him he preently made vice Roy of a province of China, to me he gave twenty thouand Takes in preent to repair the expences that I had been at in maintaining the War againt him, and foure thouand Takes in penion, cauing me withall to be aluted by Feonice the ruling object of his affections and by her Siter Ataia a principall beauty of his court.

Thee things were not done with o little noie but that they reached the eares of Floria, and as Alexis brought me word he fell icke with the hot alarum which he took at them. By him therefore I wrot back to her that he ought not to take it ill that I had quitted a party whom I at length had found to be mot unjutly and diloyally armed againt their Soveraigne, or that the danger which I aw and he knew I was every moment in by the ill will of her relations had made me think a little of acting as my preervation demanded of me, and that as long as I lived he hould have caue to beleeve that I had for her a jut veneration, a thankfull memory, and a faithfull ervice.

It followed by ome intervalls, and I have done when I have told you it, that Liantus and I were et on work by the King to help to detroy that monter (for o we now reckoned the Union) which we had o long aited, and that we very properouly atcheived our task, that Dorilas eeing no body obtinate for the league but his Uncle Lucimon, and having no mind to ruine himelf with him askt the King's pardon and received it, that Polianis jutly incent againt Atalantus for having incited and maintained his ubjects againt him with deigne of eizing
the monarchy of China declared War againt him and obtained againt him three ignal victories, that the enemies forces being vanquiht by Adratus in the province of Peuquiam, others of the ame party entered into that of Xiancy and took
• hianchieu killing the illutrious Liantus that defended it, that the famous Atragant yeelded himelf together with everall Townes to his Majety, that Lucimon eeing all his retreates lot, all his hopes blated, and Polianis crowned King, with a penitent humility aught his grace and ubmitted to his Scepter, that by this meanes a generall peace was retored to China, and in fine that the amorous intercoure between me and Floria, which had been all this while dying but had made everall efforts to recover it elf, they proving no more than blazes before the going out of the Candle, was by the end of the War wholly extinct.

Alcidor having brought his narration to a period, and the Company having paid him their thanks, I have been informed, aid Dorame to him, that your love did not die when it left Floria, but only like a Pythagorick oul pat from one to another, from Floria to Ataia, I hall therefore account myelf very much in your debt if you will relate to us what were the tranactions of it with that
beautifull wife of Certafilan. There are many reaons, Madam, returned Alcidor, which forbid me doing what you deire. But the mot remarkable of the truths which you would know, one of my freinds, deigning o to oblige me, hath faithfully enough penned down. This manucript if you think it worth your time to examine, I hall willingly put into your hands. Therewith he pulled out of his pocket and preented to her a little book of which the cover was Crimon velvet embroidered with Gold and adorned with Pearls and Cyphers. Having took it, vewed its outide, opened it, found the pourtraitures of Alcidor and Ataia on the firt and econd pages, and lookt awhile upon them, he gave it to Melian intreating him to read it to them, and he read it in thee words.

div.head: The Hitory of the Loves of Alcidor and Ataia.
div.p:
ALcidor being returned to Paquin from Canton where he had ubdued the remaines of the confederacy, now that the fires of the civill War were wellnigh all quenched, had a fire kindled in his breat
by the beauties of Ataia which was of too much force eaily to be put out: And yet he had at firt conidering her known integrity to her husband no in couragement to hope that it would ucceed to his atisfaction. But on a udden as if ome fatality had laboured to cleere his way, Certafilan with his nice and ditemperd palate began to ditat the viits which the more gallant Courtiers made to his Lady. This folly prevailing with more and more unrulines in his pirit he at length never aw any body near her but he beleeved it was to corrupt her catity; Nor though to obey and pleae him (eeing what dieae he laboured under) he hunned all the Company which he thought he might upect, grew he ever the more ober, but o interpreted all her actions to his fanie that there was not the leat and mot potles of them with which he found not fault. Wholly governed with which frenzy he retrenched the uage of thoe repects which he had been wont to pay her and mot unworthily loaded her with abues which it was impoible for her long to bear. She notwithtanding practied all the weet meanes that her dicretion was able to ugget to her to put him in a better mind; but intead of being thereby brought back to
reaon he was exaperated higher and grew more and more inupportable. Her teares which one would have thought able to melt cruelty it elf rather increat than allaied his rage and her jut complaints erved to no better effect than to make him vomit a thouand contumelies againt her honor. Nor were her own indeavors to appeae him fruitles only but the Kings alo, who having knowledge of his madnes ued what remedies he judged requiite for his cure, but without effecting it. During this ferall perecution of Ataia, Alcidor went every day to ee her without her perecutor being able to hinder it, it being in the lodgings of Feonice and in the preence of Polianis that he viited her; and as often as he aw her he made her ee that he was as deeply concerned in her ufferings as he was herelf. She again every day drunke in uch a ene both of his ympathy and accomplihments as with the aitance of Certafilan's outrages rendred this latter les and les and that former more and more agreeable to her. He proceded to manage time and his actions o advantageouly to his purpoe that he no longer regarded him but as one regards thoe whom one incerely likes. She was not contented but when he was with her, nor dicontented
but when he was from her. She felt emotions and attempts which he had never felt before; by which dicerning that Love was urprizing her heart he imploied all her trength to defend it, but he notwithtanding all made himelf Mater of it. Perceiving herelf conquered, ince thou findet it in vaine, aid he to her elfe, to oppoe the will of Love, of whom all the world holds in fee, rebell no more Ataia. Who can with common charity blame thee, becaue thou ubmittet to a puiance which dipoes of all as it lits, and becaue thy affections lacquey no longer after a Mater who hath mot barbarouly handled them, but run to one whoe qualities are all irreitably magneticke, and who, if any body, is mot likely to protect and releeve thee? who indeed if not Alcidor is able to bring Certafilan into order. But, alas, by what meanes hould he do it? for him to peak to him in my defence what is it but to augment his jealouy? And though it may be he dares not aault him, may he not till revenge himelf upon me, a woman who have nothing but ighs and teares for my armes againt him? But imagine, Ataia, that Alcidor is able to upercede his oppreion of me, who hath told thee that he will be at
the paines to go about it? The repects indeed which he renders thee eem to be uch as would aure thee of it, but conider he renders the like to all Ladies, and had he a particular kindnes for thee he would not urely have been untill this houre to let thee know it, every thing having favoured uch a deign. No, no it is impoible that a great fire hould lye o long under its cinders without appearing more or les; It would therefore be a great vanity in thee to perwade thyelf there is any uch in his breat for the. The Princes Floria indeed hath too much empire in her attractions to uffer him to ubject himelf to any other.

While Ataia was dicouring thus with herelfe about Alcidor, he was at the ame time reolving with himelft to declare to her his paion, and conidering that he had not liberty to do it by word of mouth by reaon that Certafilan had eyes and eares every where to watch her, he concluded to make a letter his proxie. Accordingly he without any farther demurre drew his thoughts on paper, ealed it up and made himelf his meenger to carry it to her. He found her in her Siter Feonice's Chamber, he being newly come in to it, out of her cloet where he had been ome while hut
up bemoaning her elf, but Certafilan followed him in at the heels, and when they could have wiht him in the remotet part of the world debarred them by his Company from having any particular ociety. He kept his eyes uch trict entinells upon them both that they could hardly teal a few glances one of another, much les could they entertain one another as they deired. But after a while as if on purpoe to dres a party againt him, Feonice et upon him with o hot a charge for his untowardnes to her Siter, that he could intend nothing but how to defend himelf againt her. Oberving which opportunity Alcidor offerd his letter to the hand of Ataia, and he civilly receiving it lipt it into her pocket. Feonice till held Certafilan to task with her remontrances of his fault, and he was o earnet in them and thought them o equitable that, though Ataia made frequent ignes to her to deit, he would not be taken off till the Criminall having pent all the weak excues which he could forge, aid nothing more but what made her hope he intended to be better for the future, though as it afterwards appeared he at the ame time reolved to be wore, with a very killfull diimulation laying a contraint upon his humor to hide
his deign. Hardly had Feonice at down from her action but Polianis came into the Chamber; whereupon Certafilan fearing a evere reprehenion from him alo made hat away, nor was he topt by the King who had at that time other thoughts in his mind. Certafilan gone, his Lady pretending herelf not well withdrew into her Chamber; Alcidor offerd to lead her, but he civilly refued it, and he pret it not gueing he went to read what he had given her. And he guet right; for having walkt three or four turnes in her Chamber among her women he went into her Cloet, and having hut herelf in opened the letter and read in it thee contents.

div.head: Alcidor to Ataia.
div.p:
I Have ighed o long for what you uffer and with what I uffer my elf that I can no longer conceale it from you. I have had a far deeper ene of your troubles than if I had endured them myelf. And it is not meerly a compaionate temper that hath bred this ene in me but a paionate Love. I contracted this Love at the firt ight of you, it hath ever ince increat by degrees, and it is now grown of too large a dimenion and violence to bee kept hid.
Punih not my temerity ince your own beauty is the parent of it, but have ome pitty for me, who have o much for you that I hall with triumph acrifice my life to draw you from the tyranny under which you groan.

Having read this letter many times over and every time with more atisfaction than other, her husbands humor began to be alltogether indifferent to her, and for Alcidor he reckoned he could do no les than draw a kinde anwer to him and he drew this.

div.head: Ataia to Alcidor.
div.p:
MY condition is uch as permitts me not to light either the ympathy that you pretend with me, or the uccour that you offer me; the one may blunt the edge of my preures, the other may put an end to them; I therefore with thankes accept of both. But I do not withall deire that you hould hazard your life in releeving me: preerve it rather as carefully as you can, that o I may reap that benefit by it that I tand in need of, and beleive, that reckoning myelf in a good part happy by the friendhip that you aure me of, I hall eteem myelf perfectly o when I hall have it in my power to evidence
to you that I am from my heart your ervant.

Having wrapt up thee lines, notwithtanding thoe that watch't her actions he ran with them to her Siters Chamber, where he knew the King and Alcidor till were: The King when he reentred was in a particular converation with that abolute Mitres of his heart, and he went on in it. Alcidor was at ome ditance veiwing pictures in which art had o dextrouly imitated nature that things dead eemed alive and enible: but he quickly left them when he aw her appear who had reall life and ene acc • mpliht above the imitation of art, with wit, beauty and goodnes, and taking the opportunity went and confirmed to her by words of his Letter. She gave him for anwer what he had written, which having read ina corner where the King and Feonice could not ee him he with a thred of gratefull, repectfull and affectionate language tied her heart to him in a mot fat knot. She owning as much to him, they proceeded to contract their affections one to the other with mot olemne vowes of reality and cont • ncy; and in this train they were when the King called Ataia to him and askt her
if he would go along with Feonice to the waters. To this your Majetyes deires, returned he, and my Siters Company are of much more value to me than that I hould be backward either to obey the one or follow the other, provided that he to whoe humor I am ubject will grant me a licence. Beleive me, Ataia, replied the King, if that untoward man hall hereafter go about any thing againt my will I hall limit him o that he hall not be able to act but by the rule of my pleaure. There cannot indeed be found Sir, aid he againe to him, an expedient more proper to till his tyranny than to oppoe to it an augut power as is that of your Majety. Certafilan urely, inerted Alcidor, will not be o rah as to reit his Prince, who he knows reigns by jutice and clemency together, and when he hall find that injuring his Ladies vertue he enterprizes upon his overaigne's authority that undertakes her protection I do not doubt but he will out of a ene of his equity and for fear of his anger make his upicions die. We will wait to ee what he will do now, aid Polianis, and if he does well, I hall as he deerves cherih him, if ill, punih him. In the mean while, Ataia, prepare for the journey with your Siter, I hall be very
much pleaed that you accompany her, and I cannot believe that your husband can be troubled at it, when he hall know that I am o pleaed. Thoe that are ill temperd as he, Sir, aid Feonice, take occaion as well to peak againt the wills of Kings, which are regulated by ober and dicerning reaon, as of common people who act not but according to the dictates of brutih appetite, without being able to ditinguih what is good from what is bad. But I perwade myelf, aid Alcidor, that Certafilan will hereafter governe his motions with o much prudence that his Majety will not be put to any trouble to reforme them.

They thus dicouring for a while together, then the King reuming a particular conference with Feonice, and by favour of that occaion Alcidor doing the like with her Siter, Certafilan in the mean time, mierably rackt himelf, feares that the Letter was reolving his wife to practies againt him, and to augment his inquietudes he apprehended that if he went preently to interrupt them the King would (not without being offended) dicover the dieae with which his pirit laboured, if he waited till the King was gone that Alcidor would in the intervall bring his wife to his will. Wandring
about in this perplexity he met two Magitrates, freinds of his, who according to the order that they had received were going to wait upon the King at Feonice's Lodgings: Them he went a long with thither, without hewing any thing of his trouble, and before the King and his Company appeared, in a gaines of temper which gave them thoughts of him very different from what they had lately had; Polianis deiring of him that his wife might the day following beare her Siter Company to the Waters he expret a free and cheerefull conent; he dicourt with Alcidor as if he had had no other fany of him but as of his dearet freind; he hewed to Ataia as kind regards as when they were firt married. And thee he continued to her not only while the King was preent (who after he had beene a little in private with Feonice bad her and her Siter fare well. Alcidor doing the like and attending upon him) but alo till he went away, which he did the next morning, having a plendid equipage provided by him for her journey.

About ixe dayes after the two Siters were come to the Waters, Ataia fell trangely ad without being able to give any reaon why he was o. While he was domineered
by which humor, and Feonice was endeavouring to awage it, word was brought her that a lacquey deired to peak with her. She commanding him to be brought to her with hopes to find him Alcidor's, he appeared in a livery which told her to her greife he was not, and preented a Letter to her, with which, when he had opend it he was thus accoted.

div.head: Floras to Ataia.
div.p: CErtafilan takes me for one of the mot wicked men in the world, but I hall let you ee that his wickednes is far greater than mine. I have received intructions from him eight dayes hence to carry you ecretly to one of his houes, where he reolves to keep you prioner all your life. I give you notice of it to the end that you may prevent it, and I withall intreate you to keep it ecret. It is a glory to hun the precipice into which an enemy would make one fall: think therefore at preent both of comforting and of delivering yourelf and hereafter when you hall command me I hall entertaine y • u more at large with the tory.

As Ataia read thee lines he often turned pale and red by udden viciitudes. Seeing
which without doubt, my Siter, aid Feonice to her, you have a ubject of affliction in what you read. The newes (alas!) which I have ent me, replied
• taia, are ufficient to alarum and ditract a pirit much more fortified than mine; read them, my deare Siter, and ee if it is without caue that I am troubled. Feonice having read what he hewed her, Treacherous and Salvage man together, cried he, can heaven know thy pernicious baenes and not abis thee? What hath Ataia done to thee that thou houldt thus unworthily treat her? It is neceary, my • iter, adjoined he, not only to beleive Floras, but at whatoever rate to deliver yourelf from Certafilan. I now ee, reumed Ataia, that the melancholy with which I have been oppret, but of which I could not tell you the reaon was an augury of the evills which this in humane brewes againt me, and indeed we often have adnees, which though we know not the ground nor meaning of, are omens of misfortunes which too nearely (though darkely) hang over our head. But there is a remedy for thoe that are prepared for you, aid Feonice; Floras hath befreinded you with the meanes of avoiding them; Let us therefore retire into your Cloet, there to
contrive your afety. Entered there Ataia fell onweeping as if he had had an intention to drown her life in her Teares: but her Siter at length prevailing with her to dry her eyes to conider of what he had to do, I think it requiite, aid he to her, that you hould firt of all make anwer to Floras, and then when we have dimit his man, we will end advertiement to the King of Certafilans purpoes. You know the compaionate noblenes of his pirit, and what an enemy he is to uch as are treacherous. You neede not therefore doubt but he will quickly retrain if not punih the wickednes of that wild beat your Husband. I cannot but acknowledge, returned Ataia to her, that Polianis is the mot excellent Monarch in the world, and that he interets himelf therefore alo in the concernements of my fortune becaue I am your Siter. But will not this be to be allwayes a prioner to tay with them whom he hall appoint to hinder Certafilan from imprioning me? I have a ecret which I mut no longer conceal from you, Alcidor loves me, and that (if I do not mitake by being over-credelous) in uch a degree that there is nothing of difficulty which can affright him or will hold him back from uccouring me.

If you are certaine of Alcidors affection, replied Feonice, you need not be affraid of Certafilans cruelty: but what evidences have you of it and ince when was it born? ee the tetimonies, returned Ataia, giving her Alcidors Letter, after which I think I cannot lawfully call his love in quetion: ee alo the returne which I have made to it, added he, giving her a copy of her anwer to him. Feonice having perued them, Ataia made a relation to her of what had pat between them, which done, conidering all, aid Feonice, I no longer doubt that Alcidor loves you and therefore I no longer apprehend that your condition is deperate. And as to your love of him a woman barbarouly handled as you have been by one bound to ue you with all imaginable weetenes as is Certafilan, cannot be blamed for eeking arefuge againt that barbarime. One allwayes lookes with pitty upon thoe women who do nothing that may eem dihonorable but what abolute neceity contraines them to, and though it be a mot reproacheable buines to deceive a good husband, it is, if an offence, a very pardonable one, to free ones elf from the perecution of a bad one. I reckon indeed, replied Ataia, that if in this preent treight wherein I am againt my
will ingaged I take any coure that hall obcure my vertue and bring it into quetion, the reall fault will be his who by his intolerable uage of me forces me to it. With thee words the Teares coming apace in her eyes Feonice to give a top to them put her upon drawing an anwer to Floras, which he did to his effect.

div.head: Ataia to Floras.
div.p: HAd you never given any other proofes of your generoity than what you have now given me, they are ufficient to make me eteem you one of the mot generous men in the world. He whom Certafilan hath choen to execute his cruelty upon me is he who delivers me from it, than which nothing can be more noble, nothing more obliging. Such a ene of it hath my Siter, and he will let you ee that he hath: much more have I, and I hall allwayes indeavor by my due acknowledgements of your goodnes to tetify to you that Ataia is though an unfortunate yet not an ingrate.

Feonice approoving this letter Ataia ealed it and delivered it to the lacquey of Floras with a larges which abundantly rewarded his paines. The Meenger gone, this
is not all, my Siter, aid Feonice, now you have the quill in your hand write alo to your Alcidor and ummon him to keep his promie of aiting you; I doubt not but we hall have him here with us oon after he knowes that you have need of him. I hall try, replied Ataia, what influence my words can have upon him, and therewith thus et down her mind.

div.head: Ataia to Alcidor.
div.p: I Am upon the point of being undone if you come not quickly to me to oppoe your charitable power to the unjut rage of Certafilan. A few dayes hence he intends to have me conveighed to a perpetuall prion: it is from the peron who is to carry me away that I have received the favorable notice of it. Though my merit cannot, yet may my miery at this time induce you to act for my contentment. All is aid when Ataia conjures you to do it by the affection that you pretend to beare her.

Ataia putting this letter into her Gentleman's hands, he put it by point of day the next morning into Alcidors, and Alcidor had no ooner read it, but, I have now, aid he to himelf, got into my power uch an
opportunity as I have often wiht for of letting Ataia ee, that I place my happines in erving her, that I prize my own life les than her liberty, and that having love for my Commander there is nothing too hard for me (to attempt at leat if not) to break through in her Quarrell. Conidering therefore, proceeded he, that nothing is more prejudiciall to buines of moment than remienes, and that Feonice being of our party will render Polianis alo of it, let us make hate to her who with o much weetnes and earnetnes calls us. What he aid he made good, mounting preently on horsback with halfe a core men in whom he had confidence, and arriving with the two Siters jut when they were preparing for bed, not without filling them with atonihment at his diligence and contentment at his preence. You are come, Sir, aid Feonice to him, (while Ataia recollected her cattered enes,) to uccor my Siter againt her Husband who goes about to murder her with affliction; I very much reent my elf your debtor for it, and poibly I hall not be o unhappy but I hall have the power one day of giving you proof of my reentment together with her. I have, Madam, replied Alcidor to her, nor power, nor courage nor
freinds nor interet which I will not gladly imploy in the ervice of your Siter who deerves no les at the hands of all that know her. But the buines being of action bare words are unprofitable as which ought to have effects for their warrant. What therefore is there requiite to be done, Madam, for this Lady whom I ee wholly eized with the apprehenion which he hath of falling into the hands of her enemy. It is with the pleaure which I have with eeing you, aid he preently to him, that I am thus extaied, and by that and by the liberty and confidence with which I have ummoned you to my aitance you my eayly judge in what eteem you are with me. If we are by common humanity, Madam, returned Alcidor to her, bound to uccor thoe whom we know not, as we without quetion are, it is a farr greater tye which I have upon me to do all that lies in my power for you who are the oul of my oul, and if I think not too fondly of myelf, that zeal which I have for your ecurity will, when you have told me what you judge itting to be done for it, impower me to do it o happyly that I make no doubt but you hall oon ee Certafilan's purpoes converted into moke. Alcidor, replied Ataia to him, who knowes all the
arts of War, who hath been ued to break quadrons and force Towns, who found out plenty of tratagems to upport the league, cannot urely want an expedient to deliver Ataia from Certafilan. I depended upon your contrivance as well as execution. Say therefore what coure you judge in my condition convenient to beteered. Only firt, adjoined he, giving him the letter of Floras, reade the information which hath been ent me of my condition. Alcidor having read the letter a conulation was held, of which the reult was that Ataia hould put herelf in a pages habit that o, as Alcidor told her, he who was worthy to command the greatet Kings of the earth might in that garbe of ervitude avoide the danger of being known, and under that diguie, the covert of the night and Alcidors conduct retire to a freinds houe, there to lye hid till the King having notice of what was intended againt her hould, as they made no quetion but he would, take order for her afety. Accordingly Alcidor preenting to her a page's habit which he had for the purpoe brought with him, he dret herelf in it, and in this dres her beauty was o far from loing any of its power that love who performed the cheif part in this act took advantage
by it to trike the Cavaleir anew, and he trucke him with o much force that he tood gazing upon her without being able to peak a word. Feonice taking notice of it, if he from whom you are to defend my Siter meets you, Sir, aid he to him, and you turn as voide of ene then as you appear now I may lay any wager that he is lot and am ure to winne. But atonih your elf no farther to ee her unhappines compell her thus to habit her elf. If you was capable of remarking, Madam, replied Alcidor to her that which Love makes me take notice of in this faire Queene of his Empire you would have your peech and judgment left you as little it may be as I have had. Certafilan himelf could not with all the hard and feirce thoughts that he hath for her conider her in this poture but he would have ome mild and tender ones mixt with them. This is but to trifle and make port with my mieery, and we have at preent omething ele to minde aid Ataia, and therewith fell on weeping, and Feonice together with her. But Alcidor to take them of from that ad exercie obliged them to bid one another farewell, led Ataia to her hore, helpt her up and pat away with her.

The Summer eaon and the light of the
Moon making it pleaant travailing Alcidor renderd it more pleaant to Astaia by entertaining her with very taking dicoures, and to himelf by conidering her feminine graces in her maculine habit. One thing which they both pleaed themelves with was that their journey was known to nobody but thoe to whom they were willing it hould be known, but here in they were deceived.

Certafilan had ent to the Waters to be a py over his wife's carriage one Berlin, and he by counterfeiting the fool, had o eay at acces into the Lodgings of Feonice and Ataia that there was carce any thing done there which he had not opportunity of being acquainted with. This ubtle agent eeing Alcidor, arrive and knowing the upicio ••
which Certafilan had of him, with a vigilance which was mot artificially diemble oberved all tranactions and by that mean (the Ladies and Alcidor uing no cautio •
againt him becaue as they thought him voi •
of apprehenion) heard the greatet part <>
what they aid, and particularly what way they would take to gaine their retreat. With this intelligence he flew to Certafilan, Certailan again flew whither he directed him with a troop of his freinds and ervants. Bu •
whatoever diligence he ued, and he ued all that he could, he could not meet with thee whom he aught for.

Some hunters who had firt een in armes Alcidor and his Company eeing again Certafilan and his, not knowing who they were nor with what intention they were abroad, carried notice of it to the King. The King dipatching troops in earch of them, ome of them in the inquet met with Berlin who had lot his way in a Wood. Berlin informing them what the buines was, they carried him to the King. The King hearing his tory, though he diliked the action of Alcidor as knocking againt his authority, he nevertheles commanded that Emiary of Certafilan and thoe that had taken him upon perill of their lifes to peak nothing of it.

As they withdrew from his preence with this order Certafilan enterd it and in a mot pittyfull fahion applying himelf to him, ee me here, Great Prince, aid he, to demand jutice againt Alcidor for his egregious. Enterprize in carrying away my wife from the place whither your appointment ent her to keep her Siter company. You are more jut than not to chatie this audacious undertaker who at the ame time braves your authority and ruines the honor of
one of your mot faithfull ervants. I come now from eeking him, and could I have found him I would have made him bear upon the feild the revenge of the offence that he hath done me. Though by your own confeion, Certafilan, returned Polianis to him, you demand not jutice of me but becaue you cannot execute it yourelf, I have, notwithtanding that, a due compaion of your trouble. You had done well if as oon as you knew what Alcidor had done you had intead of arming you and going abroad with a party to et upon him in my forret & kill him at the feet of your judge and his, came and complained to me of him. You know I uppoe how your equipage hath alarumed me, and made me, leat my own peron hould be aimed at, guard myelf in a more than ordinary manner. But be patient and you hall ee that I am King to animadvert upon thoe that are inolent. See withall, added he, what it is to incene wives, and the alary that one receives for upecting foolihly their fidelity. Without quetion it is Ataia's ene of the old indignities that you have heaped upon her and her feares that you would load her farther with new ones that have moved her thus to take her flight from you. Did you not
know that I am acquainted with a part of your capricious and frantick carriage towards her, I hould not at preent put you in mind of it. The care that I have taken to reform it may well make you remember the little account that you have made of my remontrances and deires. How of • e • too hath Feonice oberly reproved you <> thoe furious humors with which you have made her Siter weary of her life without being able to do any good upon you. Ataia would be much more blameable than he is, had he not o much caue to complain of you as he hath, and Alcidor would be far more culpable than he is, if you had not given him a very pecious pretext with which to excue himelf. Not that I approve enormous actions: time will hew you that I very well know to correct and curbe the rahnes of thoe who enterprize more than they ought in my dominion, where I would have not vice but vertue bear way: I have nothing of good reaon, Sir, aid Certafilan, where with to purge myelf of the fault with which you charge me. I freely confes I am in a high degree guilty both of direpect to your Majety and of inhumanity to Ataia: when I diobeyed you, I had lot my reaon, when I treated her ill, I was madde, and
when I armed myelf and my freinds to dedetroy Alcidor, my trouble made me forget my duty and think of nothing but revenge. Pardon me, Sir, for what is pat, and for what is to come, I hall o change my temper that neither your Majety hall have occaion to reprove me for my capricious and franticke carriage towards Ataia, nor Feonice for my furious humor. But to give proof of what I ay, where is now Ataia? She is raviht from me, Sit, and it is from your jutice that I wait for reparation of the injury. If Ataia, Certafilan, aid the King to him, hath caued herelf to be carried away, it is not to ruine either her own honor or yours; her vertue forbids any thing bad to be upected of her, and you well know he hath not gone away but to warrant herelf from the afflictions which he apprehended you would lay upon her afreh. Retire therefore without any diorder, and leave me to manage her return and the whole affair; I will labour both for your contentment and of all that are concerned.

Certafilan in obedience to what the King aid withdrawing, better atisfied than he hoped to be, was no ooner come into his doors but Floras came to him, expret a very
affectionate regret for his Ladies flight, and offerd to find her out whereoever he was and to carry her to whatoever place he hould appoint. Beleeving • he pake from his heart, he heartyly thankt him, but withall told him that he was now o far remote from any uch purpoe as he before deired him to ait him in, that he had no longer any upicion of his wife, and that, the King having promied to reconcile them, he made no quetion but what had pat, though it eemed to be very much to his detrim • nt, would turn as much to his benefit.

While Certafilan was thus growing convert from his jealouy, though he who had been the object of it little thought of his change, yet having reached her retreat in which he aw he was out of danger of the tormenting effects of that his raging humor, knowing alo that he had in Feonice a better econd with the King than that he needed fear his anger, experimenting beides in the company of Alcidor the difference between kind repects and barbarous indignities he relaxed her mind, tied up as it had been to a diet of orrow, to feed at large upon delight. Alcidor alo made much of the liberty which he had of her ociety and congratulated himelf in it as a mot blet man. But
yet amidt thee inchanting weetnees they both of them had o much conideration that Alcidor by Ataia's approbation left her the next morning and went to the King to give him an account of what they had done. Which being performed, and the King having read the letter of Floras to Ataia, it is by this, aid he to Alcidor holding it in his hand, what we hall till the complaints of Certafilan, who yeterday demanded jutice of me againt you. I uppoe Floras will not want the courage to maintain to his face that not being able to execute what he deired without an odious baenes he thought himelf bound by the Laws of humanity to give notice of it to her againt whom it was intended. I will therefore in your jutification end for him and ingage him publickly to own himelf the author of what you have been the agent. Your Majety, replied Alcidor, will (I make no quetion) bring the affaire to uch an issue that the vertue of Ataia, the honety of Floras and my fidelity hall lie under no ill name. He had carce aid o when Floras came into the Chamber, whom the King as oon as he aw him asking what brought him thither o early he anwerd, the ervice that he owed his Majety. But how, aid the King, can I
beleive them my ervants who league themelves with Certafilan to carry on his tyranny over his wife altogether contrary to my will. If your Majety, returned Floras, will be pleaed to let my peak for my elf I make no quetion but I hall o fully clear my innocence in that which you accue me of; that you will deigne me intead of your disfavor your approbation. Trouble not yourelf Floras, replied the King, you may by this ee (therewith he hewed him his letter to Ataia) that my accuation of you is only feined. But it is requiite that you maintain before me to the face of Certafilan that he deired you to be confederate and executioner of that detetable peice of violence upon his wife of carrying her to the place which he intended to make her jayle, and that having a horror of it you, as you thought yourelf in honor bound, dicovered the contrivance to her. Your Majety, aid Floras, requires no more of me than what truth, common equity and my own credit render my duty, and what I am therefore ready with all my heart to do. Certafilan will not, I am ure, deny that the evening before his wife went with her Siter to the Waters carrying me into your Majety's garden he there told me that he was reolved
to hut her up and keep her in Cloe imprionment all her life, dicoverd to me the plott that he had laid to effect it, and conjured me to be the Conductor of it, that which I promied him to be though at the ame time I determined the contrary. Hearing him ay o, the King ent a page for Certafilan; who preently coming allmot out of breath with hate, oh Certafilan, aid the King to him, here is Alcidor now againt whom you yeterday demanded jutice of me; tell me therefore if you are in the ame mind to day. The offence that he had done me, Sir, replied Certaiflan, is greater by much than that unles I am unenible I hould eaily forget it or pas it by. To this Alcidor having his mouth open to repart, If you think, Certafilan, aid the King, that in having delivered Ataia from your ugly and unufferable oppreion Alcidor hath committed a great offence, you mut eek ele where to have him puniht than of me, and perwade me to chatie myelf. It was indeed by my order that he conveighd away your wife whom I knew Floras who is here preent was by your order to carry away, to make her mierable all her life. I would not yeterday tell you this becaue I expected that you would of yourelf confes
your fault; but finding you till in the mind to perit in it, I would have you know that Kings have intelligences which their people have not. Hear Floras peak againt you, he is a wittnes whom you cannot refue. Preently Floras offering to convict him, ee, Certafilan, proceeded the King, the Letter which hath dicoverd your conpiracy, and obliged me to take into my protection the deare Siter of Feonice, and give Alcidor command to carry her away. Certafilan having read the Letter with the name of Floras to it, Jut heavens, cried he, what means you have to take vengeance on the wicked, cauing them to be detected by by the ame perons whom they would render partians of their wickednes. I ee, Sir, added he, that he who I expected would have favoured my enterprize, hath accued me of it: but I am o far from taking it ill at his hands that he hath ued me thus, that I very much eteem him for it, knowing that he hath herein been a true freind as well to my happines as to his own honor. I confes, repent, renounce my bruitihnes towards Ataia, and I will no more be governed with that madnes which hath hitherto made me continually ee things otherwie than they have really been. Hearing
him in this train, mens hearts, aid Polianis, do ometimes change on a udden, but that Certafilan whom all my Court have for his uage of his wife reckoned not much better than a alvage beat hould in a moment become humane and tractable is a wonder which will very hardly gain beleif. I hall nothwithtanding take your word and I hall indeavor alo to bring your wife to do the ame and to make you freinds. For a prologue to which reconciliation between you and her, I mut at preent have one made between you and Alcidor; oppoe my will, neither of you. I am ready, Sir, aid Alcidor, to give Certafilan tetimony that I have a erious deire to erve him. And I, aid Certafilan, am ready to make it appear that I cordially honor Alcidor. Many more expreions of amity ued Certafilan to Alcidor, and Alcidor to Certafilan; many alo ued Certafilan and Floras to one another. In the interim of which lat, the King drawing Alcidor aide askt him, if it was not advieable that Ataia hould be preently brought back to Certafilan. To this, that he might impede the union which he feared would impede his loves, your Majety, anwered he, may undertake whatoever you think good, and I acknowledge one cannot
do better than rejoin thee divided pirits, but I withall know that Certafilan's acted and intended inhumanities have o irritated his Lady againt him that he can carce endure to hear his name; much les will he endure quickly to returne to his peron. His brutall unkindenes hath newly forced her to eek her afety in running away from him, it cannot be therefore expected that he hould uddenly trut herelf again with him. For if he is of a weet dipoition he is alo enible of abues. There is reaon, Alcidor, aid the King, in what you ay: It is indeed neceary both that he hould undergo pennance for what he hath done, and that he hould receive atisfaction for what he had ufferd. He hall not therefore come near her till he hath appeaed her. But that he may have no occaion of peaking or thinking ill of her abence and that all Kings may go according to decency, I would have her leave the place where he is, and put herelf with the Religious of whom your Kinwoman is the uperiour.

The King, who though he had a harp ingeny to peirce into the myteries of love perceived nothing of Alcidor's towards Ataia, having thus concluded with him about the dipoing of her as if he had had a mind
to furnih him with meanes of eeing her without exception. Her husband coming to him, your Majety, aid he, I hope quetions not my reolution of relaping no more into my old dieae; permit me therefore I beeech you to have before my eyes her whom I have mot unjutly tormented but without whom I cannot now live but in torment myelf. Conidering the animoities which you have raied in her, returned the King to him, and the condition into which you have driven her, it would be plain folly to imagin that he hould be eaily bent and retrived to your will. She is not retired from the world to be willing to convere o oon again with men, epecially with him who hath given her uch arguments of ditruting him as you have done. My Counell therefore to you is that uffering her to live with her regret for a time among that vertuous troop whither he hath withdrawn herelf you let her know your repentance by letters, and by promiing her a uage to come as kind as what is pat hath been harh, you endeavor to make her loe that grudge with which her tomach boiles againt you. This I beleive to be the bet expedient that you can ue to retore you with her, and I will withall deire Feonice
as oon as he returnes to advance your reconciliation the quickliet that he can. That I mut not preently have her company, anwered Certafilan, is an infelicity which I know not how to undergo; but I hall, all that I am able, inforce myelf to be patient under it, knowing myelf to be the caue of it, and I will draw from my afflicted heart the mot moving and effectuall lines that I can to procure my peace with her. I would have no other but Floras deliver them to her, aid the King, for the ight of him will I beleive be very acceptable to her, ince it was by his means that he knew and diappointed your intentions of immuring her. Floras peaking himelf very deirous of the ervice Certafilan preently took him to his Chamber and there wrot this letter before him.

div.head: Certafilan to Ataia.
div.p:
YOu are no more to fear the furious tranports of Certafilan; the King, Alcidor and Floras know that I have as affectionate deires of making your honor hine as ever my uage of you hath been cruell with which I have gone about to darken it. Remember therefore no more my outrages unles it be to repreent to
your elf the greife which I have for making you uffer them, but permit me to come to you in the Cloiter where Alcidor hath told me you have ettled your new abode. He and I am freinds, and I hall allwayes eteem myelf redeuable to Floras for the advie that he gave you. Judge therefore if I conider not my midemeanors with a penitent hame and horror.

Certafilan having after he had read this Letter to Floras committed it to his charge, he and Alcidor went together with it to Ataia. In the Court of whoe retreat they and Feonice very happily arriving together, he contained not her elf a minute after he had notice of it, but intantly flew from her Chamber to receive them. The firt ceremonies of meeting being done, Floras preented to her the Letter which he had in trut. Which he having read firt to herelf, then aloud, and Floras and Alcidor having related what had pat between the King, Certafilan and themelves he expret a joy which overflowed the banks of her uuall moderation, and he acknowledged herelf debtor to both of them with a tream of thanks which though they et themelves againt it bare them away with it. She beides as oon as he had opportunity declared
to Alcidor that he was therefore tranported with the change of Certafilan becaue he hoped that they two might by that means keep an unobtructed and an unupected correpondency. They indeed both of them watched all opportunities and made the bet of them to give one another tetimonies of an ardent affection, and there was nothing wanting to them but a full liberty of doing o to complet the weetne • es of the preent ociety. But to Feonice there was wanting the preence and carees of Polianis: with him he thought long to be; but he was obliged by his deires of which Alcidor was the meenger to her, before he took her way to him to ee her Siter afe at the Religious houe where he had appointed he hould tay. Thither therefore they all after two dayes conducted her, and there after two or three houres they left her, he having firt written and committed to the care of Floras the enueing Letter.

div.head: Ataia to Certafilan.
div.p:
I Receive ome comfort a midt my mieries by knowing that you are troubled for making me endure them, but I cannot loe my ene of the barbarounes with which you have made
me endure them. It is againt that you know that I have been contrained, eeing what little repect you bore to the royall manion, to take anctuary in a religious one. Here, having conulted pirits to whom my interets are very dear, I am advied to pas ome months to gain freh trength with which to erve myelf if you hall go about again to make me a ufferer, and hence I hall then come, and not till then, when I hall be well aured that you will have no more deigne of making me your lave who am your wife and of detroying me whom you ought to Cherih.

The prudent trutee of thee lines carrying them firt to the King, then to him to whom they were directed, with the cheme in which he repreented to him all things concerning his Lady at the ame time, whetted his deires of recovering her company and workt him without any peevihnes to ubmit to her determination of taying a while from him. The King, Certafilan carrying the Letter to him, after he had read it the econd time as if it had been the firt, econded what Floras had aid to him and by the comment which he made upon Ataia's text abolutely convinced him that for her to abent herelf for a while from him was no
more than what he owed to her innocence and to her repoe, and that for him after he had driven her away from him to force her to returne to him before he thought it convenient, was to perit in his merciles perecution of her, not to repent of it. Notwithtanding this, his fond appetite of having her again with him growing every houre more and more retlely eager, he was continually oliciting the King, Feonice, Floras and Alcidor to be the charitable authors of procuring and hatening it, and the three former were erious in advancing what he ued for; Alcidor alo made hews of favouring it as much as any, but having liberty where he was of eeing her every day without diturbance, he clancularly et all the engines of his wit on work to keep her there: and by his eluive arts he retarded her returne to Certafilan for a month without either the King knowing any thing of their amorous converes or Certafilan dicovering o much as the cene where they were acted. But at length the King making oath to that diconolate and importunate husband that he would within eight dayes bring her back into his armes, and ending her Siter to her to effect it, he remontrated firt to himelf and then to her, that to keep the Kings favor,
to pererve her honor and happines, and dextrouly to conduct the caball of their loves it was neceary he hould rejoin herelf with him to whom the Laws had tied her and whoe remores called her back to him. To this his advie (they having ratified their affections to one another with freh and trong protetations of contancy) and to her Siters perwaions he reigned herelf and they went together the next morning to Paquin.

Here he had not been many hours before word was ent of it to Certafilan, but this notice withall that he would never more cohabit with him unles he would wear before the King, Feonice, Alcidor, and Floras that he would never more abue her. To this he returning anwer that he had not o wholly lot his reaon as to refue to redeem his happines upon uch eay and honourable tearmes: an interveiw was orderd and effected, and he before the wittnees that he deired made Oath to to her, that his carriage towards her for the time to come hould be a perfect recantation of what was pat and an unblotted Coppy of all the offices of love. He having by thee and other unquetionable tetimonies of his reformation obliged her to be reconceiled to him, and he having declared
that he was willing to be o, The King put her into his hands with a mot binding exhortation to him to be as good as his word. Which done, and he having kit her with a kind of adoration before Polianis, he carried her to a houe which he had prepared for her reception, and there the next day banqueted Feonice Alcidor and Floras with a mot magnificent kindenes.

He in the equcle of this never tirred from her, but was continually paying her the repects not only of a fond husband but of a upertitious votary, and after a while that he might enjoy her beloved ociety at quiet he with her conent carried her into the Countrey and there fettled their habitation. This change of their abode is beleived to have put an end to the loves between Ataia and Alcidor, in her abence another Lady taking poeion of his heart: but having of this no clear knowledge I chooe to peak of it not at all rather than not ufficiently.

Melian having done reading and reigned the book, and the Company having thankt Alcidor for the ue of it, Alcidor, aid Dorame, would be yet more obliging, if he would recount to us thoe his following loves which the writer ayes he was not well
enough acquainted with. You will it may be, replied Alcidor when you have heard all, name me a very incontant man; but there is nothing in the world beides your diaffection which I would not cheerfully undertake or undergo to atisfy you. I am therefore ready to do that which you deire. To this Dorame making no other anwer but by dipoing herelf to an attention he uccinctly related what had pat between him and Carmelia, what alo between him and Felisbea, carefully reerving whatoever might eem to knock againt the honor of either of them.

His narrative concluded, you cannot think, aid Dorame to him, that Felisbea died for any thing ele but for your neglects, and I cannot but wonder that her beauty being very taking, her pirit accompliht and her quality honourable you would not think of marrying her. I acknowledge, returned Alcidor to her, that the birth and perfections of that young Lady were uch as challenged for her a husband of a far higher forme than Alcidor; but there are certain fatalities which rule the coure of our lifes, o that we act not but according to their precriptions. What was the caue of Felibea's death I know not, but the reaon why I was
not in love with her without doubt was becaue my detiny reerved me to be in love with the incomparable Dorame. It is for the love and ervice of you, Madam, continued he that I was born and that I am to live: my paion for you is not of the number of thoe that are ruined by time; and this I reckon I can vow before no perons better than before thee your nearet relations, and I vow it with o incere an a • dor that I am ready to igne it with whatoever there is that is dearet to me. Hearing thee words come from him, we have reaon to beleive my neice, aid Rolimon, that Alcidor peaks from his heart, and to what purpoe hould thee many ceremonies be ued where marriage is the ubtance aimed at? My opinion is that you hould make a mutuall contract of love, after which there will be no fear that any body ele hould pretend to either of you. You peak, Sir, replied Alcidor to him, like one that knows how to find the knot of uch an affaire as this in hand; And I wear, Madam, addret he himelf to Dorame, that, if you will think of no other husband but Alcidor, I will think of no other wife but Dorame. And I protet returned Dorame to him, that if you will have no other wife but Dorame, I will have no other huband
but Alcidor. He having, as oon as thoe words were out of her mouth, with a gracefull veneration kit it, they again by Melian's motion olemnely promit to marry one the other as oon as he had completed her year of widdowhood. Which tie being made and thereby that which all the Company deired as firmely ecured as could be wiht to be at preent they with a generall pleaantnes, continued convering upon that and other ubjects till they were called to upper, and after upper till the late houres commanded them to bed.
div.trailer: The End of the third Book.

div.head: The Fourth Book.
div.p:
ALcidor riing early the next morning as being kept from leeping by his thoughtfull love found that Dorame, whom he beleived yet in bed, was gotten up before him and walkt abroad. Finding her out he entertained her with what he had been entertaining herelf, his affections, and he changed not the ubject till they were interrupted by Rolimon, Melian and Vindorix who came to bidde them good morrow and farewell together. The Lovers endeavoured to retain them, but they gave them reaons for their going away which induced them to allow it. Betaking themelves therefore all together into the houe they had been but a few moments there when Meonimus arrived, and he had not been much longer there before
he told Alcidor that he mother of Almidon was about to inform againt him for the killing of her on, adviing him not to deferre getting a pardon by which to put himelf out of all danger from the Law. At this notice Alcidor was not at all diturbed, knowing that Polianis had a better opinion of him than to be quickly imprinted with a bad one or indeed to deny him any thing that he hould ask, but Dorame was very much troubled, and chooing rather to deprive herelf of her contentment in his company for a time than detain him with her when his tay might be diadvantageous to him, conjured him with all peed to make a journey to Paquin to the end that he might prevent his enemies and put himelf under covert againt their malice. This counell being backt and urged by the ret of the Company, he only taied breakfat and badde Dorame adieu. Rolimon, Melian, Vindorix and Meonimus going a long with him to his houe they all taied there that night, and the next morning parted, the three firt to go home, and Alcidor and Meonimus to Court.

Here Alcidor going to the King and reporting to him his adventures with Cartagenes and Almidon and the danger that he was in of being proecuted for their deaths, he
very graciouly gave him his pardons for both and caued them to be allowed by the Counell of twelve Auditors, the Letter which Cartagenes wrot before his death to Dorame and the tetimony of Limonides erving very happily for his jutification.

Polianis farther by the contexture of Alcidors buines undertanding that Dorame was his Mitres expret everall times to him that he was very much pleaed with it; one time in particular, there is nothing, brave Alcidor, aid he to him, which obtructs your loves, for Floria is courted in marriage by my Cozen Eridan, Ataia is lately dead, and Carmelia hath taken the hahit of a Religious: See I ay if there be any thing to keep you from puruing and injoyning your preent affections ince of your three former Mitrees there is but one of them retaining to the world, where alo he is o traightly guarded that nobody can have her Company but the Prince whom I now pake of. I am not ignorant of the Love which he hath had for you, her brother having recounted to me that which he knew of it by their Uncle, who hath many times had purpoes of ending you out of the world upon that occaion. But he now gives hopes that he will entertain that new Lover, and not only Dorilas wihes
you as well as you can deire, but Lucimon alo is diarmed of the choler which he hath had againt you, knowing that the offence which he beleived you to have committed proceeded not from you but from his neice. Thee two Princes I have made your freinds, and I would have you as oon as you can joine myrtles to your laurells o that Hymen as well as Mars may render your life glorious. The many powerfull reaons, Sir, replied Alcidor, which I had to hold Ataia in eteem while he lived render it impoible for me not be troubled for her death. If Floria is loved by Eridan and acknowledges the merit of that Prince of your blood, the ucces will be far more advantageous to her than if he had nouriht an affection for one o unworthy of her as myelf. For Carmelia I reckon that he could not have betaken herelf to an abode more convenient to regret the los of her deare Clidantus than that which he hath o agely choen. And for my own particular I have abundant obligation to your Majety for the acts of Grace which your Clemency hath granted me, without that by an exces of favor you hould procure me the good will of two Princes whoe ill will I have allwayes been apprehenive of, and as much as I could hunned
the means of provoking. If the Princes Floria hath done me the honor of tetifying ome kindnes to me, I never have abued it, nor have I ever had the temerity to apire to things contrary to reaon and my duty: and if for having before them quitted the party which they headed, they have wiht me ill, why did they betake themelves to the ame obedience that made me acknowledge you my King? Have not they been contrained to ubject themelves to the Laws of your Majety as well as to thoe of your Kingdome? You have acted, Alcidor, reumed the King, very well in every thing, and with the ervices that you have done me ince you have retored your elf to your allegiance I have o much reaon to atisfie my elf that waiting for ome better grati • ication of them I at preent make you my leiftenant of my Company of men at armes. Liantus is dead, Alcidor, purued he, and my regret for his death ufficiently declares what eteem I have for men of courage. At thee words Alcidor could • ot hinder himelf from letting fall ome teares, nor could the King forbear having ome tand in his eyes, and farther was the memory of the los of that great captain about to carry them into melancholy, when Lucimon and
Dorilas came in to them and dimit it. See the generous Alcidor, my Cozens, aid the King to them preently, love him for the ake of his valor, and for love of me; there are few of his fahion to be found in the world: we were jut now peaking of you. The King thus accoting them and Alcidor very civilly addreing himelf to them, they both imbraced him and acknowledging his high value, deired him to beleive that they had, and as long as they lived, would have a very cordiall amity for him. To which he having anwerd them what was • itting, he left them and the King together and went to his Lodging.

Come thither he wrot to Dorame an account of all his occurrencies to this lat, and particularly what was become of Floria, Ataia and Carmelia. The concluion of his Letter was an aurance of the King's approbation of their marriage and of his own peedy returne to her. Limonides was the carrier o • it.

About three dayes after Alcidor being with the King newes was brought him that the forces of Atalantus had taken Thiau by aault and Senoy by compoition, and made very ill work in the province of Xanton. Hereupon he with all peed called an
aembly in forme of the etates and caued to be levied a potent army with which to put a top to the progres of thoe invaders. But while preparations were in hand againt them, what by the imprudent willfullnes of the inhabitants who would not receive any ouldiers in garrion, and what by the menaces of ome factious, they urprized Huc • io in open day. Thither for the recovery of it the King determining within two or three dayes to march, he told Alcidor that notwithtanding his affairs of love he mut go along with him his Feild-Marhall; but withall that he might go firt and wait upon his Mitres for a few houres. Which liberty he ued with a diligence which carried him quickly to her, if the firt ight of him inpired her with joy, he quickly changed it into affliction, by telling her what a hort limit of time he had to tay with her, and what imployment the King had ingaged him in which renderd it o hort. Hearing this, to go to this eige, aid he, with a face full of trouble, is to go to be killed rather than to fight; I cannot therefore, added he, but be very much diatisfied with your going. But etting before her eyes the Kings command and the forfeiture which he hould make of his favor by not obeying it, then the
glory of the imployment and the irreparable damage which he hould contract to his honor by refuing it, perwading her alo that there was not o much danger in the expedition as he imagined and that in all probability he hould not be long before he returned, he in a good meaure leened her diatisfaction. What remained after this of the three houres which he told her he had to pend with her they made much of in proteting to one another inviolable affections, and in giving and receiving carees of which the harmles fervor and weetens made it pitty they hould be quickly broken of: But time calling him away they kit and badde adieu, not without ighes on both parts, love requiring that tribute of them.

No ooner was Alcidor returned to Paquin, but he parted from it, the King the next day marching away to invet Huchio; and there the firt task of his armes was to defeate the forces of the enemie's Field-Marhalls, and he therein performed wonders. Some dayes after the eige was fixt the gros of the beeiged Cavalry making a alley with deigne of beating up a quarter, and it being Alcidors let to command that time at the place where they came on, though he had not with him above two thirds of the Kings
Company of men at armes, and the enemies were four or five hundred Lances, he upon a low pace attended them, and toutly receiving them, performed againt them all that was poible with o mall a number. He had not indeed trength enough to keep his men from being at length beaten back; but he quickly returned with them to a econd charge, and at the intant that Polianis was dipatching uccours to him inflaming his own courage and animating his Companions fell with the impetuounes of a Whirlewinde into the enemy-quadrons, put them all in diorder, made them turn their backs, and purued them, taking and killing them, as farr as the countercarpe of the trench. To this action the King and Adratus his Leiftenant-generall, in whoe ights it was done, gave applaues which plainly fore hewed the memory of it would be immortall. Several other engagements made Alcidor with the enemy during the iege) continually throwing himelf into the mot dangerous places) and in all of them he was a very uccesfull purchaer of renown, but in one of them together with renown, he got a wound with a muquet-hot in the legg, which compelled him for awhile to lie till.

Silarmin Generall of the forces of Atalantus
after he had made many attempts to uccour the beeiged and aw he was not able to atchieve it taking his way home wards, and thereupon they in Huchio (the Indian garrion firt paing out in good order) yeelding it up to the King, he preently led his army (which was compoed of the military flower of his Kingdome) after the enemy into their Countrey: but the memory of his pat victories imprinting uch a terror upon their ouls that they feared nothing o much as that Mars of China's fury: he could by no means draw them to a battel. There indeed appeared nobody in the Feild to top his triumphant progres: but to prevent the univerall ravaging of his territories Atalantus dipatched to him propoalls of reconciliation, and to give his empire a calm he freely accepted them. Peace being re-etabliht and the armies on both ides disbanded, Polianis promit his ubjects a golden age in room of that iron one, which had o long and o adly aggreived them, and what he promit at the intant began to appear: the artit workt with ecurity, the Merchant trafficked with freedome, the Villager laboured the earth without fear, King, Prince, Lord, Gentleman, Souldier, they of holy Orders and thoe of common quality feated
themelves with thoe weetenees of repoe, pleaure, advantage, which the tumults of the word had a great while hinderd them from o much as tating, in a word all every where in China appeared with a laughing face.

Of this univeral joy Alcidor took part awhile about the King, but not with a full atisfaction: to make it full he mut ee Dorame, and not only ee her, but alo accomplih his marriage with her. The King therefore at his requet dimiing him, not without extraordinary commendations of him in the midt of his Court and other remunerations of his ervices worthy of uch a Prince, he flew a long the wayes without reting till he was with her. Being gotten again, together (not without a kind of intoxic • tion of delight at their firt meeting) they imployed their time in recounting to one another ome remarkable peices of their fortunes which they were not yet acquainted with, and particularly what had occurred to them ince their lat eparation, in dicouring of others and by name of Cloriates and Carmelia, the former of whom was as well as the latter enterd into a religious Order, in entertaining themelves as occaion and their ingenies led them, but principally in interchanging
pledges of dearnes and in deigning the order of their wedding.

They thus wearing out the year of widowhood, Alcidor the next day took hore to go wait on Rolimon, Melian, Vindorix and ome other friends, and having pent ome dayes upon that occaion he pent two at home, during which his houe had the apect of a uperbe Court with the viits which perons of Grandeur made him, and with the noble receptions which he gave them. He had here indeed abundantly enough of repect hewd him, and good company enough came in to him and was likely to do o, to have tempted him to tay longer, but love called him away, and he took the road to Dorame, having firt intreated her and his friends to be the eighth day after at her houe to ait at their hymenean rites.

The day come and thoe that were invited rendring themelves at the palace of Dorame (for o it may well be called, conidering the glories with which it honne) the illutrious pair of Lovers were joined together with ceremonies of exquiite tate; there was indeed nothing of the day which did not make it memorable, the feating, the dancing, the masking, the muicke were all intances of choice gall • ntry and magnificence, but the
fairet thing of all was the delivering up of Dorame into the hands of Alcidor by Ladies whoe beauty deerved, they hould have been lookt upon as o many Suns, but that it was obcured by that of the Bride.

What pat in the night between this excellent couple is a mytery, which to divulge would be to profane; but they appeared the next morning like uch who had been drinking to and pledging one another in thoe delights which are the prize, the recompence, the food of love. Their humor had nothing in it, but erenity; the Company therefore had nothing in it, but mirth; and to nourih it to the highet, improvement was made of all the recreations of body and pirit that were gentile and opportune. This continued eight dayes together, after which (there being a neceity that uch fetivities hould have an end, as well as a beginning) the aembly diolved and left Alcidor and Dorame to enjoy themelves by themelves.

But it was not long before Alcidor carrying Dorame to his principall Houe and there intalling her abolute Mitres of his etare, as he had done before of his heart they kept a kind of econd wedding: Company flowed in from all the neigbourhood to wih them
joy and pay them honor, and all the time of their tay was pent in little ele but in Feats, Balls, and receiving and making Viits.

There now wanted nothign to complete Alcidor's ovation, but that his Sun hould diplay her beams in the horizon of the Court. Thither therefore they went together with an equipage which made all Paquin admire it's plendor, as much occutomed as it was, to ee great things. Dorame was o radiant and her retinue o bright, that hardly could there have been imagined a train perfectly aorted to hers, had not Alcidor marched with the ame air. He indeed in this notable occaion omitted none of thoe brave things which had been born with him, and which he had all his life practiced.

Preenting themelves to the King, he entertained them with demontrations of extraordinary favor and contentment in eeing them: Staying about half an houre in his preence, the mot gallant of the Court were all the while gazing upon them with affectionate admirations: Going away, Dorilas who at the intant came in detained them a while with an accotage made up of civility.

Dorame indeed while her husband Cliidas lived was eteemed one of the fairet and mot charming Ladies of the Court; but they who knew her then, and coniderd her now, and compared what he was then, with what he was now, proclaimed her beauty & attractions doubled. In augmentation of this glory he uffered it not to make her vainly conceited, but the more he was extolled, the more humbly he demean'd herelf: Every wayes were both he and Alcidor of uch a frame as made them happy in one another. Never was correpondence more perfect, than theirs, never was contentment weeter; but this latter lated not long. Dorame after ix moons growing heavy with Child had by that means o much indipoition, that he was eldome to be een out of her bed, and Alcidor had o deep a ene of it that he was eldome to be een out of a dark humor: her illnees increat and therewith his greifs welled high. And yet amidt his wollen greifs he would have reckoned himelf in ome ort happy; if he might till have injoyed her; but to make him the mot afflicted man in the world he was by the ravenous hand of death taken away from him; he died in Child-bed together with her Child of which he could
not be delivered. Before he expired, I ee, my Alcidor, aid he to him, I mut go from you; it is the will of fate, and that is not to be oppoed by our wills. I know the kindnes that you have for me, will render my death bitter to you; but let it be with moderation that you afflict yourelf for it. I have done, my dear Alcidor, added he, I leave you, Adieu. Saying o and imbracing him he breathed out her oul upon his lips. At the intant he grew as void of motion, as if he had been as much without entiment, as the dead body, he ent not a igh after her, he made no kind of complaint, he was indeed wholly tupefied with extremity of greif: But after a while coming to himelf, he by all the great kinds of lamentation characterized himelf a mot ditret man, there is nothing of erious and maculine orrow which was not to be een in him, and he wholly abandoned himelf to be governed by it. Oh Heavens, cried he, what a treaury of beauty and virtue you have depoiled me of! why did you make her o fair, o good, to take her o overhatily away? why did you make me a little while happy in injoyning her, to render me altogether mierable in being without her for the ret of my dayes? Oh the forces of adverity which I have
to conflict with but know not how to tand againt!

If the nuptialls of Dorame were eximiouly remarkable with their refulgent and joyous, o were her funeralls with their able and lugubrious pomp; the King contributed to it his part, all the Court aited at it, there was nothing miing in it, which might erve, either for the honor of the dead, whoe quality and merit chalenged the mot tately obequies, or for a tetimony of the diconolate Widower's love and greif which were both extreme. He had indeed o much love for her, that he had none for life; Now that he was no longer living, he would gladly have been laid in the grave with her: he had alo o much greif for the los of her that all mention of comfort was a new way of afflicting him, that all viits were troubleome to him, and that all endeavors to appeae his orrow proved ineffectuall, thoe of his other freinds who practied all the meanes of doing it that they could devie, thoe of the Princes Floria who ent Alexis to him upon that errand, and thoe of the King who laboured it with a particular concerne.

While Alcidor was pending dayes and nights in lamenting his los, Polianis conidering
he could have no heirs to his Crown by the infertile Agenora, upon mature deliberations concluded to divorce her, and though he was one of the highet born Princees of Aia, and her beauty and ingeny ran parallell to her birth, yet whether he preferred the good of the publike before her own interet, or whether he was waied by any private reaons, he tetified no other relih of the reolution, than what dipoed her to conent to it. This notable eparation was no ooner known by the Potentates of Aia, but they all ought that Augut mans alliance; Princees were offered him together with Principalities: but of all the pourtraitures that were preented to him none pleaed him o much as that of the Princes Partenice, and with her he tranlated and accompliht a marriage. The conjunction of thee two Starrs of the greatet magnitude and plendor and of mot benigne influence making China all a bright Heaven by their hining in it, made it yet more o by their having another illutrious Star for their iue, a Son whoe birth made his mother's pains weet, his fathers glories full and the people's joyes alike great and univerall. In the publike rejoicing which was made upon this occaion Alcidor who had till then done nothing ele
but igh over the fate of Dorame thought him elf in duty obliged to be a party. He therefore induced his oul to dimis ome part of thoe black thoughts which reigned in it and dret his face in the characters, which it had not a long time worn, of cheerfullnes. Which the King and Queen eeing and conidering that it was an effect of the interet which he took in their happines they told him they were his glad debtours for it, and taking the opportunity improved it to cleer his pirit from thoe thick clouds, with which it was till overcat. Here in there workt with them all of quality that were acquainted with him, and they had the ucces that they deired; he promied them not to think o much of Tombes for the future but to divert himelf, and accordingly frequenting the palace, viiting Ladies, and uing recreations, he by little and little chaed away his melancholy, it contributing to his repoe that the Princes Floria was by the earnet perwaions of her freinds and by the inetimable merit of Eridan wonne to receive him for her husband, and thought herelf happy in him.

It being impoible that a man of worth as Alcidor, detined by the reerves of fate to give of his race to that flourihing empire to
which he had given extraordinary remarkes of his valour, hould remain allwayes a widower; after he had been a good time o, he aw at a ball a Lady from falling in love with whom he was not able with all his trength to defend himelf.
