Her habit told him he was a Widow and upon enquiry he learnt that he was Widow to Palemon who took Prince Meander prioner in battle, that he was iued of one of the mot antient houes of the Kingdome and that he was Mitres of a mot plentiful fortune. This he liked very well, but that which captivated him and made his heart hers was that her face exactly reembled Dorame's, that the eyes, the hape, the features, the aire of the one, were the eyes, the hape, the features, the aire of the other. His paion for her riing from this pring grew to a large, deep, and rapid tream, when by getting acquaintance with her, he found he was like Dorame not in body only, but in mind alo, that the wit and virtues of the one, were the wit and vertues of the other. Thinking therefore that as often as he aw Florinda he aw Dorame and beleiving that after Dorame, he could not find o meritorious an object of his affections as Florinda he taied not long before he addret himelf to
her in the quality of a lover, and what with the King's Favouring of his Suite, what with her friends and particularly the dicreet Celida her Siter telling her, that to make herelf happy he mut take him for her husband, what with the affectionate obervances which he ued towards her, what with the unmatchable accomplihments which he aw in him, he was wonne to admit him in that quality, after he had driven to depair with her coldnes many gallant perons who ambitioned the title of her ervant, and not only o, but to love him alo as much as ever did Floria; Ataia, Carmelia or Dorame. Cupid indeed had no reaon to be les favourable to him, than Mars, for he had acrificed upon the Altars of the one, as well as of the other, and that with equal devotion.

During the tranaction of thee amours as Alcidor was one day returning from the chae, there met him an unknown and in o handome a fahion requeted him to be his Second in a combate which was that hour aigned him, telling him who he was (and he was Periander) and who were of the other part, and what was the ground of the Quarrel that he without any farther ceremony went along with him. Fighting they
killed thoe with whom they fought, returning to Paquin they found themelves to be Cozens, meeting with in a day or two, their action paing about upon the wing of fame, they contented themelves with the elogies that were given them under the afe names of Incognitoes without being o imprudently vain, as to chalenge the interet which they had in them. But Loivel whom they left for dead upon the Feild, being enough acquainted with their perons, as well as too much, with their valours, before he died made report of both. Herewith all the Court preently ounded, and it was not long before it came to Florinda. So he gave her lover to undertand by the evere reproof with which he entertained him the next time that he aw him: but the excues which he made for what he had done, and the promies wherewith he aured her that he would ingage him elf no more in uch Quarells eaily obtained his pardon of her.

Hence Celida took occaion to repreent to her Siter that it very much imported her to haten her marriage with him. Alcidor, alledged he, hath too much of the man in him to turn his back to honor, or to refue the combate when obliged to it. His • irm
active and known courage will be continually ready to carry him into dangers, but it may not always bring him afe out of them; for though he is one of the mot valiant men in the world, he is not immortall, a misfortune may befall him: but when he is your husband, your influences will retrain him from hazarding his life, and he will preerve himelf for love of you, when he would not, for his own ake. Procure therefore as oon as you can this good to him and to yourelf.

Florinda, liking and following the counell, by her inflaming forces, and expert management of them bred in Alcidor o eager a thirt of having their marriage peeded that it was, before a month was gone by, dipatched. It was celebrated with the preence of the King and Queen and everall Princes and Princees, and the celebrity went beyond all example; that of his wedding with Dorame was excelled by it. And not only the pomp of the latter was more plendid, than that of the former, but the ucces alo was much better, For Dorame lived with him not one Year, but Florinda many Years; by Dorame he had no Child that urvived her, by Florinda he had 3 Sonnes and 2 Daughters, all of them of rare Endowments.

For a long time was Polianis as happy a King, and China as flourihing a Kingdome as any in the World, they had no experience what the troubles of arms meant: but they were at length diturbed by the Indian King, who as if unable to be quiet, but in the inquietudes of War; And ambitious of meriting the title of Conqueror, and upurper together, beeiged a Town with the people of which, who lived then, and live till in a common wealth, Polianis had a very trict alliance. His uccor therefore being begged by them he caued the drum to beat, the Trumpet to ound and an army to advance, of which that great Captain and Prince Roileon found him elf contrained to ay that he never aw a braver Nobles or more complete Fantains, and which triking a terror into the enemy, made them fly before them, handled them very much to their dammage in their flight and diipated them o, that there was no fear left of their return. In this expedition in which all was done, that either the glory of Polianis or the relief, of his allies required, Melicertus being Generall, Alcidor was his Leiftenant Generall and Feild-marhall of all the Cavalry, and the Cheifes and their triumphant return preenting themelves to the King, he
pay'd him the econd honors, which Melicerlus was o far from looking upon with an envious eye that he pake of him as if he deerved the firt. What wellcome his Florinda gave him is left to them to judge who know how high the pleaure ries when after

About this time a tutor was to be provided for Melinta, a Minor who was neice to Alcidor, ole heires of Orgeries and owner of a beauty and Gentile • es, which inchanted the World, and there appeared Candidates of the Charge everall of her kinred whom (as they pretended at leat) not o much a conideration of her great fortunes as a love of her mot amiable qualities made olicitors to get her into their hands. But Alcidor who loved her as his Child and whom he loved as her Father, who affectionately deired to have her with him and with whom he earnetly deired to be, who conidered that his competitors were les neerely related to her, than he, and of no more exalted quality, proecuted his deire with a courage and prudence anwerable to the equity which he had on his ide, and was by the conent of thoe who would have
upplanted him ettled in the Governement of her, that which he with a mot jut, wie and tender care dicharged, and in the dicharge improved her uncommon qualifications to a full perfection; She was reckoned the Grace of the Virgins of that age, and he is eteemed the ornament of the Matrons of this: but Melinta's virtues and worths are far greater, than to be hut up in a little room, an entire Book is neceary for their decription.

Peace and the age care of Polianis having repleniht his Coffers with vat heaps of Money, and the gallantry of his dipoition carrying him after the otenees of love to the roughnees of War he determined with himelf to make the Barbarians feel the weight and harpnes of his Sword. He armed o puiantly that all the great Maters of the World took notice of it, but which of them all he aimed at, was a mytery which they could by no means dicover. China warmed with Souldiers as banks with pimires, the Canon was upon the roade, the Captains had their Rendevous and Alcidor had an imployment amongt them the mot glorious that he had ever had. But, oh dire event! the day before the King was to take the Field, as he was buied about the Coronation
of his Queen, he was in the midle of his capitall City mortally aainated by one of his ubjects. This mot detetable blow put all China into out-cries, atonihment, deperation and Tears; but no body was deeplyer truck with it, than was Alcidor. He was hereby defeated of the Viceroy-hip of Foquiem in which Poli • nis had ome dayes before told him he would ettle him; but this was little or nothing to him; that which affected him was, that his overeign was in this horried manner depoiled of life, who was one of the mot Augut Princes that ever wazed Scepter, who gave the Crown of China abundantly more lutre, than he received from it, and who honne upon him in particular with very benig • e rayes of grace and et a high value upon his ervices. With the thought of this his oul was for ome time rendered unable to dicharge its functions.

Though furious tirres ue to be the conequents of the unhappy fall of Monarcks, there happened no uch thing upon that of Polianis, the Miniters of tate by their indutrious prudence preventing all micheifes that might in probability have arrived. His eldet Sonne Aritenus was without delay or obtruction declared King and Partenice r •
gent
during his minority, and ome lutres of his reign pat in tranquillity as they began; but there is no fair weather which is not attended upon with ome foul, and o it proved here. Polidamus ucceor to Atalant • s, who died oon after that the peace was ettled between him and Polianis, ent propoitions of marriage between himelf and the Princes Ariana Siter to Aritenus, and between Aritenus and his Siter the Princes Callirea. About which watches all things being after ripe conultations concluded upon, and preparations made on both ides for the nuptialls, when one would have gues' that every body would have eteemed this double alliance very much conducing to the advantage of China, and when there was mot reaon to think of peace and rejoycing, there appeared ome in armes to top the current of the Kings properity; but notwithtanding thee he went with Partenice to receive the wife that was detined him, cauing withall an army to follow him by which they were quickly reduced. There was not long between, and there aroe another torm of more dangerous conequence; The Princes, as well thoe of the blood as others, armed againt Aritenus, and Aritenus againt the Princes. The King making Generall
of his Army Policaris Uncle to Florinda, and her husband Alcidor Cleife Marhall of the Camp, this latter having taken leave of his wife, who heartily wi • h • ill to the authors of the Stirres that took her husband from her and carried him into dangers, and being gotten into the Feild, within two dayes journey of Paquin beat up the quarters of Prince Porirus and took his bet hores and plate. In equele of this the two armies approaching one another, he was of the opinion not to let Prince Clorimax pas the river Caromoran but to ight him, and in all probability he had that day done the King very ignall ervice, if his counell had been followed, but Policaris was of another judgment and was to be oberved. He notwithtanding hirmiht the enemy o that a great number of them were laid dead upon the place, while the others made their paage.

He after this had order given him to go and receive upon the Frontier of Junia a thouand Fantains and two thouand Hore that were raied in Brama, and to conduct them to the eige of Molineu; that which having very expeditiouly performed he was with the other Cheifes practiing to force the Town when intelligence came to
the Camp that Poligan was extinguiht. It oon came alo to Prince Calitus who defended the Town, and it no ooner came to him, but he ent word to the Commanders of the eige that having no other reaon to depart from the King, neither he nor the other Princes and Confederates, but the inolencies of that Monter of pride and common enemy of Princes, now that he was removed, he would without any more delay return to him. The punihment indeed which was jutly given to that ambitious o changed the poture of affaires that not only Cali • lus but alo the Princes and Grandees that had taken up arms againt the King, laid them down and reumed their obedience to him. Upon this return of peace the Miniters of State conidering of dimiing the forces which they had called from foreign oile, ome of the principall of them judged it advieable to give the Bramians a grave in China; which Alcidor hearing as boldly as generouly repirted to it that to cut in peices trangers that came to the aitance of the King was a mot hatefull treachery and would be an eternell reproach both the King and Kingdome, and that for his part he was reolved to put himelf in the head of them that as he had had the charge of bringing
them into a trange Countrey o he might have the glory of carrying them back (or of endeavouring it at the leat) to their own, without uffering as much as he was able any dammage to be done them either in bodies or goods. This he did, as he aid, and had for recompence the particular thankes and Eulogies of the Cheifs (from whom the baenes uggeted againt them lay not hid) and the general, good word and will of the nation for ever after.

A few weeks paing Partenice under pretext of being ill dealt with betook herelf to armes, and the authors of her doing o endeavoured by promies of extraordinary remunerations and by all other likely arts to draw Alcidor to her party, but he plainely anwered that from the intant that he had left the league he had preerved his lozalty intemerate to the great Polianis, and that there were no propoitions o advantageous or any thing ele o powerfull as to be able to corrupt it to his Son Aritenus. According to what he aid, the Queens army being in the Province of Honao and the King advancing to ight them though with one much weaker, he advanced with him their Feild-Marchall, and et them in battalia, the King complaining to him that he had not a
Prince about him, your faithfull ervants, Sir, aid he, I have allwayes heart ay many name themelves companions of Princes, when it comes to fighting, having taken the right wing and given order for fight, he put himelf at the head of the Kings Company of men at armes and charged the advere Cavalry with a violence which totally routed them, their infantery alo at the very intant running the ame fortune with them. Upon this ucces, the glory of which was given to Alcidor, the Queen reconciled herelf with her Son who treated her with all the weetnes diireable.

Florinda thought now he hould keep Alcidor many lutres with her, but they proved not many months. Thoe of the new Sect of Religion beginning enterprizes of hotility contrary to their duty in the Province of Quancy, and the King making an expedition thither to repres them; he, as he was bound attended him, and his attendance was not unerviceable to him, the places which they made their ayles being very much by his conduct and aitance reduced.

From Quancy, leaving there ufficient forces, the King pat into Honao, and to bridle the revolted which here fortified
themelves caued to be raied eight thouand Foot and three thouand Hore. Of thee he made Alcidor Cheife and commanded the Governors of the Townes of that flourihing province to furnih him with armes, Canon and other necearies of War and to obey him as their abolute Commander, returning himelf to Paquin: And with this trength and power that ingular man taking Chianchio for his tation o uppret and awed the enemies who held Quichio and other places, that they durt attempt nothing or carce look abroad.

He thus following the road of honor, his eldet Son Silvanus generouly trod in his Steps and having hewn himelf in eminent occaions had the charge given him of the Colours of the Kings Company of men at armes, as had alo Belanis that of the Captain of the King's Guards in the room of Palamion who as a partizan of the rebellion was declared guilty of high treaon.

The King again after a while leaving Paquin with gravid deignes of bringing back to their allegiance thoe who had eparated themelves from it and of re-etablihing the peace which their eparation had broken dipatched orders to Alcidor to come to him to Ancheou with two thouand Foot (ending
Arpaax Field-Marhall to command the ret of his army in his abence) and he in obervance of them imbarking his men upon the river of Cantao renderd himelf with them at the place aigned eight dayes after the King. As oon as he was come the King appointing him to attake one of the uburbs of the Town which had not yet been fallen upon, he lead on his men, overthrew the barricadoes, beat back the defenders, made himelf Mater of the place and there fixt his quarters. Having orders again to beat and way the Campagne, and while he was executing them with his two elder Sons having notice that three hundred Hore of the Garrion of Holepaou were gone to the eaide to meet a Convoy that was coming to them, he was upon them at the point of day, put them to the rout and eized their equipage and what they came for. Returned to the eige he with the attakes that he made and other parts of Martialime that he performed, o intimidated the cheife who had ingaged himelf to defend the Town. (He was Ariances Brother to Filiten) that he thought himelf happy in urrendring it upon compoition. At the urrender he by the Kings command et the army in form of battell while the enemy
came out of the Town, and a Garrion was placed in it, and after that conducted Ariances and his men to two parts of it to defend them from being ill ued.
After Anchieu there capitulated and yeelded Holepaou, forced to it by want of the upplies which Alcidor had deprived them of, and after Holepaou everall other Towns to which the King led his forces.

About this time as Alcidor was coming all alone from a covent of Religious, whither he would have no body accompany him in regard he had buines of ecrecy as well as importance with one of the Covent, there met him two Gentlemen of the Regiment of the Kings Guards, who accoted him with complaints of an injury which they had received and which they could not pocket up, and he very civilly asking them what was the name of him, who had offended him and what the offence, it is yourelf, Sir, aid one of them, letting him ee that he knew him, who have abued us, at the delivering up of Ancheou, when we would contrary to your order have gone into the Town, trikeing us with the flat of your Sword. Would you then, replied Alcidor, have atisfaction for this? Though, added he, I might ue my eminent charge in armes for
my dipenation, I am nevertheles ready to give it you, only let the one off you draw of while I have to do with the other. With thoe words taking to task the forwardet of them he in a minute had wounded him in the thigh and diarmed him. After which paing the next way to the other, he found him ready in tead of fighting to aske pardon and he freely gave it him. The King afterwards coming to know the buines and ordering the Souldiers to be puniht; he generouly procured both their pardons of him. But he withall incurred himelf the cenure of the other Field-Marhalls who told him, that they would not follow his example in atisfying every one that took things ill from them: To which, you may do as you ee good, replied he, but it is a humor which I by narure have, and which I know not how to leave off, never to refue the combate when it is demanded of me. Not that I acquit myelf from being reproveable for it, or that I hall not endeavor to moderate it by the directions of reaon. Acting o, aid Arpaax to him, and not hazarding your life, which is of conequence and ought to be taken care of, upon occaions of frivolous moment, you will be o far from impairing your glory that you will increae it. If you mut
die by the Sword, it ought to be at the head of an army and in the ervice of your King who values you more than all his Captains beides. I hould conent to what you ay, returned Alcidor to him, was I owner of your fortitude and other worths; but ince I well know to what degree I am to be conidered, pardon me, if I tell you that I place your Elogy of me in the range of flattery. Truth deerves not to be o tiled, aid Arpaax again, and you would very much injure your judgment hould you not own the difference between the one and the other. But to make you acknowledge for true that which I have aid concerning the account in which his Majety holds you, I need only put you in mind of the choice which he hath made of you, abolutely and in quality of Generall to command his armyes, and of the many meritorious and inclitous actions which you have atchieved in War, as in your element. You handle me with too much quicknes, replied Alcidor to him, and I hall chooe rather not to deny what you ay, than to contet with you any longer.

Inquenhu, while everall of the Towns that were its companions in mutinying reverted themelves into the Kings hands, till
diplaying the enignes of rebellion, Alcidor was ent thither by him to learn the tate of the place and enemy. Returning and reporting what he had learnt, he was appointed by a counell of War to go thither again the next day to oberve the places at which they might aault it. As he was doing what he was appointed they of the Town allied out upon him, but he received them in uch a manner that a great part of them never re-entred but remained behind upon the wayes. Two dayes after they et upon the Town in three places, on the right hand the couragious Belican commanding, on the left the judicious Brielin, the middle the Gallant Alcidor, and they all bravely performed their parts, but Alcidor with o much advantage that he was the Cheife (if not the ole) caue that the Town was preently delivered up. Here Aritenus left him to order all as he aw good with eight Companies of the regiment of his forein Guards, and as many of that of his Chinoie, but with injunction to be with him within nine dayes at Quichio. Coming hither as he was injoined, he with Prince Tirenas with o much life attaked the Town that all within trembled with feare and lookt upon themelves as at the lat gape.

During this eige Ermautain going with all the Cavalry to uccor a catle of importance which Filitin and Aigremont had beeiged, Silvanus who was then ixteen Years old followed him with the Kings Company of men at armes whom he in his Fathers room commanded, and nine hundred of the Hore, when at their arrivall they found the place taken, for the re-taking of it braving the whole army of the enemies, and having a conflict with them in which they took two of their Canons, he therein did things worthy of Alcidor's Son and which made the Generall in a particular manner admire him. He received in this occaion a wound with a Pitoll-hot, but the Generall taking care of him and making him to do o of himelf, he was quickly well of it.

During the ame iege of Quichio, Alcidor executing ome orders and the enemy appearing, his econd Son Dolompus attempted together with others to force a barricade, and venturing o far that the beeiged iued out upon him, after the • ight had been for ome time very obtinately maintained on both ides, excellently mounted as he was, he in the veiw of more than five hundred Volunteers with a Pitoll-hot killed one of the Officers that commanded at the Barricade,
which he forced and returned victorious to his Father.

Aritenus after a while upon ome weigh •• ty coniderations drawing off his forces from Quichio, Alcidor was left by him with ten thouand men to command as Generall in the Countrey, and the Countrey being thick own with enemies he had frequent encounters with them, not without making the •
feel the heavynes of his arm and dread <>
But while he handled them roughly in that part where he was, they were indutrious to revenge themelves ele where, and their indutry propered o that they urprized a very coniderable Town. Advertiement hereof being brought him, and that the catle of it held out till for the King, though it was in the Wort Seaon of Winter, he ent men to the aitance of the catle who by ladders and cords planted a-long the walls got into it in depight of all oppoition, and at the ame time went himelf and approached the Town with Batteries of Canon. Thee approaches proceeding lowlier, than he deired, and thoe of the Town hewing themelves one day in the mazers n • r the walls, he with five hundred Gentlemen flew upon them, trawed the ground with their bodies as with ruhes and
beat them up to the very gate without looing any more than two Gentlemen and a Trumpet that ounded the charge. From this he going on to other executions they who had taken the Town the fourth day after the eige was formed delivered it up to him upon artic'les that were les beneficiall to them, than they imagined.

Though Alcidor had o cooled the hear of the boldet of the revolted in the province, with which he was intruted that there durt none of them hew their heads againt him, contrary to the opinion with which they had been imprinted of making uch progrees that they hould give Laws to them, from whom it was their duty to receive them, and though he had long had an earnet mind to make a viit to his dear Florinda, and he conjured him to do it every time that he wrote to him, yet he durt never give himelf and her that atisfaction for fear there hould ome diorder or micheif fall out in his abence. He tuck cloe to his charge and with his painful cares and vigilancies renderd himelf o formidable to the advere party that they fled from the place where they knew he was as from an abode of the plague, o far were they from attaking him or forming parties to
urprize him. Nor were they the common Souldiers only that thus dreaded him, but the mot renowned ••• ifes alo, who hunned meeting him all that they were able, as having indeed experimented, that for Alcidor to conquer was no more, than his ordinary practice.

At the beginning of the pring Aritenus, who had pat the winter at Paquin, parted from it, to go againt Ariances, who, he was aured, contrary to the faith which he had worn at the rendring up of Ancheou never more to bear arms againt him, had a body of men about him towards the Province of Foquiam. He found him in the Iland of Tumbaca where he had hut himelf up with an opinion that it was inacceible; others alo had the ame thoughts of it: but the King by a kind of miracle dicovered a place that was foordable, where no body in the memory of man had pat, and paing it fell with o much life upon the enemies that they were almot in a moment cut and broken in pieces, and their Canon and Baggage taken, their Commander aving himelf by flight. Adorned with the laurells of this victory • e laid eige to Chiquiano and within a few dayes took it. Thence he marched afreh towards Quichio; upon the way whither
Alcidor meeting him with five hundred Gentlemen, and mot of the officers of the army that was under him, he with extraordinary carees thankt him for the notable ervices that he had done him in that Countrey, and in tead of going to Quichio, as it was beleived he would, went and et down before Quamchieu, giving Alcidor ix thouand Foot and all the ordinary Cavalry of pay, to fight Filitin, who it was aid, would endeavor to uccor the Town. But not long after the eige was laid, Prince Meander commanding the Army at Land and Prince Dorilas that at ea, fell out the navall battell of Liampo, in which o uperbe a victory was obtained over the forces of the rebells that they were throughout the Kingdome contrained to ue to the King for his grace, that which he according to the uuall weetnes of his dipoition granted them.

A univerall calm recovered, Aritenus viited his Provinces of Canta •
and Foquiam, but not without taking Alcidor along with him, as he did alo in the other little journeys, which he made for the good of his affairs.

At their return to Paquin Florinda being ready there to receive her Alcidor they after their long eparation, it will eaily be believved,
met with an unpeakable joy. Having taid a month or two at Court, leaving Silvanns there, they retired into the Countrey, having pent half a Year in the Countrey they re-pat to the Court. In both places they led a mot happy life, happy in regard of the innocent amenities with which the Countrey erved them, and of the braver delights, with which the Court entertained them, happy, in regard that in the Countrey, they were by the Nobility and Gentry mot kindly and civilly repected, by the commonalty little les than upertitiouly worhipt, and that at the Court Aritenus and Callirea miled upon them and made much of them as the principal ornaments of their royall tate, happy, in regard that their Children were by all eteemed as rare examples, their eldet Sons Silvanus and Dolompus (the latter of which his Father had ent to Mongul) of mot genuine courage and addres, their younget Son Lidiam of mot pregnant hopes, their two Daughters Deli • a and Serapis of mot charming beauty, wit and virtue! But cheifly happy in regard of the reciprocation of e • tire love between themelves, the exact conort of their humors and wills, and the liberty which they had of a mutual fruition,
that which was agreeable to the one being o to the other, and though they had been married many Years, as pathetick dearnees continually paing between them, as if they had not been joyned together a month.

Together with Alcidor and Florinda (though carce by the ame meaure with them) the Court alo was happy, it was wholly a theatre of gallantries: War and the things that affright and molet were carce o much as mentioned, all the dicoure was of love, of the chae, of dances, of feats, of all the more elegant recreations of humane life. There indeed pread a felicity over all the Kingdome, Heaven bleing it with a erene tranquillity and an exuberancy of good things. But the tranquillity was at length diturbed, the workers of the pat tempets raiing new ones; Liampo forgetful of the mercy which the King had hewed it when at the next door to ruine renewed its old factions, and the Ile of Varella was powerfully and harply aaulted by the Japonoies. Aftertaind of this the King, who armed with peed, to prevent the micheif with which he beleived the Ile of Chapai threatened, commanded Alcidor to put himelf into it, and it was in an intant
that he had et foot on ground there with a great number of Gentlemen, who reckoned it a fair glory to fight under his colours.

To help him make good his charge, there was quickly ent to him by the diligence of the admirable Oretes eight thouand Foot and fifteen hundred Hore, and with thee aids he o well dipoed the Iland to a defence, that the Japonoies coming three dayes after to view it, found it too well fortified and managed, to be aaulted. After this the King eeing that the deigne of Callimorus was wholly et to force the Ile of Varella, caued a good part of Alcidors forces to be joyned with others and make a decent thither, and the ucces was that they compelled the Japonoies with great los to retire to their hips.

Callimorus being gone (Ariances who came with him fled alo back with him to take refuge at Meaco) Alcidor who had not as yet tirred from Chapai was orderd by the King to go Feild-marhall to the eige of Liampo. He was again upon intelligence that Ro • ilus had forces in the Feild which he intended to put into Liampo, or ele to divert the iege with them, ordered by him with eight hundred Hore to go eek him out and ight
him; and taking with him Silvanus and Dolompus (the latter of which, the newes of the arming had brought from Mongul, where he had been dangerouly wounded at the iege of Teudac,) he made his coure, but could no where meet with them that he looked for.

Returned to the Kings quarters he had pat but few dayes there before he received the newes of the icknes, and within a few houres after of the death of Florinda, newes which filled his great heart as full of greif as it could poible hold and not break, and which put his two Sonnes all in adnes. He had Condolers of his unhappines the King and all of his acquaintance, and, when eeing the change of his habit they had learnt the caue of it, the whole army, the King withal together with others his freinds reading lectures to him of patience and comfort. He had indeed for arguments of quieting himelf, that he was fallen into a leep for which it was below a oul of true courage to torment it elf, and from which all his Stock of Tears and ighes could not awaken her, that the Queen and Court had taken all the care and pains about her, not only, which humanity, but which alo a zealous tendernes could ugget, and that he
had neither himelf nor any other to complain of for his not eeing her in her icknes, the firt moment that he fell ill a Cur • ier being dipatched to him with notice of it, and he dying within ix hours after, of which alo he had as quick a meenger. But after all he had an earnet mind to throw aide his charge and arms and go weep over her: that which top him from doing it was a jut conideration that his overeign had preent need of his ervice and demanded it, and that therefore to leave him would be to incurre an opprobry from which he hould never be able to clear himelf. Let us wait therefore, aid he to himelf, to go pay our lat duties to that part of our dear Florinda that remaines, till this rebellious City, which is at the even of its being ubdued, be fully o. It is not now the firt time that we have received an infelicity of this kind, we have too well learnt the ad uage of reenting a wife's death to forget it, and hall we make les reitance againt the oppreions of affliction now, than heretofore when our pirit had more of impurity, than now by the advantage of age it hath? The exercie of Tears is to be left to women, we have reaon to hew ourelves more contant. And beides
into what region is Florinda gone that we hould do nothing but lament for her? Is he in an abode that is inacceible to us? Is he not there, where all faithfull ouls have a place reerved for them, and where it is not long before we hall ee her again? Let us forbear then to igh over her tate of blis, and reume the temper which we had before the los of her, that o we may the better imploy ourelves as our duty and neceity require in things importing to the peedy reduction of the enemy. This reolution tooke and followed Alcidor, and by his advice and example his Sonnes alo, very much to the atisfaction of the King in regard both of the benefit which thereby they would receive themelves, and of that alo which would accrew from it to his own affairs.

The Japonoies having a good mind to uccour Liampo, but in regard of the invincible obtacles that tood in their way contenting themelves to appear upon the ea and retire, the beeiged though they had thereby their hopes frutrated continued obtinately enough to defend themelves; but at length great numbers of them being detroyed by the arms of the beiegers, and greater by icknes and famine, o that the Town made
hat to be deert of inhabitants, they were neceitated to beg the Kings mercy, and what they necearily begged, he freely indulged. Having matered this City, which three Kings his predeceours could not do, and re-etabliht there the old Religion of China, he returned in triumph to Paquin; and thither Alcidor waited upon him, and then applied himelf to perform the upreme honours to Florinda. When he came to ee her body in the Coffin, he was wholly poet with greif, and his entiments were more equitable, than to be blamed: but his reaon after a while making good its empire and tempering his paion, his Cheif care was taken up about her funerals, and he laid her in the grave with a State in which Mourning was renderd full of Majety.

While the King continued at Paquin Alcidor was always about him, and new occaions calling him abroad, he and his Sons attended him. They were of his Cheife aitants when he forced his way through the barricades and other obtacles that hut it up, and diipated thoe that oppoed it, releived Baiador that was traightly beeiged upon the Prince Nimeis, and contrained Alcippus who had caued this trouble to ue to him for peace.

Affairs being quieted on that ide, Aritenus left Clomedon there with ufficient forces to maintain the quiet, and pat into the Province of Quiechen in quet of Filitin who with great numbers of men ravaged the Countrey; but though this Prince was the grand Cheife of the diobedient party, and had the boldnes to counter-act the Kings authority, he durt no where appear before him. In this expedition Tocichu was begirt by the King, taken by aault and put all in blood. At this eige Dolompus was wounded with a Muquet-hot in the head together with other little hurts, while his elder Brother had better fortune, though he continually engaged himelf in mot hazardous ervices.

Taking warning by Tocichu, Hilani opened its gates to the King: Hilani leading the way everal other Townes returned to their allegiance, Filitin giving them the alutary counel to do o, who himelf alo recounted his diloialty and obtained pardon of the King both for himelf, and all the party of which he had been head and protector. Things being brought to this iue, the King returned to Paquin, leaving the great Oretes and Alcidor to receive the Townes to the obedience that they owed him and to caue their fortifications to be razed: and they
were not long before they were again with him with an account of their negotiation which perfectly atisfied him.

Envious of the Univeral peace which China now enjoyed, and reolved as it eems to hew himelf, what he was reputed to be, the mot incontant Prince in the World Alcippus performed nothing of what he had promied Aritenus when he made peace with him, but by freh and thoe unufferable provocations obliged him to recommence War. Oretes pat the mountains with fourty thouand men, took Chaquoam in the ight of Alcatus and put that flitting prince in uch a fright that he taied no longer before he repented of what he had done. Aritenus himelf alo in the equele marched with a great army into Camboia; Alcidor who was Field-marhall of it led the Van when they entred the Countrey and finding Prince Euebes retiring with his Army was earnet to have bid them battle: but whatoever clear day he aw of utterly defeating them, and whatoever aurance he gave the King of it, he could not get his conent that he might fall on, he would reerve, he aid, his forces to make himelf Mater of all the places of trength in Camboia, and to out their Prince in his Shirt. But it could not
well be that the two Armies hould meet without triking a blow, Alcidor moved the Quarel, prefaced with ome skirmihes, made a looe, broke into the midt of the enemies, trawed the ground with five hundred of their bodies and retreated gloriouly, the King approving the exploit though not agreeing to the attempt. At length the whole conduct of the Army in Camboia was left to him, and he beeiged Townes and took them by the meaure of quickly bringing under the whole State.

Daiador in the mean time the mot coniderable place of its Countrey was vigorouly beeiged by the Indians who reolved to take it or dye, if they were not hindered by a greater trength, than theirs, and in all appearance they had not long to tay to be poet of it, o low had they brought it. Thither therefore Aritenus with all peed caued thirty thouand men to advance under three of his mot experienced Captains, and they with Sword in one hand and Pitol in the other bravely et it at liberty. Never received Alcatus uch an affront, and he was the more enible of it becaue he received it in his native Countrey. To ee indeed himelf and his army proudly triumpht over by the Chinoies while they forced them digracefully
to dilodge from before the Town about which they lay encampt waiting only the hour in which according to the compoition that was made, they were to enter; It was a dipleaure which he was o far from being able to diget that he endured not to urvive it, but within a few dayes after marched off the World. Bajador releived the Indian King, and the Potentates that ided with him were contraind to make a peace with Aritenus upon conditions advantageous enough to him to declare him Victour in the War. The Catles, Townes, places which upon thee conditions he delivered back to Alcippus were all monuments of Alcidors virtue that had conquerd them. Indeed to combate the enemy in their own Countrey and vanquih them, to inviron Townes and take them, to aault Places and win them, by all the methods of valour to render formidable the arms of the jut Aritenus were his ordinary exercies (both at other times and) while he had the care of the War againt Alcippus.

But the labours of this extraordinary man mut have an end; they are glorious enough for him, they have dret his name with flowers of honour which will never wither, the grand Cheifes of the World dicoure
of him with elogies of praie which poterity will with publicke voice tranmit to the end of time, and Aritenus regards him as one whoe Sword hath trucke as many important blowes in his ervice as any's whooever, and whoe merit might plead title to as rich rewards. In anwer to his merit he reolves to ettle him in the Viceroy-hip which Polianis a few dayes before his death deigned him: But as he is about to do it he is called to arms by the Province of Orgones for the Chatiing of that Felonious. The leading of this War is committed to Alcidor; but when he hould take the Field, he falls ick. It is at firt a heavy urcharge of trouble to him beides that of his icknes that he is hindered from waiting upon his Mater and gathering the roe which is at the end of the thorn. But when he findes by the coure of his dieae that he can in all likelyhood have none but a fatall iue of it, he looks upon thoe former thoughts as no longer eaonable, he wholly applies himelf to think of his retreate, the honours of the World he with a holy elevation of mind contemnes, and hath his deires grow cold to every thing ele, but to go and enjoy a purity of happines with his Dorame and Florinda. In fine eeing his end at hand he with mot
age remontrances incites his Children to follow the way of virtue and glory, and then compoes himelf with a pious courage to undergo the aaults of death which he feels beginning upon him, and which within a quarter of an hour dilodge his heroick oul.
